SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures Senator Schacht for his conduct in making use in the Senate adjournment debate on Monday May 29 of an illicitly-obtained transcript of a private meeting of Senators and Members and his subsequent destruction of the material.

It is now a little over a year since we moved into this building. From the time we arrived, senators have been expressing concern about the perils of living in an era of high technology. On behalf of the Opposition, for example, I raised with you, Mr President, the question of whether the sophisticated equipment attached to our telephone system would enable the telephone numbers dialled by senators to be recorded, in the way that the hotels and motels that we occupy so often record those numbers. I was assured that attention had been paid to that aspect of privacy. In Estimates Committee A senators have raised a succession of concerns about the security in this sophisticated building, about the capacity of the recording system to record when, perhaps, things are not meant to be recorded-about our capacity to have any privacy at all in this electronic age.

That is not, of course, the subject of this censure motion. I simply remind the Senate that over the past 12 months I and numerous other senators have expressed concern at the potential invasion of privacy in this age of sophisticated electronics. Yesterday, Mr President, I welcomed your statement that you and the Speaker of the House of Representatives were taking seriously the concerns that had been expressed by both Opposition and Government senators and members about the potential for flagrant breaches of our civil liberties. I note that at the same time as Senator Schacht was making his grubby use of his grubbily obtained material, a more experienced Australian Labor Party man, perhaps a Labor man from a different tradition-the Hon. Gordon Scholes-was raising with the Speaker his concerns about the abuses that can occur in this building. In raising those matters at the beginning of this censure debate, Mr President, I say simply that we believe that you, as the person we have elected as the President of the Senate, of all senators, will devote your energies to trying to ensure that outsiders-people of ill will-will not be able to abuse the communications system in this building and make private communications impossible.

That is a very important issue which stands on its own. But this censure motion is not about that; it is about the fact that the best systems in the world-systems designed to avoid abuse by criminal elements, by subversive elements, by those who would destroy the Parliament, and perhaps even our society-cannot protect us against anything if fundamental ethics are not applied to the behaviour of senators and members in this building. Ultimately, the only thing that can protect us from the sort of subversion that we would all wish to avoid is a bit of honesty. Senator Schacht is a new member who comes straight out of the splendid bureaucratic mould of the modern Australian Labor Party. I doubt whether he has ever done an honest day's work in his life, but he has certainly done plenty of work for the Labor Party and moved the numbers around and so on. He came into this place and in a debate on the adjournment quoted extensively from what was clearly an illicitly obtained transcript of a private meeting. It was not even a private meeting just of Opposition senators and members but an all-party private meeting dealing with one of the most sensitive issues of public policy that we can be called upon to deal with.

This censure motion is not about that issue and it should be no part of that debate. I suppose its only relevance is that, in the range of issues we are called upon to deal with, the question of abortion and the right to life is one of the most vexed and most difficult. The difficulties are not confined to the Opposition or to the Labor Party. It is an issue which men and women of goodwill can feel fundamentally divided on, and the public statement of the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, over recent days is just the most recent illustration of the complexity and difficulty of that issue. I say again that its only relevance to this debate is that when senators and members get together for the purpose of trying to work out how to promote their view of the public interest-a matter which is fraught with very great personal and political difficulty for all participants on all sides-it is absurd that those people cannot meet in a committee room of this place without having their conversations illicitly taken down and transcribed. If we are to believe Senator Schacht-and as a person deemed to be an honourable senator we must believe him-the transcript was handed to Senator Schacht to use in the way that he used it in the adjournment debate in this place.

It is the wholehearted view of the Opposition that Senator Schacht, in the difficult business of politics-and we all acknowledge its difficulty-has fundamentally failed to acknowledge standards which should be followed in this place. We do not believe that it is proper for a senator to lend himself to this illicit taping of a private meeting in the way that Senator Schacht has done. He has come into this place and made certain denials, which seem to be carefully worded. For example, he said that he personally was not involved in the recording or taping of the meeting in question. His words were:
. . . I again emphasise that I was not involved in the recording or taping of the meeting in question.

He is twice on the record as saying that. He has not told us-perhaps he will tell us in this debate today-whether his staff or people in any sense acting in common purpose with him were involved in the taping. We might hope for some enlightenment from Senator Schacht as to whether he is taking a lawyer's tight definition of his words or whether he is saying that he was in no way involved in this. Perhaps he will enlighten the Senate. We do not believe that that goes to the basic issue about which we are concerned.

It is quite clear that the Labor Party was aware of what happened. I think Mr Scholes's rather more concerned and honourable behaviour indicates that. I have reason to believe that the Minister at the table, Senator Robert Ray, who will be responding, had some earlier knowledge of the availability of this material. The Opposition believes that this censure should be carried because it should be made absolutely clear to all senators and members that having truck with this sort of behaviour is something that we should not have to put up with in this building. The perils from those who would destroy this institution are real enough without having it destroyed from within. The fact is that Senator Schacht, in his use of this material, has fallen below the required standards.

Let me also say that Senator Schacht was faced with the proposition that this morning we would have debated in this place a motion, of which I gave notice yesterday, that we should have laid on the table of the Senate before 2 o'clock today any document quoted from or used by Senator Schacht during the adjournment debate in the Senate on 29 May 1989; and a statement by Senator Schacht setting out how he obtained any document from which he quoted. He has, of course, refused to acknowledge the latter part of that. He has come up with the old plea that he must protect his sources.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the material Senator Tambling came up with?

—The fact is that Senator Schacht-in an action which makes him, as one of my colleagues pointed out, the Ollie North of the Senate-put the document into the Minister's shredder. That is what we are told he did. Again, it reduces the standards of this place to the standards that we have looked at elsewhere and have been rather critical of. I heard an interjection from Senator Collins; he is another man who should have been a defence lawyer. He almost rivals Senator Barney Cooney in his capacity to take a dock brief in a hopeless case. Senator Collins's interjection was, `What about material put in by Senator Tambling?'. There has been no shortage of documents which have fallen off the back of trucks being used in this place and in the House of Representatives by both sides of Parliament-no shortage at all. I am glad that Senator Collins interjected, because it enables me to draw what I think is the appropriate distinction. In those cases we are talking about material which comes into the hands of senators and members through the acts of third parties and which is used in the course of political debate in this place-and there have been some very famous examples of that. The Age tapes are a classic case. The difference is that, quite clearly, in this case members of the Labor Party have conspired to breach the confidentiality of private meetings, to tape record them, to produce a transcript and to use it in this place. That is behaviour which I believe everybody in Australia would accept as distinct and different from a circumstance in which people who are not part of this Parliament choose to make material available, whether it is to one side of the Parliament or the other.

SPEECH.PARA: A most recent example is when members of the Labor Party made material available to Senator Bronwyn Bishop relating to the behaviour of Senator Richardson with respect to the dismissal of a public servant in Washington. They are matters which are not unusual in this place.There is a total difference between the situation where a senator, like Senator Schacht, is involved in subversion in a direct way of the private discussions of his colleagues, including colleagues from his own side of the Senate. That is what Senator Schacht's crime is. That is why he is deserving of censure in this place, and that is why he has entered into a totally different line of conduct from those which are the subject of the interjection from Senator Collins.

There is no absolute protection against abuse in this building. It requires a little honesty on the part of honourable senators. We have certainly not seen that from Senator Schacht. The view of the Opposition is that he should be censured.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I draw the attention of honourable senators to the remarks I made in the Senate last night. I denied completely the accusation that I had been involved in illegal taping. I still deny it completely. I had given to me, from sources, very detailed information of the meeting which I thought was relevant.
—A transcript. Don't prevaricate.

—I heard Senator Chaney in silence; I would appreciate it if he would extend to me the same courtesy. As I said, I made remarks in the Senate about what I thought was relevant information. It was certainly not the first time in this chamber, or in the other chamber, since Federation, that information has been given in debate when people have had access to details of what has gone on in a private meeting. I would be extraordinarily surprised if an Opposition member, some time tomorrow or the day after, got very fulsome details of an internal meeting of the Australian Labor Party, of, say, a Caucus meeting, and did not give full details of it in this chamber to get some advantage if he thought it would embarrass the Labor Party. I would be surprised if he did not. As I said in my statement last night, I accept that that is what politics is about.

SPEECH.PARA: In my 22 months in this chamber I have been continually surprised at the level of sanctimoniousness to which members of the Opposition will go in order to proclaim their defence of this institution of parliamentary democracy, particularly Senator Chaney. He has taken sanctimoniousness to a new level and made it a new art form. For somebody who only three weeks ago was saying one thing to John Howard to his face while planting a number of knives in his back and planning to knock him off as leader, I find his sanctimoniousness here today about propriety, honesty and so on quite remarkable. One of the things that I have noticed is the composition of this censure motion compared with that of the notice of motion that Senator Chaney gave yesterday. I do not know why Senator Chaney has not proceeded with the notice of motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because you destroyed the evidence. You shredded it. Come on, Ollie!

—I would have thought that on my admission that I had destroyed my material Senator Chaney would have jumped up today and moved his motion which included the famous phrase that a senator not be permitted to speak. I do not know in the record of the Senate whether anybody else has ever had such a motion put on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to Senator Chaney that although he is not proceeding with it now, that notice of motion he moved yesterday will haunt him and be used against him for the rest of his political life. He is against free speech; he wants to gag the right of people to say what they like in this chamber. Whether he finds it distasteful or not, the impression is that he is out to gag people. He intended to make sure that I did not say what I believed to be correct. I do not ask him to accept my argument or my views, but to bring into this Senate a motion that I cannot ever be heard again unless I meet his demands is extraordinary. I hope that in the years to come he will not object when we remind him that he is against free speech.

I want to remind honourable senators opposite-there are not too many left-that their party philosophically goes back to the days of Alfred Deakin, one of the small `l' liberals and one of the people who started the non-Labor side of politics in this country. I do not know where Alfred Deakin is buried, but he would turn over in his grave if he found that a leader of the Opposition in the Senate had put on the Notice Paper a motion saying that a senator cannot speak in this chamber. The people who make the choice as to whether I speak are the electors of South Australia. If they choose not to elect me to the Senate I accept that judgment. When they put me here they gave me the right to speak in accordance with the rules and regulations of the Senate.

This is not the first time I have run into politicians who have attempted to gag me. In 1983 I visited Tahiti where I spoke publicly against French nuclear testing. I described Tahiti as `French occupied Polynesia'. The French secret police said it would be a very good idea if I left the country because they did not want to hear what I had to say. I was escorted onto a plane by armed gendarmes. Has anybody from the Opposition had the guts to go to a place such as Tahiti to speak out against French nuclear testing and take on the French secret police? The answer is no. I wish to give another example. Today in this building I am hosting a visit by a man called Issayas Aferwerki, the Secretary-General of the Eritrean Peoples' Liberation Front. For 26 years he and his people have been fighting for democracy and for the right to have free speech in their country. It is interesting that, on the day they are present, the business sheet contains a motion to be moved by Senator Chaney that a senator cannot speak. Fancy saying to him, `This is the model that you should have in your country when you get your independence, that a motion can be moved so that you cannot be heard in your chamber'.

The last example I can remember of this occurring in the Westminster system occurred in the eighteenth century, when John Wilkes, in the Westminster Parliament, passed a few remarks against the king of England. The king's supporters in the Parliament had him gagged. The people were forced into a special by-election and Wilkes was returned to the Parliament, and again gagged. In the end he won the right for people to stand in the Parliament and speak their piece even if the other members do not like one word that they utter.

What Senator Chaney is about is gagging those who have views with which he does not agree, those whom he finds distasteful. He may say that what I said was distasteful and he has every right to say it. I will not move a motion to gag him because of what he says. He should read and understand a few episodes in the history of the evolution of the Westminster system. Overnight, Senator Chaney realised that he had pulled a bit of a boner with this motion to try to gag a senator; so he backed off. The sanctimonious senator from Western Australia squibbed it, as most Liberals will squib the pressure.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If he has not squibbed it, why did he not continue with the motion? I said last night that I would not table the document and that I would not reveal my sources, and the senator has chucked this motion into the bin and moved a censure motion in the thought that there would be a better chance of its being carried by the Senate. He knew that nobody but the robots behind him among the Liberals and the Nationals would vote for gagging a senator, and so it should be. Senator Chaney went on at great length about the taping. I have sat in this Senate for 22 months. I have heard Senator Bronwyn Bishop produce material, a so-called tape, about the Castlereagh by-election.
—And I tabled it.
—Yes, and every point of it--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! When an honourable senator is speaking to a censure motion that has been moved against him, he is entitled to be heard in silence.

—Senator Bishop produced a tape. She did not say how she got it. I have said quite clearly that I was not involved in any taping. Senator Bishop has used a tape and she tabled it. I did not rise and move that she be gagged and never be heard again. I did not say it was unusual for her to have the right to use that political stunt. Others will judge. The Electoral Commission has judged Senator Bronwyn Bishop, who has been described by Peter Ward in the magazine section of the Australian as the Eva Peron of the Liberal Party in New South Wales. That is probably an apt description. The only question that it raised in my mind when I read the description, to which I imagine Senator Bishop has no objection because it was a most fulsome article about her ability, was who is the Juan Peron in the Liberal Party who supported her in New South Wales?

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard talk in the Senate about the sanctimoniousness of the Liberal Party. As Senator Collins alluded to last night, Senator Tambling has produced bucketloads, truckloads, of material which he says had fallen off the back of a truck. We know that that is a euphemism for getting a direct leak from people in a government department who are upset with government policy. They have not gone to the Minister and said, `We want to send all of this stuff to Senator Tambling so that he can table it'. Of course not. We did not jump up and squeal and say that he should no longer be heard because he will not name the public servants.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the same as ratting on your own colleagues.

—Rats? The biggest rat sitting there at the moment is the leader of the senator's party in this place who ratted on John Howard. He should ask Senator Michael Baume what he thinks about rats. I have here what Senator Michael Baume says about the Liberal Party. He is the best script- writer we have ever had. People still ask us for the posters. If Senator Chapman wants to talk about rats, he should speak to Senator Chaney and ask Senator Michael Baume, who sits beside him in the chamber, what he thinks about rats in the Liberal Party.
—Order! There are far too many interjections and I suggest to Senator Schacht that he should not answer them.

—Mr President, when I get a free kick for goal like that from Senator Chapman, I cannot but take it. I return to the motion. I accept the right of my peers in the Senate to judge the contents of my speech and say whether they think it was in good taste or bad taste. The question of taste is always in the eye of the beholder. I think that many things said by honourable senators opposite are in extremely poor taste.
—Pretty poor taste.

—I accept Senator Calvert's opinion that what I said was in poor taste. He should also accept that even though he thinks it was in poor taste, I had the right to use this institution to say it. There are very few places in Australia in which people have the right to say what they think. The parliamentary institution is one of them-the Federal Parliament and the State and Territory parliaments. Senator Chaney went on with the usual humbug when he talked about how I abused this institution. He wants to try to make a political point, to embarrass me and accuse me of some sort of activity. That is his right; he can keep doing that. His censure motion may be carried by the Senate; that is fine. But I say to Senator Chaney that if he were really fair dinkum he would have moved the other motion of which he gave notice and tried to debate the issue that a senator may be gagged because another senator does not like what that senator says. He tipped his hand on that issue. He made a real boner yesterday. I do not know whether the electors of Pearce will elect him to the lower House, but I would like to see him try to use that sort of tactic in the House of Representatives-if he is successful in gaining a seat in that House-whereby, if he does not like what someone says, he tries to move to gag him. He will be treated with contempt by his peers for misusing the Standing Orders because when he cannot take the heat he squeals.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been accused of making remarks in poor taste. The one person I do apologise to-I now say it to him because he is in the chamber; I said it last night-is Senator Harradine because on Monday night I did not inform him that I was going to speak on this matter. Quite rightly, he is upset about that. I apologise to him for that. I must say that there have been a few occasions in the past when I have been attacked in this chamber by honourable senators opposite. They never inform me beforehand that they intend to do so. I do not expect them to; that is fair cop in this game. I remember honourable senators opposite raising in Estimates committee hearings the cost of the establishment of my electorate office. They made a lot of play about it in the media in Adelaide. I did not complain; I did not whinge about it; I did not stand here and say, `That is terrible, why didn't you tell me about it beforehand?'. Opposition senators thought they could make a political point. I am willing to cop that. In this game one must cop a few kicks now and again. If one cannot take the heat, that is fine.

Senator Chaney had a couple of swipes about whether I had legal advice. I say to Senator Chaney that if he represents the average ability of members of the legal profession in Australia-I understand that he was a lawyer-it shows why I supported very strongly the reference to a Senate committee of the matter of the high cost of law in Australia. If Senator Chaney represents the level of competence of Australian lawyers, it is no wonder that many Australian citizens are getting fed up with the poor deal they are getting from our legal system.

Senator Chaney raised the matter of whether I have done an honest day's work in my life, and so on. It is true that for over 20 years I was employed in one form or another by the Australian Labor Party. Some people may say that that is not a very arduous position. That is a matter of judgment. All I can say to Senator Chaney is that since 1969, as an official of the Labor Party in South Australia, I participated in about 27 election campaigns. I take great delight in telling Senator Chaney that on most of those occasions we kicked his mob out of office. The coalition in South Australia has won two elections since 1969, one of which it won by cheating; it got 43 per cent of the vote and, because of the gerrymander, it stayed in office. It lost all the others, other than in 1979. It is for Senator Chaney to judge whether he calls that hard work. I enjoyed doing it to his Party. I am sure that I will continue to play my role and keep doing it to his Party in South Australia. Before I became involved full time in politics, I trained as a school teacher. Unlike some Opposition senators, I did not have a golden spoon in my mouth. I had to do it off my own bat.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are the golden spooners here?

—I can see a few; goodness me! Again, I accept Senator Chaney's right to say that what I have been doing for 20 years in the Labor Party is not hard or relevant work; that is fine. All I can say is that I experienced great joy in being involved in campaigns to knock over the people opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: If I am censured by the Senate, so be it. I will treat it as a political stunt on Senator Chaney's part. All I know is that Senator Chaney was not game to move his original motion. Had it been carried, we would have had to move such motions every day. For example, unless Senator Tambling indicated who his sources were, we would not let him speak. The next day, it would be someone else. Once Senator Chaney started down that road, people would say: Who is next? He made a boner in regard to that proposed motion. He could not go through with it. He had been told by his Party that it was a stupid motion, so he moved a general censure motion against me. That is a good, reliable tactic. He has had time to put his case. Although he may say that what I did on Monday night was in poor taste, I say it was in accordance with what is the cut and thrust of politics in this place. If he cannot take the heat, he is in for a terrible belting if he is successful in moving to the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Macklin I point out to the Senate that I would not normally leave the chair during a censure motion, but I have ceremonial duties involving the Governor-General at 11 a.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney has moved:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures Senator Schacht for his conduct in making use in the Senate adjournment debate on Monday May 29 of an illicitly-obtained transcript of a private meeting of Senators and Members and his subsequent destruction of the material.

This is clearly not a matter which falls under the Standing Orders. When it was raised with the President he made a statement on the matter-I think that statement would probably be accepted by most honourable senator-that it clearly falls outside the parameters of the Standing Orders. However, it does fall within an area which must be of great concern to every senator who has to work in this building. The matter we are discussing has been fairly clearly set out, first in the speech by Senator Schacht during the adjournment debate on 29 May, and again in the speech he made during the adjournment debate last night. I accept the statement by Senator Schacht last night that he was not involved in the recording or taping of the meeting in question. The fact that a senator comes into this place after there has been some controversy with regard to these matters and makes a clear statement as to where he stands, in the absence of any other evidence, should be taken as being the truth. I take it as being the truth that Senator Schacht was not involved in the recording or taping of the meeting in question.

If one looks at Senator Schacht's speech of 29 May, one must accept that the meeting to which he referred was recorded. His references to the meeting involved a very clear setting out of the discussions that took place during the meeting. I know that people who were present at the meeting, in speaking to the press and elsewhere, have quibbled with some of the points raised by Senator Schacht as being inaccurate. By and large, each of those people has added that he thinks the meeting was recorded because Senator Schacht referred to the basic flow of the discussion and to many of the finer details.

I think that honourable senators would be aware-and it has probably happened to quite a number of people in this place-that from time to time the sound system in this building has been on in committee meetings and other meetings that take place in the committee rooms. I understand that a number of journalists have taken to twiddling the dial on our little radio sets to see whether any particular committee meeting happens to be being broadcast inadvertently. I do not know-no-one has suggested it and, therefore, it must be left in the realm of speculation-whether anybody deliberately set out to tape this particular meeting. A more reasonable conjecture would be that one of the twiddlers of the dials picked it up. There is no way of knowing whether it was a journalist, a member of parliament or a staffer. However, it seems that somebody with skills in being able to take it down in either shorthand or some other method picked it up.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be reasonable for honourable senators to listen to what I have to say on the matter before they make judgments. It seems that some people who have skills in taking down such matters were involved. That would probably point to a shorthand typist, a journalist with shorthand skills, or somebody in, for example, the Hansard Department, whose staff have exceptional skills in such matters. However, no matter who it was-at the moment there seems to be no evidence to suggest who it was and nobody has attempted to raise the matter of who it was-the transcript was provided to Senator Schacht. Senator Schacht then made use of the transcript in this place with regard to attacking the Pro-Life Group on a matter about which, people are happy to admit, he feels reasonably strongly.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable senators have said, the whole exercise is whether Senator Schacht should be censured for engaging in the activity, that is-all that we know at the moment-using an illicitly obtained transcript, as Senator Chaney's motion calls it, in the chamber. The second part of Senator Chaney's motion contains the words `and his subsequent destruction of the material'. Last night Senator Schacht said:

After the adjournment I had a meeting with the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Robert Ray, about the status of the material from which it was claimed I had quoted. In particular, my primary concern was that if the material was circulated, it would jeopardise the confidentiality of my sources and it was on this basis that I sought Senator Ray's advice as to what I should do with the material. Senator Ray advised that as the Senate had rejected the resolution that the material be tabled, I was free to do what I liked with it; therefore, to ensure the protection of my sources, the material was destroyed late last night . . .

I think that Senator Ray's advice was probably what might be termed good political advice. It was certainly accurate advice-that is, that Senator Schacht was free to do precisely what he liked with the material. Senator Schacht chose to destroy the material. I do not believe that on that basis Senator Schacht would be able to be censured.

I believe that there are grounds for censure as to the first part and I will explain it more fully. I intend to move an amendment to Senator Chaney's motion to test whether the Senate is serious about this issue, that is, to add after the word `members', leaving out `and his subsequent destruction of the material', the words:

and Senator Tambling for his conduct in making use in the Senate of illicitly-obtained material from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and any other senator who has used material illicitly-obtained from an individual or a group or from a department of state, and urges serious consideration of the establishment of an ethics committee.

The reason for the amendment-if it successfully attaches to Senator Chaney's motion honourable senators will vote for the censure of Senator Schacht, Senator Tambling and other senators who have used illicit material-is that I believe there is an area that falls outside the Standing Orders and within the area, as Senator Chaney said, quite rightly, of ethics. The material about which we are talking has been obtained illicitly. I do not happen to believe that what Senator Schacht did was in poor taste; I happen to believe that it was unethical. I do not believe that what Senator Tambling did was political; I happen to believe that it was unethical. I happen to believe that any other senator who uses that type of material is engaging in unethical conduct.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you ever used any yourself?

—No, Senator. It is interesting that Senator Tambling, by way of interjection, which may or may not have been picked up-I am sure that he will disagree if I have his interjection wrong-said that he had tabled all the documents. Quite frankly, that makes not a hap'orth of difference to the context of whether the material was obtained illicitly. The question is what is done with it subsequently. The documents were still obtained illicitly. They were still stolen documents. They were stolen from a department of state by some person within that department of state. I am not saying that Senator Tambling either sought or encouraged anybody, in any way, to provide him with that material. I have no evidence of that and I certainly would not want to make that allegation. He was, as it were, the innocent recipient of a lot of stolen material. But he chose to use it. Likewise, I do not know, and there is no evidence of it, whether Senator Schacht sought or encouraged anybody to provide him with that material. Senator Chaney did not make that accusation and Senator Schacht did not respond to any such accusations. I have no way of knowing that and I do not believe that any other senator has a way of knowing that. We must take it that both Senator Tambling and Senator Schacht were the innocent recipients of material. The fact that they both chose to use it I regard as unethical.

SPEECH.PARA: The difficulty with the context-it has already been said by Senator Schacht in his own defence-is that we do not have ethical standards by which to operate in this chamber. In a sense the motion before us is retrospective. It refers to something that has gone on to date. In other words, it suggests that there should be ethical standards. I concur totally with that. I happen to believe that the censure motion should be carried with my attachment. I hope that honourable senators, having considered the position-and certainly Opposition senators, knowing how distasteful they find this context-will also be able to feel how distasteful many Government members felt when Senator Tambling used stolen material in this place. All those on the receiving end of the use of stolen material get very upset. They are outraged and feel that something should be done. However, it is amazing how that outrage tends to dissipate once somebody who supports our own political position manages to find some damaging material about our political opponents.

A more productive stance regarding the issue with which we are confronted today would be to seek among all parties serious consideration of the motion of establishing an ethics committee with a view to drawing up a code of conduct for members of parliament. It may or may not be that the issue before us ends up before such a committee. Indeed, when one considers the ramifications of not permitting the use of stolen material in this chamber, one would be making a heavy inroad into many of the things that go on. For example, I can remember when in 1982 Senator Chaney, who moved the motion before us, was a Minister and was having a tussle with then Senator Grimes over material that Senator Grimes had received from a department. Senator Chaney made quite a number of comments about the use of stolen material. In other words, he, as the responsible Minister, was outraged, quite rightly, that somebody within his Department had stolen material that did not belong to him and leaked it to his political opponent. It happens constantly.

We are talking about how this material is obtained, not how it is finally used. I believe that its final use by Senator Schacht was unethical, as I believe its use by other honourable senators would be. I will be supporting the censure motion and move as an amendment to the motion:

After `Members', insert ``and Senator Tambling for his conduct in making use in the Senate of illicitly-obtained material from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and any other senator who has used material illicitly-obtained from an individual or a group or from a department of state and urges serious consideration of the establishment of an ethics committee.''
If my amendment is not carried, I will still be voting for the motion because it, at least in part, raises some of the points that I, on behalf of my Party, have just made to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning the Senate is addressing a matter of the utmost gravity. On that matter Senator Chaney has moved for the censure of an honourable senator. That is not a matter upon which honourable senators embark lightly. Certainly I would not embark lightly upon it. Senator Chaney has moved:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures Senator Schacht for his conduct-
that is the keyword, `conduct'-
in making use in the Senate adjournment debate on Monday May 29 of an illicitly-obtained transcript of a private meeting of Senators and Members and his subsequent destruction of the material.

I was not in the Senate last Monday night. That is a matter of some regret because had I been, and had everything else been as it was, Senator Schacht would have been required-because of the division at that time-to table the documents from which he was quoting. Most unfortunately, I was not present.

TALK.START.PARA: —Neither was I.

—Senator Tate says that he was not present either. Indeed, many honourable senators had gone home because the adjournment debate does not normally lead to that kind of outcome. Only the extraordinary events of last Monday night produced a division.

SPEECH.PARA: Last night Senator Schacht again rose to his feet on the adjournment of this place and referred to `the issue of material I quoted from last night in an adjournment debate'. Even up to that point Senator Schacht was in the first place guilty of dissimulation on this matter. On Monday night he did not talk about the material he was quoting from. As recorded on page 2962 of the Senate Hansard Senator Schacht, when referring to a meeting of the so-called Pro-Life Group which took place in Parliament House on Tuesday evening of the previous week, said:
Sources have given me a very detailed run-down of the discussion that took place in that meeting at about 5 o'clock last Tuesday.
As shown on the following page, 2963, of the Hansard he said:
From my sources, I have some pretty detailed discussions.
At another point of the Hansard on the same page he said:
According to my sources . . .

It is as though he had had an oral report of some kind from perhaps someone who was present at that meeting. The impression with which the Senate could have been left from listening to Senator Schacht that night was that there was a leak from somebody present at that meeting or somebody who talked to somebody who was present at that meeting. The Hansard report continues:
one of the discussions that took place at this meeting concerned tactics . . .

And so he went on. Midway through his remarks on page 2963 Senator Schacht began to diverge somewhat from this presentation of depending upon sources, oral communications. He began to quote, putting the words in the Senate Hansard in quotation marks. He said:

`If we are successful in having legislation passed to remove Medicare payments, there will be a lot more unwanted children'. One member said, `We have to have an absolutely foolproof oversupply of pregnancy support services'. Another member present-it may have been Senator Harradine-said, `I cannot follow the argument. I donate to pregnancy support all the time'.

And so on. Senator Schacht, after having begun by presenting to the Senate material from sources, went on at a later part of his remarks to make it clear to observant listeners that in fact he was quoting from some kind of transcript. It is now clear that Senator Schacht was in fact quoting from a document that was either a full transcript of the proceedings of that private meeting of members and senators from all parties in this place or a very full significant extract from such a transcript. It is also clear--

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't know that. You're just making--

—I will come to Senator Crowley's interjection as to whether we know that in a moment. It is also clear that there was, indeed there may be still, a tape recording of those proceedings. What did Senator Schacht say about that in his remarks to the Senate last night? Like Senator Macklin, who said that we have not yet received yesterday's Senate Hansard, I cannot quote from the official record but I can quote from a transcript of what Senator Schacht said last night. I hope that Senator Schacht will not contradict me. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I can state unequivocally that I-
underline `I'-
did not tape the meeting of the Pro-Life Group which took place last week.
Later in his remarks he said:
In doing so, I again emphasise that I was not involved in the recording or taping of the meeting in question.

On that point, let me say that I accept Senator Schacht's assurance to the Senate that he was not involved in the taping of that meeting. Indeed, the words of Senator Chaney's censure motion do not accuse him of that. They seek to have the Senate censure Senator Schacht for his conduct in making use of the results of the taping.

Let me digress for one moment to a couple of other related incidents arising from these events, apparently, of last week. First, on Thursday of last week, 25 May, Mr Scholes, the honourable member for Corio, who after all has held high office in the House of Representatives, got up in the House of Representatives, 36 hours after this meeting had occurred-I suggest that it is no coincidence; it would have taken about that time for the proceedings of that meeting to be transcribed and for the existence of that record to have become known within some ranks of the Australian Labor Party-and said:
Mr Acting Speaker, I wish to raise with you a matter which impinges on the privileges of this Parliament.
This was quite out of the blue. He continued:

The broadcasting from committee rooms in this House is remotely controlled. The Chairman or members of a committee have no indication of or control over whether the proceedings of a committee are being broadcast. The broadcasting of the proceedings of private meetings of committees or of committees which are in camera is a breach of the privileges of this House.

There are some questions as to whether Mr Scholes is correct in stating that, although I have no reason to question his view. But that is not the issue. The point is that on Thursday morning of last week Mr Scholes got up in the House of Representatives and raised a matter of concern, this question of broadcasts out of committee rooms of this House being available to be picked up by, perhaps, those who might choose to monitor such broadcasts.

Let me refer to another piece of fallout, if I can call it that, from these events of last week. Again I cannot be certain, and I therefore make no assertion, that this is in fact a consequence of these events last week. But on Monday night Senator Schacht referred to Senator Tate's position. On page 2964 of the Senate Hansard Senator Schacht said:
Then the discussion got round to the role of Senate Michael Tate, who is a member of the Pro-Life Group.
That is a matter of public record, and was before it was put on the Senate record by Senator Schacht. He continued:

I gather that, at the meeting, there was certainly some bad spleen vented about the way Senator Tate had refused to go along with the proposal to introduce amendments to stop Medicare payments. Since then, Senator Tate has published a letter and made statements to the effect that, although he has a pro-life view, he wants women to be able to choose not to have abortions.

I am not going to enter into a debate as to the rights and wrongs of the so-called pro-life argument-or is it the pro-choice argument? What I am saying is that we are aware that Senator Tate did in fact make some public statements which seem to suggest I put it no higher than that-that the fact that those proceedings became publicly known, by way of transcript may have placed Senator Tate in an embarrassing personal situation. Senator Tate may want to say something about that at a later point. I simply raise that possibility. But it is clear-and this is the reason I raise it-that where we have a group of this kind meeting on a very sensitive subject, and in this case including members from all parties, what those people may want to say in the confines, and what they understand to be the privacy, of a committee room of this Parliament can, if it indeed comes into wider possession within the Parliament, cause any of those members or senators very great personal embarrassment. I leave that point there.

I and others have said that the motion moved by Senator Chaney focuses on two points: first of all, the need to censure Senator Schacht for his conduct in making use in the Senate adjournment debate of an illicitly obtained transcript of a private meeting of senators and members; and secondly, his subsequent destruction of the material. Let me take the second point first. Following an approach to him by the Leader of the Opposition and others and following these events on Monday night, the President yesterday informed the Senate of the preliminary action he had taken arising out of that incident, including discussions he had already had with Madam Speaker in the other place, and of his intention to undertake further action to deal with the possibility-I would say what is now clearly the certainty-that a broadcast was made out of one of the committee rooms which should not have been made and was illicitly recorded and transcribed. Senator Schacht has said as to that point:
. . . I will be more than willing to offer any assistance-
that is to the President-
regarding this matter.

Those were Senator Schacht's words. Yet last night he told the Senate that he had destroyed his copy of the transcript or extracts from the transcript, which is after all the subject of the President's investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the next sentence.

—That seems to be a rather strange way of going about assisting the President to pursue this matter. Senator Schacht is indicating, by way of interjection, that he believes he has some justification or some rationalisation for that position, and I will deal with that aspect in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me now come to the more important charge, the charge relating to Senator Schacht's conduct in making use in the Senate adjournment debate last Monday night of an illicitly obtained transcript of a private meeting. Senator Schacht has sought to justify this-and indeed Senator Macklin gave us a long discourse on the same subject-by referring to the fact that in both this place and the other place senators and members from time to time make use of what are, I think, colloquially referred to as `leaks'. They may be leaks from the bureaucracy, they may be leaks from the Cabinet room, they may be leaks from the Caucus or they may be leaks from the coalition party room, but leaks are used. I have never found that a very attractive manner of proceeding. Nevertheless--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is very subjective.
—What about the National Press Club?

—If I were the honourable senator, I would be careful of saying things like that, because he does not want any more egg on his face about his personal conduct in this place. In particular, Senator Schacht referred-and again Senator Macklin has referred to it this morning and indeed has made it the subject of an amendment to the censure motion-to a number of interventions in this place by my National Party colleague Senator Tambling in the area of Aboriginal affairs. Senator Tambling has been favoured with a great many documents-leaks-from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Aboriginal Development Commission and many other quarters in a portfolio area which has become a shambles and a disgrace, not only to this Government but also to the conduct of the administration of this country. In those circumstances, Senator Tambling has been the recipient of many leaks from public servants who have clearly been pushed beyond their bounds-and I do not justify their behaviour-by a Minister and a group of activists around that Minister who have used those public servants shamefully. I do not want to pursue that point further, other than to say that last night Senator McMullan and Senator Collins also spoke in the adjournment debate attacking Senator Tambling on the same point. It was clearly a good, professional, concerted attempt by Australian Labor Party senators to divert attention from the disgraceful conduct of their colleague Senator Schacht.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw a very clear distinction-this seems to be a distinction that Senator Macklin is incapable of drawing, judging by his amendment-between this episode and the use of the documents or other forms of report leaked out of the bureaucracy, the Caucus or the Cabinet by certain people. Those are what I largely regard as unfortunate facts of life in the political system and the way it operates. But the fact is that leaks occur and they are used, as is rightly said, by most members and senators in this place. The question is whether such leaks are comparable to the use, by Senator Schacht, of a clandestinely recorded transcript of a private meeting of members and senators in a committee room of Parliament House. I suggest that the answer is that there is no comparison between the two things.

People can argue in both directions about the question of leaks. There are those who argue that beyond a certain point it is in the public interest that documents should be leaked. I myself do not accept that argument. However, there are arguments to that effect, and there are arguments to the contrary. I put it to honourable senators, including honourable senators opposite, that it cannot be argued that it is appropriate to have committee rooms in this building bugged-whether bugging as it is normally understood, or bugging by making use of the high-tech electronic equipment in those rooms- clandestinely to record proceedings. I cannot imagine anybody in this place arguing that that is desirable, though I will listen with interest to see whether I am wrong.

If such material is obtained, as obviously happened in this case, it is then a matter for members or senators-in this case, senators-to make up their minds whether to use it. It is like knocking on the door of a member's or senator's room and walking in, not knowing that he is not there. On the desk is, let us say, a Cabinet document. Is it suggested that the person walking into the room should pick up the document, merely because it is there, and walk out? In the case which is the subject of the motion, is it suggested that because the transcript was there Senator Schacht was right to make use of it? Unless we can have a bare modicum of honour in the conduct between ourselves in this place, there will be no bottom to the pit into which we will descend.

Honourable senators opposite will recall that a little while ago one of their very distinguished colleagues in the other place-Lionel Bowen-achieved a very considerable milestone in his parliamentary life and, I suggest, in the parliamentary history of the Labor Party. I wrote a personal note to Lionel Bowen-I do not propose to divulge its contents-congratulating him on having pursued an honourable course in this Parliament for so long-something that I thought was more honourable than having been a Minister, or anything like that. Mr Bowen is an old-style Labor man. Does any honourable senator opposite think that John Curtin would have made use of a transcript of that kind in the way that Senator Schacht did on Monday night? Does anyone think that Ben Chifley, in his time, would have got up in the House of Representatives and made use of such a transcript obtained in that way? Or Arthur Calwell? I do not believe that even Mr Gough Whitlam would have made use of such a document in that way-and I do not put him in quite the same category as the other three gentlemen to whom I have referred.

The fact of the matter is that those who touch pitch will be defiled. On Monday night Senator Schacht touched pitch, and he has been defiled. He has lowered the repute and standing of the Parliament. In doing so, he has brought a reflection on all of us. That is one reason-not the most important reason, but one reason-why I personally feel so strongly about this action. Senator Schacht is deserving of the censure of this place. Indeed, whatever the outcome of the votes, Senator Schacht will stand censured not merely in the eyes of people on this side but, I believe, in the eyes of many on his own side, even though, of course, they will march into the lobby to support him, as will the Democrats, who today have once again proved themselves to be the most faithful supporters of the Labor Party in this place, with their diversionary amendment, which will allow them to vote against the motion. That is the only reason for the amendment. The fact is that Senator Schacht already stands censured in the eyes of all parliamentarians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already said we will vote for the motion. Why don't you listen?
—Senator Macklin tells us that if his amendment is defeated he will vote for the motion. I am glad to hear it.
—You should have listened earlier.

—Perhaps we could have less intemperate interjections from the honourable senator. Whatever the outcome of the divisions, Senator Schacht already stands censured in the eyes of the Parliament. The fact that he is sitting there giggling, laughing and carrying on shows that he is incapable of understanding what standards are expected-and demanded-of people in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion is about hypocrisy and double standards. The Opposition-I do not extend these remarks to the Democrats or to Senator Harradine-adopts one type of behaviour in a certain set of circumstances but does not apply it in others. That is the essence of this motion. We all make mistakes. Perhaps in this matter I have made mistakes and Senator Schacht has made mistakes. But what is the biggest mistake I have made in the last few weeks? A few days ago journalists asked me how I thought Senator Chaney had come out of the Liberal leadership kerfuffle. I said that he had been through a very traumatic time but I thought that, after the leadership struggle, he was a far better person than he had been before, the one element missing in his performance in this chamber and elsewhere being his well-known and oft-criticised sanctimoniousness. But welcome back, Fred. It was all there today-all the old form, all the old sanctimoniousness.

SPEECH.PARA: We are talking about standards of behaviour. We always get the blowtorch put to us over our behaviour. Senator Chaney got off very lightly in the last few weeks if we are talking about consistent, decent, or even ethical, behaviour. I do not want to go into that in detail, but I have to say that I do not know how he could be loyal to Andrew Peacock up to 1985 and then desert the ship and support Howard. I do not know how he could go on public record as often as five times this year saying that he was loyal to John Howard and criticising others for opening the leadership matter, and then do what he did. Having been approached when the numbers were sewn up, he had a critical choice, an ethical choice, to make: whether to continue to support his leader, or at least provide him with the twenty-eighth vote. He did not do so.

These are matters of ethics-as much as anything Senator Schacht has been involved in. Yet, while Senator Schacht is brought to account for his behaviour, Senator Chaney is not. But that does not worry me. I thought that Senator Chaney's trauma-and I acknowledge that it would have been a terrible time for any leader-had washed away all that sanctimoniousness, and that all his mirroring of our morals would be gone. But today we have had it all again.

The worst aspect of this motion is that it devalues censure motions, which are supposed to be specific tools to be used sparingly in the most important circumstances. I do not regard this as justifying those circumstances. I did not regard the matter raised last week against the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, and the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, as justifying a censure motion. But if this is the case, then every censure motion will go through and everyone will say, `Ho hum, another censure motion in the Senate. Someone had the numbers, someone didn't have the numbers. Ho hum'. It totally devalues the censure motion.

The guts of the motion refers to the use of illicitly obtained material. How many examples have we had, sitting here in this chamber and the old chamber, of listening to the other side going on hour after hour using illicitly obtained material? How often did my colleague the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, have to sit through the Estimates Committee listening to thousands of questions based on illicitly obtained material? How often did we sit in this chamber and listen to taped phone conversation transcripts on the question of Justice Murphy? How many times have we had to put up with things like that? I will tell the Senate what the distinction is this time, and I will refer to it only once. It is because it affects us. The most pathetic thing about parliamentarians is their incestuous desire to protect their own rights and entitlements. One can go to the Estimates Committee and see $10m go through, but the moment the issue comes up of whether a car driver should open the door for female parliamentarians, whether they should get flowers delivered to their rooms, what their postage rates are, or anything to do with the rights of a parliamentarian, it is elevated above anything else.

That is what this is about. It is not about the use of illicit material, which happens here all the time. What makes it so special, why we take such an interest in it and why we had all the galahs here earlier on interjecting on the speech made by Senator Schacht is that it affects parliamentarians. That is what this motion is about. It is pathetic. It is an elitist concept that we are above everything else and that to use any illicit material that affects us and our involvement is an absolute crime but that to use truckloads of information from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs is not a crime and is not to be condemned. There is nothing wrong with using documents from the Department of Defence, as have been produced here by Senator Newman, even though they are illicitly obtained, even though they have dropped off the back of trucks, and even though, to get them, some public servant has breached his oath of office. That is okay, but the moment one deals with parliamentary rights it is suddenly elevated way up there. All that indicates is how pathetically elitist we are at times. I have watched it at the Estimates Committee and in privileges debates. I have watched politicians being able to dish it out and not cop it time and time again.

There is no evidence produced so far in this case that there are tapes; but should someone ever use the product of an illicit tape that clearly was not in accordance with the wishes of the meeting? We have had an example. Apparently it is excused by Senator Bishop because she tabled the tape. So what? Where did she obtain the tape?

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a tape of a public meeting, not a private meeting.
—Where did she obtain the tape?
—Not the point.

—Where did she obtain the tape? Thrice denied, but not once has she said where she got the tapes from. Not once has she said what her source is. Not once has she apologised for the fact that the whole series of allegations has been rejected by the New South Wales Greiner-led inquiry into them. Not once has she apologised for the distress she caused everyone by using that tape in an opportunistic way. But I do not object to all that. What I object to is that she ran around before her preselection boasting about the use of the tape and the effect that it may have had on the New South Wales election. That is what she did. She was happy to do that then; yet she will come in here full of cant and hypocrisy and vote for a censure of Senator Schacht when her own level of behaviour is not only equal to but far, far worse than his behaviour would ever be in this chamber. That is the cant and hypocrisy of this particular motion.

SPEECH.PARA: I take up something that I really did take offence at in what Senator Chaney said. He described Senator Schacht in the following terms: `He has never done an honest day's work in his life'. Not everyone came up the easy way, and I know that Senator Schacht did not. His father was a fitter and turner and then a failed farmer. He did not have a father who was a member of parliament to give him a golden ride through. He did not have that golden ride whereby he could even have a choice of career. The only career open to him was that of a schoolteacher. Senator Chaney made the assertion that he had never done an honest day's work. I have known him for many years. I know how hard he has worked and how dedicated he is. If working in the political area, going out into the back blocks and organising branches, is not an honest day's work, I do not know what is. I would hate to think what Senator Chaney has ever done in his life as a sort of golden spooned lawyer, one of the sons, one of the dynasty of politics. It is all right, there is nothing wrong with being part of the dynasty of politics, but he should not in a snobbish way start getting into other people's behaviour and work patterns. In my view, that is totally unacceptable.

If people are wondering why we are wasting time on a censure motion today, let me tell them that yesterday we had a much worse and sillier motion. Notice was given of a motion unprecedented in this Parliament, that said that unless Senator Schacht behaved in a particular way he could no longer speak in this chamber. I have got doubts as to whether that is constitutional. I could not find any standing order that said it could be done. On the other hand, I did not find one that said it could not be done. There is a group that can stop Senator Schacht speaking in this chamber if it wants to. Any time the South Australian electorate wants to, it can make that decision. The Opposition cannot make that decision for it. I am pleased that at least the Opposition has had the grace to drop off that rather stupid motion. Its precedent in this chamber is worrying. But the precedent for use in the other chamber, where one must have an absolute majority at all time, is absolutely horrifying. The Opposition has set this example here. What happens if in a week's time there is a blow-up in the House of Representatives and a motion is moved that Mr Wilson Tuckey no longer speak in the Parliament for ever?

TALK.START.PARA: —You chuck him out quite regularly.

—He is only getting one-day suspensions. That does not indicate regularity. If one is thrown out for a week, that indicates regularity. That could be done. That is a precedent. I think that was an ill-conceived motion, probably thought up on the run, and I am glad that it has gone out.

SPEECH.PARA: I now have to have a major dispute with Senator Schacht and discipline him. He made reference to Deakin as the father of liberalism and as a prime example. Senator Schacht is obviously not a history major, because Deakin was the greatest leak in the history of this Parliament. When he was Prime Minister he was a secret correspondent for the London Post, I think it was. For years he wrote these great articles about what was decided in Cabinet, how brilliant Deakin was and what a decisive role he played. So the first great leak of the Parliament was the father of liberalism. He had no sense of privacy and breached his Executive Council oath time and time again. Senator Schacht is a minor offender. He might have defiled everyone, as Senator Stone said, but he is minor compared with Deakin, the founder of the Liberal Party.

I make two other points. Senator Stone gave us a long speech. It is probably not true that Senator Stone got down to the National Press Club every Friday night and talked to everyone. I think he was directed not to at one stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many times.

—Many times. But it did not stop him going down and pontificating. I agree that is short of leaking; `pontificating' is probably the most appropriate word. He went on to talk about the destruction of that transcript. I ask this question: did anybody after that division, for which I was present-it was 23-23-ask Senator Schacht to retain the material because he or she wanted to take further action? Had anybody done so, my advice to Senator Schacht would have been to retain that material until all avenues had been exhausted. Not one Opposition member said--
—It was destroyed already.

—Senator Watson should follow the sequence of events. He is excited about being re-endorsed and about what is happening in Tasmania, but he should try to concentrate on the series of events. We had a division. The Opposition asked for the document to be tabled. The motion was moved by Senator Watson's colleague, Senator Tambling. Not one Opposition member went up to Senator Schacht afterwards and said, `We're angry. We're upset. We want you to keep the document'. If they had, my advice certainly would have been to keep the document. But they did not, and there is no suggestion-and I am here as a witness-that Senator Schacht destroyed the material post Senator Chaney's motion. I do not think Senator Chaney even suggested that. He certainly destroyed it that night in my office.
—You were party to it.

—I cannot hear the honourable senator. But at least I have a better chance of hearing him now than I will have after the next election. It will be pretty hard to get on the front bench from where he will be. Talk about someone interjecting as a mug! I have to be very careful what I say here because I have great respect for the person in the chair. Senator McGauran was asked to step down on the ticket to make way for three sitting members, and he did. Unfortunately-and I say sincerely that I regret this-my colleague in the chair is not No. 3 on the ticket. Senator McGauran might like to send a photo of himself to my office. I have always wanted a photo of a mug in my room just to show overseas visitors.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me come back to the question. Senator Stone used an old trick. He picked it up off sanctimonious Fred. He said, `I like the old style--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask you to withdraw that remark, Minister.

—I withdraw the remark, Mr Deputy President. It is a trick Senator Stone would have picked up from Senator Fred Chaney, no doubt. He said, `I like the old style Labor men'. Some were good. I think Mr Lionel Bowen is not of the old style; he is very much a modern Labor person. The old style that Senator Stone likes is the member who would sit in opposition, the person he could kick around. He is the sort of Labor person who would split continuously and always leave the conservatives in power. That is Senator Stone's idea of old style Labor men. He criticises us for the modernity of our Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Imagine what Artie Fadden and Page would think of a carpetbagger like Senator Stone, who went up north after being hired by Bjelke-Petersen to be his economic adviser, and who dumped poor old Stan Collard off the ticket and came here. So let us not get into what the good old days were and what the morality was then. It was not 30 pieces of silver; apparently it was $250,000 a year that tempted him up north out of the lovely State of Victoria. But I know that he loves it in Queensland now, and that he has been converted along those lines. But he should not talk about the old style Labor man, about Chifley turning in his grave. What does Senator Stone think Page and Fadden are doing right now, knowing that he is the Leader of the National Party in the Senate. He was born and bred out of the Melbourne Club. He is part of the Establishment-no application at all to the old rural agrarian socialist, the old classic Country Party person who could not read or write but when rat cunning was handed out was right at the front of the queue. They are our good old National Party boys, the boys who know about boundary rigging, about taking brown paper bags and about the old ethics of the Country Party. And Senator Stone represents none of it. He would never rig an electoral boundary, he would never accept the brown paper bag. He would never put the fix in for a road contract. He is the new modern National Party carpetbagger of today-yet he has the cheek to talk about the good old days of the Labor men, the ones they could always defeat in elections.

The thing that people in this chamber resent about the Senator Schachts of the world is that they delivered government to the Labor Party. They worked hard, albeit copping the appellation of hard working apparatchiks, the machine men, or whatever else. But it is the Senator Schachts of the world who, by working hard, have delivered State Labor governments in South Australia and Federal Labor governments here. In the time Senator Schacht was State Secretary, South Australia always returned a majority of Federal Labor members to Canberra. It is a credit to him.

In conclusion, this debate has added nothing to the Parliament. It has added very little to the value of censure debates. To make censure motions valuable they should not be devalued by being moved every week. To make it stick, those opposite have to be consistent. They have to apply the same standards to everyone.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not approve of what happened.

—I am as culpable as, or more culpable than is, Senator Schacht. If this motion of censure is carried, it is not only carried against him but it is carried against me, and I accept that. But what we need is an equal application of standards. If it is wrong for Senator Schacht to use material that the Opposition alleges is illicitly obtained, it is wrong for any parliamentarian here to do so. It has been done many times. This motion is hypocrisy, this motion is cant, and it should be defeated.
