TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Robert Ray, who is the Manager of Government Business in this place, needs to ask himself a few questions, and so do we all. Do we agree that the taping and transcribing of a meeting of members and senators in Parliament House on a matter of public importance is something that should be condoned? That is the question. Does Senator Ray agree with that? There were at least two meetings on that day: one convened by Senator Ray, of what he termed the Pro-Choice Group, and one of the parliamentary Pro-Life Group. The parliamentary Pro-Life Group meeting happened to be on the videotex, as the President said in his statement. The meeting in question was publicly announced and listed on the television monitors throughout the building. It was there for all to see. Senator Ray's group was not listed. There was a meeting in his name, but it was not shown under the name of his group.

SPEECH.PARA: But let me put the boot on the other foot. Say, for example, I used in this place a transcript of a tape recording that was taken from Senator Ray's meeting. Does he think that I would not expect a censure? Does he think he would have remained silent? Of course not. It would have been front page headlines right throughout Australia. That is what Senator Ray has to think about. There were other meetings on that day. There were several Caucus committee meetings on that day. Does he think that it is fair that I or anybody else should record the conversations in those Caucus committee meetings and place them before the Senate when the members of the Labor Party are going about their business considering important matters of public importance? Of course not. That is not the honourable way to proceed. That breaks down trust. That is an attack on democracy. Does Senator Ray think that it would have been acceptable for someone to have tape-recorded another meeting that took place on that day, the meeting of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade? Of course not. Senator Ray would be the first to jump, to move a motion of censure in any of those respects.

I acknowledge and accept what Senator Schacht has said. I do not wish to vote for a censure of him personally. I propose an amendment, which is being circulated, which goes to the question of the action. I think we should focus on that question because we, in determining this issue, have to decide not whether Senator Schacht is a good bloke, but whether the action is censurable. We have to determine whether it goes to the very heart of our responsibility as members of Parliament to respect the rights of our colleagues, whether they are in the same party or not, to consult with each other in an atmosphere where we are confident that mutual trust will apply and that there are no outside people who are recording what we are saying, using the tactics of secret police.

I accept what Senator Schacht has said; he was not involved in that taping. But he did use the material. I sense from what he said last night that perhaps it was a good idea at the time. I would have hoped that he would have got that advice from Senator Ray sooner. I feel that the question does go to the heart of democracy. It can be distinguished from other areas such as those in which Senator Tambling has been involved. I confess that I have not gone into that question thoroughly and I am not privy to where Senator Tambling got his material.

Presumably there comes a time-as was suggested in the Watergate area-when persons in the Public Service consider that democracy is not being served within the particular department-in other words, that the will of the people is somehow being denied and circumscribed by actions of the bureaucracy. Personally, I believe that it would have to be a very serious matter for documents to drop off the back of a truck. But it may well be that if they do drop off the back of a track, and there is a matter of serious concern that democracy is being thwarted, either by the bureaucracy or the Government, then a member of Parliament must discharge his or her audit and control functions. That is the distinction. In this case the member of Parliament was not discharging his audit and control functions over the processes of Government. To a certain extent the action impinged upon the rights of those individual senators and members to sit down and consider a question and the ways in which their representative functions could be exercised on a matter of public importance. To the extent that this sort of action could threaten that freedom of members of parliament to go about their business in this proper way it is certainly a censurable action.

As I said at the beginning of my speech, and as the President said in his statement yesterday, the details of the meeting were shown on videotext. I do not know whether somebody saw it on the television screen and then activated the sound system. I did not know about this matter beforehand, as Senator Schacht has said. He has made his apology and I accept it. I left at 10.10 p.m. on Monday when Senator Walters was in full flight in the Estimates debate. I thought that that debate would go on for some time. The first time I heard of this matter was from the Australian Associated Press report the next morning, written by Sandra Bull and Virginia Cook, which said:
The creation of a baby pool for childless couples was suggested at a secret meeting of the parliamentary Pro-Life Group, the Senate was told last night.
I have gone through what Senator Schacht said. He did not say that the meeting was held in secret.

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly was not.

—Exactly. I have told the secretary not to take the minutes in future, just to apply for the transcript. We should look at what the motion says and what is in the amendment that has been put forward by Senator Macklin. I accept what Senator Macklin says-that is, that there should be a consideration of the ethics that should guide us. I think we all know in our minds and hearts what those ethics should be. We all accept that unless there is mutual trust and mutual respect for the freedom of individual members and senators to go about the business for which they are elected then this place will not work. So far as freedom is concerned, it is not freedom amongst thieves, as was sort of suggested by Senator Ray. We are not here to make political capital this way or that on major issues of public importance, particularly the issue which this meeting discussed. We are here to consider the matters in a proper and reasonable fashion.

SPEECH.PARA: The ironical part about all this is that one of the reasons why the parliamentary Pro-Life Group was established was to ensure that there be a proper free flow of discussion between members and senators on this particular issue to enable those senators and members to discuss these questions properly and exhaustively and to avoid any unilateral tokenism. I ask senators on the Labor side particularly to listen to what I am saying and to avoid unilateral tokenism. This is one of the major reasons why this group was established. It has written papers, one of which was about the abortion issue. But there are others in respect of technology, human life and other matters which are extremely important.

What does worry me about the whole issue is that the actual material from which Senator Schacht has quoted has been destroyed. I am sorry that I was not here on Monday night because the vote was 23 all. I am sorry about that because of the distortion and selective quoting of the transcript. It is unfair, not necessarily to the group or to me as chairman-I am not worried about that-but to the people who have been named in this document. I will not rename them but there are six people who are isolated and named here in a selective and distorted way. If the full transcript were available those names would have been placed in context, including those of colleagues on my right.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you got a full transcript?

—No, I do not. I know what happened at the meeting because I was there. To say, for example, that bad spleen was vented about the way Senator Tate had refused to go along is a disgraceful distortion. We are not a monolithic group. We allow free flow of discussions and the people who were there will know what was said about that. People have their say in those meetings, as in other meetings, and other people have a sort of balancing say. None of that was mentioned by Senator Schacht and that is one of the reasons I am sorry that this document has been destroyed, because damage has been done to some of the people who were mentioned. I do not think that that is fair at all. Frankly, I am in an awkward position to censure Senator Schacht for destroying what was an illicitly obtained document. The more illicitly obtained documents that are destroyed, the better.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand and congratulate Senator Chaney for moving this motion because it is a matter of serious importance to the working of this whole Parliament. It is a matter that goes to the trust and mutual respect that we ought to have for each other. It is action that is censurable. In line with what I said originally, I foreshadow the following amendment:
Leave all words out after the word ``censure'' and insert:

``the action of Senator Schacht in making use in the Senate adjournment debate on Monday, 29 May, of an illicitly-obtained transcript of a private meeting of Senators and Members held in Parliament House on Wednesday, 24 May 1989''.

That foreshadowed amendment focuses on the action. Senator Robert Ray is not here to respond to what I have said but he should agree that such action is censurable. I accept what Senator Schacht said last night. I feel that the action should be censured and, I suppose by implication, the person should be censured. I have the feeling that we should censure the action and make it perfectly clear that we are talking about a meeting of members of parliament, within the precincts of parliament, in a committee room booked officially and notified on the screens throughout the building, and that we will not accept those meetings being recorded through the sound system, as was quite clearly the case on this occasion, and later used in parliament to undermine the representative rights and functions of members of parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had a long debate this morning on the motion of censure that I moved on behalf of the Opposition:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures Senator Schacht for his conduct in making use in the Senate adjournment debate on Monday May 29 of an illicitly-obtained transcript of a private meeting of Senators and Members and his subsequent destruction of the material.

It would be fair to say that most of the debate from the Australian Labor Party side has involved an attempt to debate issues other than those before us. Senator Schacht set the precedent, which was followed by Senator Robert Ray, of ranging over a whole lot of matters including a motion that was never moved, my qualities and all the rest. All of that is very interesting and no doubt edified Labor senators, but it had nothing to do with the issues raised in the motion.

The simple facts of this matter are-and I assume that no-one would defend what happened with respect to that meeting; not even Senator Schacht or Senator Robert Ray has seen fit to defend it-that the meeting was overheard, perhaps using the sound recording system-who knows?-and no explanation has been forthcoming. Senator Schacht is persisting in a cover-up, which makes the ultimate determination on how this occurred very difficult indeed. As I understand it, no-one is defending the proposition that a group of senators and members, meeting in private in this building, should be subjected to having their conversations illegally or illicitly taped, without their consent, transcribed and made available to others.

I do not think that there has been any serious defence of the proposition that Senator Schacht should be entitled to collude with that sort of activity and use that material in debate. I think it represents, and clearly represents, a threat to the doing of any sensible business in this Parliament. As I said in opening the debate, this building is designed for the use of most modern electronics. Senators and members on both sides of the Parliament have made it clear that they demand from the Presiding Officers the highest possible standards to avoid the interception of their conversations and the illicit interception of their communications. That is clear common ground in this Parliament. Today we are talking about a blatant abuse of this place in which Senator Schacht is implicated up to his neck.

Senator Schacht was invited, in my opening speech, to give some explanation. He made no attempt to do that. There is no innocent explanation. Senator Schacht knows exactly how this transcript came into being. The fact that he has chosen not to disclose it simply indicates the implication of the Australian Labor Party, and it is ridiculous to assume anything other than that this is a Labor Party effort to subvert a group of senators and members, across party lines, who have been trying to come to grips with one of the most delicate policy issues that we have to face.

Senator Schacht tried to divert the argument-and it is interesting how effective this part of his diversion was-to suggest that it was all a matter of taste. I seem to recall that Senator Macklin addressed the question of taste, although his own conclusion in the end was that it was a censurable act. It is not a matter of taste. It has nothing to do with taste. I agree that those matters are not in the eye of the beholder, as I think was said by Senator Schacht. They are certainly in the mouth of the taster. We should not waste the time of the Senate on those matters.

Rather, the point was put quite shortly and well in example form by Senator Stone who spoke in support of the motion. Senator Stone pointed out that no-one here would defend the proposition that anyone could walk into an office which might happen to be empty and help himself to the contents of a desk. That was something that occurred in this place some years ago, and it was the subject of some rather violent parliamentary response and properly should have been.

TALK.START.PARA: —A journalist.

—I am reminded by Senator Stone that it involved a journalist. I do not think that either Senator Schacht or Senator Robert Ray would suggest that it would be defensible for Senator Schacht to walk into the office of, say, Senator Harradine, and because Senator Harradine happened not to be there and because the record, perhaps of this meeting, might be on his desk, to help himself to it. I think that that was a very good parallel and a simple, graphic example of the fact that, if this building is to operate in any satisfactory way at all, there have to be some standards.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had the ludicrous situation where Senator Schacht has, for the second time, apologised to Senator Harradine for not telling him that he intended to speak on the adjournment. Not telling Senator Harradine that he intended to speak on the adjournment has warranted two apologies; the use of an illicitly obtained transcript warrants no apology at all. I suggest that that shows an extraordinary lack of balance on the part of Senator Schacht and either a refusal to face the facts or a determination to put those facts in some sort of odd light.

It is not a matter of taste, as claimed by Senator Schacht. It is a matter of whether there are any standards at all that have to be observed here. There is no innocent explanation of what occurred. Had there been, I am sure that Senator Schacht would have given it to us. He knows that he is protecting Labor Party people who undertook this transcription, and he is deserving of censure.

I turn now to the Australian Democrats and, at risk of again irritating Senator Macklin, I say that he finds it very difficult to avoid going into agreement with any proposition put forward by the coalition in opposition. He did indicate in his speech that he thought that this was a censurable matter. He went on to suggest that the motion should be amended by censuring other activity, and he specifically named Senator Tambling, who has used material which has been leaked to him by officials of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs or the Aboriginal Development Commission, as a basis for questioning both during the Estimates committee hearings and during debate in this chamber. In my opening remarks I made it clear that I thought there was a distinction. There is a distinction. It is quite different from a tape recording being made of the private deliberations of people in this place. The truth is, as was said by way of interjection during Senator Macklin's speech, that it has been a part of the political process in this building, and in the old building, and in all parliaments, that that sort of material is used.

I do not think Senator Macklin would deny that members of the Australian Democrats have been enthusiastic users of such material. For example, Senator Janet Powell on a number of occasions has brought forward leaked material, presumably made available from the Public Service, with respect to the scrapping of the community youth support scheme (CYSS). I refer to reports in August 1987 in which Senator Powell described her source as `being as reliable as I can get without a public statement from the Minister'. In June 1988 it became a little clearer, when Senator Powell released a leaked draft Cabinet document outlining the proposed closure of CYSS projects. I do not raise that in some way hostile to Senator Powell. I do not suggest that she is doing anything different from what has been done by numerous senators and members in this place over a long period. I am using Senator Powell as an example because, among the Australian Democrats, I suspect she has been the most vigorous user of such material. In July 1988 she leaked what was described in her press release as `confidential Cabinet documents on child-care which are being considered today by the Federal Cabinet'. Senator Powell used those documents to criticise the Government and to call for policy changes. In the same way she referred to other leaked documents about plans to reduce projects in the field of community employment.

I do not wish to labour the point. The simple reality is that the Australian Democrats, in common with all other political parties in this place-Labor, National, Liberal, or any other party such as the Democratic Labor Party-have had access to material which is confidential and have used it. I believe that the entirely appropriate and proper distinction which is drawn by this Opposition is that if the normal deliberations of senators and members of this place are subject to electronic eavesdropping, however arranged, whether by the planting of a bug or the illicit use of the communications mechanisms throughout this building, we say that is of a quite different nature and kind. It destroys the basis for effective exchange between members of parliament and affects the system.

I reject what was an excellent diversionary speech and an excellent diversionary point by Senator Robert Ray. He said that we are concerned about this matter only because it touches us. The operation of this Parliament happens to be fundamental to the maintenance of democracy and our system of government. If we are not prepared to defend the integrity of the system here, we cannot expect anybody else to do so. We have a particular responsibility, not in the name of self-interest but in the name of being the people who are primarily responsible for the way this place functions. If it is good enough for members of the Labor Party and members of the Opposition to raise the issue of security of communications, as we all have done because it goes to the working of this place, it is good enough for us to show that we object to the sort of behaviour in which Senator Schacht has indulged in the use of this illicit material.

There were endless attempts to draw red herrings into the argument. Senator Bishop was used as an example because she brought into this place a tape recording of a public meeting. How in the world can that be said to relate to the issue we are looking at today, which is the taping of a private discussion between individuals-not even from one party, but across party lines? If this motion is defeated it will be an indication that the Senate is not prepared to impose any standards at all, that it is prepared to let these things run at large.

We do not accept the Democrats' amendment because, as I have tried to indicate in this response, we see the matters which Senator Macklin has tried to bring forward in his amendment as being different in quality and kind from the matters in this motion. We do not see the need for the sort of amendment that has been moved by Senator Harradine, although, were Senator Harradine's amendment to be carried, there would be no reason for us not to vote against the motion. On the speeches which have been made, it is the clear view of the Opposition that there has been a censurable act on the part of Senator Schacht. There is a clearly expressed view by Senator Macklin-and he did not indicate whether he was speaking on behalf of all the Democrats; I suppose we must assume that he was, since he did not--

TALK.START.PARA: —Only for the amendment.

—He spoke for them only in putting forward the amendment. On that basis it is clearly the view of the Australian Democrats that what Senator Schacht did was censurable and therefore, whatever the outcome of the divisions that will follow my resumption of my place, Senator Schacht should understand that it is the clear majority view of this place that what he did was improper, wrong and is not to be repeated.
—He is still laughing about it.

—He is laughing. Senator Schacht's incompetence as an individual was demonstrated in the debate here today by the performance of Senator Robert Ray, as against his own lacklustre incapacity to defend his actions. We are not surprised that he was unable to defend his actions because they were indefensible. In closing this debate, I say that the Labor Party is asserting in response that there are no rules at all. That is the simple assertion it is making. If that is its assertion, it is a very sorry day for the Australian Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Community Services and Health, and relates to the present guidelines issued by the Department of Community Services and Health on the approval of admission to a nursing home. Is the Minister aware that the present guidelines preclude from admission to a nursing home any person who may have been a resident of a state institution for a period which may have been as short as one year preceding the application for approval? Is he further aware that this guideline also applies to persons who may similarly have been residents of state institutions for three years in the past five? Does the Minister acknowledge that such guidelines infer that many elderly persons, who may be required to enter such institutions for treatment of a temporary illness, are precluded from ever returning to the nursing home situation despite a recommendation to the contrary by Commonwealth medical officers? —I think Senator Calvert promoted me by addressing me as the Minister for Community Services and Health. —Does the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories intend to congratulate his Queensland counterpart, Mr Geoff Muntz, on at last declaring a truce in the senseless, one-sided, 3 1/2-year war against crocodiles in the Daintree River? —No, it is not, as a matter of fact. I have an interest in crocodiles.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I have to concede at the outset that this is one battle, perhaps the only battle, that Mr Muntz appears to have won, because the purging of crocodiles has apparently been extraordinarily successful. As a result of that policy, uranium mining companies in this country have been able not only to obtain but also to hold their markets. The companies that currently operate under that policy have a capacity to increase production to meet any anticipated growth in demand, should that growth prove to be attractive.

So far as long term contracts are concerned, I recall-this may not be an absolutely accurate figure, but it is certainly in the ballpark-that the contract price is about $32, whereas the spot market price is about $11. That indicates that there is a greater likelihood of healthy trading on the spot market, rather than a readiness of potential consumers to write long term contracts. All of that suggests that at present the market is in a state of oversupply. I make those observations because I think that they support the Government's existing policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister saying that, in respect of market expertise, he and the Prime Minister are in a better position than those people who, hopefully, are prepared to risk their own money on new projects? If so, does he mean to imply that that sort of thinking will pervade any other sort of development that might occur in Australia?

—I do not accept the words that Senator Parer chooses to put in my mouth. It may well be that the Prime Minister is in a better position to make judgments about market matters, but I do not claim that expertise. I know that the Prime Minister is capable of making very incisive judgments about these things. On the whole, however, he may not be-and I do not think that he would claim to be-in a better position. I do not accept the honourable senator's proposition as being true.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask whether his attention has been drawn to a letter to the editor of the Gold Coast Bulletin of 27 May, in which Senator Sheil claims that when citizens:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . complete their compulsory Census form for the Australian Bureau of Statistics, private enterprise can then buy the information from the Federal Government.

Does the Minister agree that the statement by Senator Sheil may be construed as implying that personal confidentiality may be breached by the use of census material by the Federal Government? Can the Minister give an assurance that no specific identification of individual citizens, or personal information given on census forms, is selectively available to private enterprise organisations? As a national census will be conducted in 1991, can the Minister put aside any doubts in the minds of the public by explaining the manner in which census information is supplied to private organisations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The aggregated information from the census is, of course, supplied to virtually anybody who wants it. That is the reason for conducting a census in the first place. Of course, the information is useful to governments in various ways, but the expense of a census could not be justified if only governments had access to the aggregated information. I have been asked whether Senator Sheil's letter to the editor of the Gold Coast Bulletin, which I have read, implies that personal confidential information-in other words, disaggregated information-will be sold to the private sector. Senator Sheil's letter certainly implies that it will, as I believe it was meant to do. I suppose that Senator Sheil's footnote in political history will be that he was the shortest-serving Minister ever-all of about six hours, I think.

ANSWER.PARA: He has again been chasing votes among his ratbag right wing cheer squad, including such collective organisations as the League of Rights, and such individual luminaries as Peter Sawyer. He is regurgitating the pathetic assertions that Senator Walters made over the last six months or so, in the Senate and elsewhere. I do not really mind her doing it elsewhere, but I object particularly to her wasting the time of the Senate by doing it to such an extent here. I assume that Senator Sheil is not so ignorant that he does not know that information about individuals is not made available by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) to the private sector or to governments, although it is published in aggregated form, for the reasons that I have given. On the question of confidentiality, the way in which information is published is set out in ABS publications as follows:

The extent of detail in the tables is constrained to ensure that identifiable information is not being released. The likelihood of identifiable information being inadvertently released is dependent on the size of the geographic area the table refers to and the number and level of detail of the variables in the tabulations. Since data are more likely to be identifiable when smaller geographic areas are specified, census tables have been designed so that the level of detail of other variables matches the geographic areas. Thus, very detailed information is available for large geographic areas, such as capital cities or States, and limited detail is available for small geographic areas, such as legal local government areas.

To further avoid the inadvertent release of identifiable information, the tables have been subjected to slight random adjustments. The random adjustments are insignificant in relative terms, except for all numbers too small to be of statistical significance. Further details can be obtained from the entry INTRODUCED RANDOM ERROR in The 1986 Census Dictionary,

The catalogue number is 2174.0. This is just another example of the phenomenon to which I referred previously. The most inconsequential members of the Opposition-the TSMs as they are acronymically called-are trying to get a bit of publicity and few cheers from ratbags around the place by implying, knowingly I believe, falsehoods about the census and other matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. The Minister will be aware of speculation about a referendum on the environment, given the fact that he is quoted as having discussed this issue. Can he inform the Senate as to the status of this speculation? Can he estimate the cost of holding such a referendum in conjunction with the next election? Can he tell the Senate what further powers the Commonwealth would need-powers that it does not have currently-to ensure the protection of the environment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Given that I am the source of the speculation-I refer to a speech that I made last weekend-I am aware of it. At that time, however, I suggested that a referendum of this kind would be some way-five to 10 years-down the track. I was moved to say that because the problems that the greenhouse phenomenon would bring to Australia are of such scope that the Australian people would not expect six States, two Territories and the Commonwealth to come up with nine separate solutions. A national approach would be necessary. I hold to that view. I do not believe that I ever suggested that a referendum ought to take place at the next election. However, I am informed by my colleague the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr West, that if that were to be done the cost would be approximately $5.75m, and that most of that amount would be accounted for by printing, a very small proportion being accounted for by counting. I hope that that covers the first three parts of the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: He referred to the status of the speculation. As I have said, this is something that I have suggested for consideration some years down the track. So far as the further powers that the Commonwealth would need are concerned, may I say that, taking even the lower range of predictions about the greenhouse effect, quite clearly policies on coastal management would have to be turned over to the Commonwealth, given that there would be very significant changes in our coast. Beyond that, land clearance has been an enormous problem in Australia. I would have thought that there would need to be some national approach to that. In fact, if one looks at emissions from industry, from the production of energy or from motor cars, Commonwealth power might be necessary in a whole range of areas. That would depend largely on the results of the research that will be carried out here and in other nations during the next few years. The discussion at the moment on the specifics is probably, therefore, a little premature.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. I note reports that the fifteenth meeting of the Western Australian Iron Ore Industry Consultative Council was held in the Pilbara on 29 and 30 May. Can the Minister indicate what the Council's assessment of the current industry and market positions was? In particular, has the trend detected for last year of a decline in lost time through injuries been sustained? If so, what does this mean for the industry? What is the outlook for the industry for the next few years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fifteenth meeting of the Western Australian Iron Ore Industry Consultative Council did take place on Monday and Tuesday of this week. It was an occasion on which the Council conducted a review of the current situation. There has been significant improvement in the operation of the iron ore industry in the Pilbara over the last several years. At one time it was common badinage that the Pilbara was synonymous with industrial disputation. Apart from Robe River at the present time that cannot be said any longer. Increasingly it is recognised in tangible ways, the most tangible being the readiness by the Japanese earlier this year to come to long term iron ore contracts with Australian suppliers. There has been a growth of the Australian market share from 42.8 per cent in 1987 to a forecast 46.5 per cent this calendar year in the overall consumption of iron ore by the Japanese, with the largest increase amongst all the national suppliers to Japan going to Australian companies. In 1988 a record 98.3 million tonnes was shipped-that is, a 17 per cent increase on output over the 1987 figures.

ANSWER.PARA: This performance has been reached by an increase in productivity per employee. In 1980 the output per head of employee, measured by tonnes of ore mined, was 7,500 tonnes. Last year it was 11,000 tonnes per employee. It has also been occasioned by a significant reduction in lost time due to injury or accident. There has been 20 per cent less lost time in 1988 as opposed to 1987 through injury or accident in the Pilbara. That has resulted from a close working together of the unions and the companies on lost time issues. The lost time has reduced so much that it is equal to two extra working days per employee across the industry. That is a significant achievement in what is an accident prone industry. The task of mining is a capital intensive but dangerous task, and to achieve that result is a significant outcome. In addition, lost time due to industrial disputes has fallen markedly over the whole period across all companies. The achievements would have been much greater if Robe River had been excluded from the statistics. Indeed, Robe River has now excluded itself from the statistics, in that it has declined to answer Department of Industrial Relations surveys on the amount of down time because of industrial disputes on the ground that it is not compulsory to do so. So we have lost the measure of what industrial disputation is occurring in that company.

To bring this to a conclusion, this Government, working with the Western Australian Labor Government, over the last five years has brought about significant micro-economic reform in the Pilbara in that the Japanese consumers, who are the main consumers of our iron ore, recognise that this is now a reliable supplier. They not only recognise that but they also reward it with long term contracts and bigger market share at a 15 per cent price increase last year. That has been achieved by the application of Labor Party policy in industrial relations and the handling of developments in the iron ore mining industry. The one exception to that is Robe River. One hopes that, by the model achieved in the other iron ore companies, it will see that it is wrong in pursuing a confrontationist, anti-worker approach in the company and should adjust its management procedures to the type of management procedures now in operation in Mount Newman Mining Co. Pty Ltd, Goldsworthy Mining Ltd and Hamersley Iron Pty Ltd.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I advise where that puts me? A long way in front of Senator Brownhill, I suspect is the answer. Senator Cook has been responsible from the beginning for negotiations with the New South Wales Government on the south-east forests of New South Wales. I have had no talks with the New South Wales Government on this at all. My role has been to advise Senator Cook, which I have done. He has since come up with a proposal which, if adopted by the New South Wales Government, would mean the protection of more than 90 per cent of the National Estate forests in the area. —My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. I refer him to a recent meeting of the Australian Privacy Foundation held in Sydney.
—Was it taped?
—It was taped.
—Let's see the transcript then.
—The transcript is available to all. The issue of credit reporting was discussed.
—An excellent debate.

—It was an excellent debate, as Senator Bronwyn Bishop says. Excellent contributions were made to that debate by members of this chamber, including Senator Bishop, Senator Hill, Senator Janet Powell and the Minister. Last but not least, I was there.
—It is very interesting, but can we have the question?
—I ask the Minister: Does the Government propose to pass any legislation in respect of credit reporting?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Cooney for his most timely question. The Government will be legislating in this area to cover consumer credit and the industry. There is very much a need for it, as was instanced at the seminar Senator Cooney referred to. There is a need not only because we should prevent privacy abuse in this area but also because there is in place at the moment a rather inadequate and patchy mix of State laws and self-regulatory systems which are nowhere near the national set of rules that should be governing such a nationally based industry. The Government intends to cover this area by amendments to the Privacy Act to give the Privacy Commissioner extra responsibilities to cover this field.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the main issues discussed at that seminar was a proposal to introduce what is called positive reporting, which entails the collection and dissemination of detailed information on both the nature and the size of an individual's current credit commitments. Basically, it could amount to a personal profile. This information would be collected regardless of whether a particular person might be a defaulter in terms of his or her handling of credit. The Government believes that this proposal has not been sufficiently substantiated in terms of the benefit to the community. It believes that there are privacy concerns involved with it which are legitimate and real. It also believes that there are practical problems and, as a consequence, will not allow positive reporting to go ahead. The Government will also address issues which arise under the current system of reporting information. The Government intends to regulate access to and the use of existing credit reporting files, the primary target being those files that are transferred either to or from credit reporting agencies. In terms of the information held by credit providers, they will be able to maintain their files but if they wish to convey them to other credit providers, they will have to obtain the consent of the consumer involved. We will cover the fundamental issue of who has access. In that respect, the Government is concerned that only credit providers have access. Accordingly, there will be a need to cull some of the existing membership of an organisation such as the Credit Reporting Association of Australia. We will also cover the questions of in what circumstances access will be available, of accuracy of information, and, as I said earlier, the question of what information. Individuals will also, under this proposed legislation, have the right of access to their individual file in certain circumstances.

In terms of enforcement, as I said, the Privacy Commissioner will be supervising the area. The regulations under the legislation will lay down the parameters for the development of a code of conduct, which will be in accordance with privacy principles. That code will be a disallowable instrument for the purposes of this Parliament. Also, in terms of enforcement, there will be a mix of civil remedy sanctions. As well, the Privacy Commissioner will have the power to obtain orders from the Federal Court. The Government sees this as a very significant and historic guarantee of privacy for individuals in our society. We are pleased to be able to announce that we will be amending the Privacy Act to extend to this particular area of activity.

Can the Minister give an unequivocal guarantee to Territorians and travellers that no further delays will be occasioned by the failure of the Government or the FAC to consult with the airport terminal users?
—I am afraid I have not got a current brief on the state of those negotiations. I will take the question on notice.

—Is the Minister for Resources aware of a proposal being developed by some scientists, both here and overseas, to site all concentrated carbon dioxide emitters, such as thermal power stations, close to the sea and to use chemically engineered technology to enable carbon dioxide and sulphur dioxide to be absorbed by the ocean, thus reducing damage to the ozone layer? Will the Government investigate the feasibility of such a process and, if it is feasible, support the development of appropriate technology in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposal that carbon dioxide-CO2-from power stations be pumped into the oceans so that it can be absorbed by seawater has been considered by several researchers in the past. The results of preliminary studies suggest that such systems would require 20 to 30 per cent of the power station's output to operate and would result in an approximate doubling of the cost of electricity. The engineering, technical and economic feasibility of disposing of such large quantities of CO2 in the oceans is yet to be determined. The question of dispersing the huge volumes of CO2 through sufficiently large volumes of seawater, however, could be an important issue. There could also be, though, major environmental implications for the oceans themselves and there could be impacts on both a local and a global scale. Nor is there any certainty about the ocean's long term ability to store such large amounts of CO2.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Primary Industries and Energy will continue to monitor developments, and should the technology ever be proved feasible, Australia will be well placed to take advantage of it as virtually all of our major power stations are located close to the oceans. I acknowledge Senator Zakharov's long term interest in energy efficiency and environmental matters generally. A major focus of this Government's energy policy is on finding ways of developing clean burning technology and ways in which we can market clean coal to help to reduce the addition to the greenhouse gases of CO2 from coal-fired power stations. We are also looking at alternative forms of energy-adaption of liquefied natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas as transport fuels, and at the whole range of alternative non-renewable fuels.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY: COMPUTER CENTRES

He probably does not know that much about the 250,000-odd students in universities and the nearly one million who are doing trade courses, mostly in technical and further education institutions of various types. I do not suppose that the Ferrari-driving set has much contact at all with those people. I assume that because Dr Hewson saw that around $7 billion of Federal Government money is spent on education, he thought that education was a sharp and easy area to cut.

ANSWER.PARA: The experts, such as they are in the Liberal Party-that is, the people who have designated responsibilities for specific areas or for spending areas-set things straight about this yesterday. The Opposition spokesman on education-that is Mr Reith these days, I understand-told the Sydney Morning Herald that the coalition remained committed to its announced policy that `no school will be worse off' and that it would `maintain the existing number of tertiary places', which, of course, leaves no scope at all for the cuts that Dr Hewson was proposing only three days ago. Together with Mr Carlton's weekend comments on the impossibility of cutting defence, let alone those of some of the more pipsqueak Opposition front bench members who talk about increasing defence expenditure, we see the usual process of members of the Opposition, shadow Minister by shadow Minister, contradicting those others in the Opposition who say they would cut expenditure. They are walking away from all the hard decisions while still having the effrontery to say they will cut expenditure. The only thing substantial that is coming from the Opposition is what comes from Senator Stone.

I remind Dr Hewson of the article he wrote about taxes which was published in the Business Review Weekly in November 1986. It is not the article in which he described the present Leader of the Opposition as a prima donna; this is a different article. In respect of the Opposition's non-policy on taxation he said that the Opposition's credibility on tax would continue to be questioned until it specified all the detail. I say `ditto' to Opposition policy on outlays.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Finance to his reply to the question I asked in this place yesterday about his statement in the Senate on 11 May during the debate on the Wheat Bill in which he said that the taxpayers of Australia would have been liable for $300m had the Opposition's amendment of 95 per cent of guaranteed minimum price (GMP) on a subject year been used in the 1986-87 season. —As I said yesterday, I expected Senator Panizza to ask this question last week.

I gather from the questions asked today that Senator Panizza accepts that those figures were in the relevant issues of the Quarterly Review of the Rural Economy, or whatever it is called these days. That was the source of the figures that I used. It illustrated the difficulties and the potential risks in guaranteeing a fixed proportion of an expected price when that expectation is not realised.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Bearing in mind Senator Walsh's non-answer to the last two points of my question, does he expect me and my knowledgeable colleagues on this side of the chamber to accept that he has such an appalling understanding of the wheat market system for establishing the underwritten figure-especially considering that he is a farmer? Why has he given us irrelevant data from irrelevant publications to distort the implications to Australia's taxpayers of the Opposition's amendment to underwriting?

—I will confess a tendency to use archaic language sometimes, for example, `wireless'. Archaic though it might be, it is the term that ought to be used by all of those who think we should resist North American cultural imperialism. For the same fundamental reason, minus North American cultural imperialism, I tend to refer to the BAE Quarterly Review, as it was called in the days when I was more familiar with it than I am now. I know that Senator Panizza regards it as an irrelevant publication. I am not sure whether I have a personal view on that but I will put it to Mr Kerin with a view to effecting a savings option.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Finance, and I ask him to use neither archaic nor arcane language in reply. Has the Minister observed and reflected upon the large amount of new and unfilled office space being built in all Australia's capital cities? To what extent have high interest rates failed to curb building activity but merely shifted that activity from the area of need-that is, housing-to the central business districts (CBDs)? Can the Minister explain how Australians building homes in Australia with Australian labour and with Australian building material contribute to this country's foreign indebtedness? Finally, if families and others seeking their own housing are prevented from investing in Australian labour and building material will they not be more likely to buy foreign manufactured goods, causing high home interest rates to contribute to foreign debt rather than to reduce it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are four questions altogether. The first one referred to the large amount of new and unfilled office space. There is inevitably always some unfilled office space in CBDs. I am not sure whether it is substantially higher at this time than it normally is. It may well be. However, there are many misunderstandings in this question. The first one, and possibly the least serious, is that if it is true that there is a large amount of unfilled office space already but that resources continue to be diverted-as believed by Senator Coulter-into construction of more space, the underlying assumption is that those who are undertaking construction expect to lose money. I think that is an unlikely assumption.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the building of houses-this should be taken with a caveat because by definition no statistics are entirely up to date; but I will use the best available statistics-residential building in Australia is still proceeding at or very close to its physical capacity to supply. Under those circumstances the diversion of more money or credit into housing construction will not produce more houses so much as higher prices for houses and higher construction costs, with all the undesirable implications that flow from that. Under those circumstances, which probably also applied a few months ago, and with an excessive level of fiscal demand in the building industry, bidding up the inputs, including labour for residential construction, a higher level of demand and consumption is induced. Apart from pushing up the price of houses, this has adverse effects on our current account deficit in a direct way. Not all the components used for all residential construction, or for the furnishing of residences once completed, are supplied from the domestic market. Even if they were all supplied from the domestic market there would still be an effect on total demand and therefore an indirect effect on our balance of payments. The premises upon which Senator Coulter has based his questions are at best suspect and at worst wrong.
