DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Knowles proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for the Government to take immediate action to reduce the appalling level of poverty and homelessness of Australian youth and to apologise for the Prime Minister's campaign device in promising Government action to ensure that no child would be living in poverty by 1990.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance is one that the Opposition considers particularly important today. It is in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to take immediate action to reduce the appalling level of poverty and homelessness of Australian youth and to apologise for the Prime Minister's campaign device in promising Government action to ensure that no child would be living in poverty by 1990.

The Opposition brings forward this matter of public importance because it is simply not satisfied that enough is being done by the Hawke Labor Government to tackle the problems of poverty and unemployment. These twin evils that affect thousands of young Australians cannot be divorced from the macro-economic policies of the Labor Government that place families under stress through the combination of high interest rates and high personal taxation, and whose refusal to deregulate the labour market continues to price the young out of jobs.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), with little over six months to make good his pledge that by 1990 no Australian child would be living in poverty, is now actually trying to claim that he has solved the problem. I refer honourable senators to a statement by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) on the April economic statement, when he said that the pledge for child poverty to be abolished will be met by July 1989. That is but one day short of one month away. What a cheap, cruel position to put down to the people of Australia. They know full well that that will not be the case. We saw a little bit of soft-shoe shuffling by the Prime Minister not long ago, to try to change his pledge from `There will be no child living in poverty by 1990' to `There will be no need for children to live in poverty by 1990'. He carefully inserted the word `need'. That would probably be correct if the Prime Minister had taken action before now to ensure that people, particularly children, would not be living in poverty. Today 2.6 million households-one in every eight households-live in poverty. That appalling figure just happens to include 800,000 children. I might add that Australia has the highest child poverty rate of all Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries, with the exception of the United States. I believe that that is an absolute disgrace and a national embarrassment.

The Government has seen fit to saddle every Australian man, woman and child with its own debt, equalling $7,400 each. The size of our foreign debt just happens to have doubled from this time last year. The Government-and the Prime Minister in particular-has the audacity to say that the problem of child poverty will be solved by the end of this year. The Minister for Social Security has even more audacity in saying that it will be solved in a month's time. Whenever the Prime Minister states that child poverty caused by adolescents leaving home is somehow beyond the scope of his pledge, as it is not an economic cause, we can only point to the consistent weight of evidence that clearly suggests otherwise. It should be clear to the Labor Government by now that relationships, whether between spouses or between adolescents and parents, fracture because of economic considerations that in turn can result to so large a degree from government policies.

Just look at the Government's statistics. At the beginning of this year there were 239,000 recipients of class A widow's pensions and of the supporting parent benefit, and 79 per cent of those had no assessable income under the social security income test. When we consider that 180,000 single parents are responsible for 339,000 dependent children, all of whom are solely reliant upon government benefits for a living, the Labor Government hardly has cause for self-congratulation. It is indeed the Labor Government's record that the number of welfare beneficiaries in those two closely related categories rose from 209,000 in 1982, when Australia was in recession, to 240,500 in March this year. Yet yesterday the Prime Minister said that even the Brotherhood of St Laurence agreed that his promise to alleviate child poverty would be met.

Research quoted by the Brotherhood of St Laurence estimates that the introduction of the family allowance supplement has assisted only approximately 30 per cent of the 800,000 children to whom I referred earlier. A person who has close links with and sees poverty on a day to day basis is the Bishop of Tasmania, the Right Reverend Phillip Newell. He, as a Tasmanian church leader, yesterday criticised the Federal Government's interest rate policy and said that high rates were causing undue financial hardship. So there is little cause for rejoicing and for the Government, and the Prime Minister specifically, trying to quote other people in support of their false promises. In Western Australia alone, a leading voluntary welfare agency, Anglicare, quotes a report to say that 77,000 children in that State alone live below the poverty line and that two-thirds of sole parent families survive on less than $12,000 annual income. And the Prime Minister has the cheek and the gall to say that he is solving child poverty.

Welfare experts have estimated that, even with the meeting of the much-vaunted benchmarks, some 400,000 children will remain in poverty after housing costs are paid. If that figure of children in poverty is anything like correct, on a national basis it would translate into over half a million Australian children. Unquestionably, this is the pool that is sure to produce hundreds of homeless adolescents. We have only to look at the cost of raising children, according to the latest information from the Institute of Family Studies. In a low income family, a two-year-old child imposes costs of $23 a week, or $1,200 annually. An 11-year-old costs $38 a week, or $2,000 annually. A teenager can cost $57 a week, or $3,000 each year. In middle Australia, the realistic respective weekly costs of raising a two-year-old child, an 11-year-old and a teenager are $35, $63 and $95 respectively. So the figures get worse and worse. They do not equate with what the Government is allegedly doing to assist people.

The new family allowance of $9 a week, of $468 a year-I might add that the Government is enormously proud of that figure-does not make any impression whatsoever on the costs to which I have just referred when for a three-child family they reach $1,400 for the year. The real solution to child poverty requires much more than token gestures of financial assistance. It requires attention to housing, employment and education-all issues which the Government has just happened to recognise. But it is all too late. The extreme face of poverty grows from the breakdown caused by economic difficulties, problems that have increased and continue to worsen because we have a government that has adopted high interest rates as its tool of economic management, while at the same time doing nothing except make cosmetic changes to the tax burdens that affect Australian families.

The greatest immediate problem that drives families into poverty is the cost of housing. That is rising absolutely out of control as a direct consequence of the high interest rates used by the Government as its only tool of economic management. The latest rise to 17 per cent means that there has been a 47 per cent rise in five years. Since early 1988 they have risen from a figure of 13 1/2 per cent. I will be very surprised if anybody on the Government benches can be proud of that figure. Yet we hear people opposite saying, `That is okay. They probably own their homes'. That is the difference. Those opposite do not care. They do not live in poverty. Obviously, unlike Opposition senators, they are not seeing people living in poverty. That is a great tragedy. One needs to remember that families are $56 a week out of pocket since the Labor Government came to office. It is no wonder that average Australians are not inclined to rejoice about the July tax cuts, necessary as they may be as a belated alleviation of the economic bind affecting families. The tax cuts will be swallowed up by high interest rates, high inflation and more taxes within 12 months.

I remind the Senate that the Hawke Government is the biggest taxing, biggest spending government in peacetime history. Yet in a month's time the Government will give a candy back to the people pretending that all is well and that the wounds are healed. They certainly are not healed for low income families. A low income family on an income of $15,000 stands to gain $68 a month in increased allowances and tax cuts but will surrender over $38 in the latest interest rate rise, just on a $50,000 mortgage. Of course, it would be much more on a higher mortgage. I stress that these are mortgage costs alone and that Australia's inflation is running at the rate of 6.9 per cent generally, putting pressure on family budgets.

Repayments on the average housing loan of $60,000 have increased by 23 per cent, or $40 a week, over the past 12 months. With housing interest rates having reached 15 1/2 per cent by the March quarter of 1989, mortgage repayments on a national basis were consuming 40.2 per cent of median family income. It has been generally agreed that a figure of 25 per cent places a strain on family finances. I might add that it was only 22 per cent when this Labor Government took office. It is an absolute and utter disgrace.

These statistics cannot be divorced from the problem of poverty as it is inevitable that homes will be lost and living standards of individual families drastically reduced because of the failure of Labor Government policy. When people lose their homes because of the high interest rate policies of this Government, what do they do? In my State, Western Australia, the rental market availability is under one per cent. People cannot even rent. Those people who are financing the rental properties are also paying high interest rates. They cannot give their properties away. So people, forced out of their homes because of high interest rates will have literally nowhere to go.

Having failed Australian families by denying them affordable housing, the Hawke Labor Government stands equally responsible for a continual tax burden, quietly increased by bracket creep. Tax reform for families has been a sham. There have been tax changes; no reform, just changes-they have all gone up. Families supported by average weekly earnings that 35 years ago paid tax at a marginal rate of 19 per cent and 10 per cent of total income, now pay a marginal tax rate of 40 per cent-soon to be reduced by a mere one per cent to 39 per cent. How generous! Incomes of no more than $20,600, substantially below average weekly earnings, will attract a marginal tax rate of 39 per cent after 1 July. Incomes of $35,000, which will attract a marginal tax rate of 47 per cent, do not necessarily go far towards repaying mortgages and supporting families.

The policies of this Labor Government will, in two years, see two-thirds of Australian taxpayers-those that have supposedly not fallen into poverty-paying tax at the top two rates. Since March 1983 a family on average weekly earnings with two children has seen its real disposable income fall, taken away, robbed by this Government to the extent of $56 per week. Too often this Labor Government sends the message that if a family has two incomes all will be well. Where is the choice open for a family to have one income earner? This Government is trying to demand that Australian families have two income earners. This is to the detriment of the quality of family life and is contributing to the cycle of pressure that causes family break-up and eventual poverty. If families choose to have both mother and father working, that is fine. But why should the policies of this Government force people to do that?
Even fuel taxes have gone up to 22.39c per litre, with only 4.95c being spent on roads. This equates to about $15 of tax every time people fill up the average sized car.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator Crowley may well laugh. She is not in poverty. There are many families who are in poverty, trying to run a family car, and she could not give a continental whether they are paying $15 tax every time they pull up at the bowser.

SPEECH.PARA: Today the Opposition also seeks to highlight the fact that this Government has failed in providing adequate employment to young Australians which, I might add, is causing even more poverty. Rather than solid results of real jobs, we have had ingenious publicists dreaming up brand new acronyms with great fanfares of publicity for one person, and one person alone-the Prime Minister. How could we ever forget Priority One. What a disaster! That was going to create 75,000 trainee jobs. We are still waiting to see well over half of them. Those that were filled were filled basically in the public sector. Despite the Government having spent $29m, less than the previous allocation in 1987-88 to create 10,000 traineeships, most of which were in the public sector, the 1988-89 Budget earmarks $45m for 15,000 placements. The record is simply not encouraging. Why should we believe the Government now? Why should the people of Australia be conned any more.

The Government's employment and training initiatives announced in the Budget would reach only 5 per cent of sole parents with children, while less than 15 per cent of the long term unemployed could expect any help. To have any effect, these programs must be programs of substance, not just programs of rhetoric. The proportion of the unemployed with children increased from 37 per cent to 46 per cent between 1980 and 1986. This Government's track record is simply appalling. The way it continues to thrust people into poverty is just disgraceful. In particular, since 1982 the greatest proportional increase in unemployment rates has been for families with three or more children. The duration of unemployment for people seeking full time work is now 47 weeks-a 23 per cent increase from March 1983 when the Government took office.

The Government claims to have created 1.2 million new jobs. Before the number of new jobs that this Government has created is thrown up to us in this debate today, let us neither forget nor ignore the fact that we need at least 60,000 new jobs per year just to keep up with the population growth and school leavers. But does this Government say that? No, it does not. It just talks about the jobs it has created. It does not talk about the ones that are needed just to keep pace. Unemployment, like the poverty that affects children, like adolescent homelessness, can be solved only through sound economic management. Management that is sound and humane must work towards lowering the interest rates that destroy the basic foundation of living standards-housing-and must focus on protecting family living standards in taxation policy. The Australian Labor Party has failed on all counts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just in case people need reminding, I go back to the matter of public importance that is before the Senate today, which is:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to take immediate action to reduce the appalling level of poverty and homelessness of Australian youth and to apologize for the Prime Minister's campaign device in promising Government action to ensure that no child would be living in poverty by 1990.

I must admit that I am absolutely astounded that this matter of public importance has been raised in this chamber, in this Parliament, by a member of the coalition in view of the amazingly adequate achievements, in many respects, of this Government; in view of the abject failure of the coalition when it was in government; and in view, most of all, of the revelations that we have been hearing in the last few weeks about what this coalition would do in the unhappy event that it should be returned to government. It is quite correct for Senator Knowles to link together problems of poverty and homelessness of Australian youth. I would have been a great deal more impressed with her contribution if she had given us some really constructive ideas on how these problems would be dealt with by a coalition government.

We have had an amazing collection of purported facts and figures, many of them out of date, many of them totally incorrectly quoted, and a number of them amazingly spurious. For example, scorn has been poured on the fact that we have created only 1,300,000 new jobs in view of the fact that we need 60,000 a year just to cope with the school leavers coming into the work force. In six years 60,000 school leavers would take up at most 360,000 of those new jobs, so we are still almost one million jobs ahead. I think that Senator Knowles should have had a much closer look at the figures before she started using them with such gay abandon. The honourable senator could have profitably looked at a number of other issues in her analysis, if I can call it that, of the problems that she has raised today. She did not mention health, matters such as training for adults, child-care and a number of other initiatives on which we have an extremely proud record.

Let us go back to the matter raised by Senator Knowles and the claim she has made against the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his promise that was given at the time of the election in 1987. What I would like to put on the record here are endorsements not of Australian Labor Party people but of those who are in a very good position to know, those who are in possession of the information and who make a very serious analysis of these issues. Bishop Peter Hollingworth, when giving the George Syme Oration to the Royal Australian College of Surgeons on 7 May this year, said:

In strict economic security terms, it is true that the prime ministerial promise `that no children shall live in poverty by 1990' . . . will be achieved. This represents significant progress, and demonstrates that governments can meet some modest social justice objectives, even at a time of economic restraint when they are involved in public sector cutbacks and tax reductions in order to improve their economic efficiency.

I interpolate here that Senator Knowles's references to the Brotherhood of St Laurence and the statement which I also read some weeks ago, were based on 1986 figures. This is the up-to-date opinion of the Brotherhood of St Laurence:

This pledge, the most specific social commitment of the century has been the subject of a historic package to provide a guaranteed minimum income for poor children whose parents earn less than about $300 per week.

We congratulate the Federal Government on its work on child poverty, which represents a historic breakthrough in the national attack on child poverty. The Federal Government has now built a solid foundation of income security for Australian families.

Quite a glowing testimonial, I am sure honourable senators will agree. The third endorsement comes from the source which, in statistical terms, is probably by far the best placed to give an analysis; the Australian Institute of Family Studies' publication Families and the Tax Package. I will quote only the most salient comments because the analysis is very long. It states:
The centrepiece of the Government's strategy to assist low income families is the family allowance supplement (FAS).
I interpolate that this has been ignored by Senator Knowles. It continues:

When FAS was introduced, in 1987, the Treasurer pledged that the rates of payment would be increased to specific benchmarks related to the Prime Minister's commitment regarding child poverty. Those benchmarks were that combined weekly payments for children aged 12 and under would be set at 15 per cent of the married rate of pension and those for 13-to-15-year-olds would be set at 20 per cent of this rate.

As a result of the tax package, rates for younger children have been lifted to the benchmark via substantial increases in the rate of family allowance and those for 13-to-15-year-olds were raised, in addition to family allowance, by $3.10 per week to $34.10. By these means the Government's pledge to meet the benchmarks has been met. The new levels of FAS represent rises in real terms since 1983-84 of 41 per cent for younger children and 203 per cent for older children over the previous family income supplement payments.

Those are substantial increases in the amounts of real untaxed money in the hands of low income families, in the hands of the principal carers in those low income families, who in most cases are the mothers. Currently more than 530,000 families with 1.1 million children benefit and that represents a considerable hole in that series of figures that Senator Knowles has just used. In fact it gives us an idea of exactly what widespread advantage has been brought by comparison with what was previously the case with low income families in this country, as the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) said on the night of the April statement. We have now reached the point where younger children are receiving 15.3 per cent of the married pension rate and older children are receiving 20 per cent of that rate. They are two benchmarks considerably ahead of what was advocated in the report of the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty as the way in which those families should be lifted out of poverty, which was between 12 and 18 per cent, depending upon the age of the children involved.

What did we have from the coalition when it was in government? We had a failure to index these payments; a failure to recognise the extra needs of families with children; and a failure to establish standards-and standards are what we have established. I have not seen them being questioned by the Opposition, or by anybody else for that matter. I have not seen any alternatives to the standards we have set being proposed by the Opposition. In fact all that I have seen-I must say that it is a matter of considerable interest to many of us who have been working on these policies for years-are statements like the ones I have just read endorsing the Government's attempts to lift these families out of poverty. Honourable senators should not forget that we also introduced for the first time a rental assistance allowance for low income families renting privately and we have made a considerable improvement in the payment that is being awarded regularly to families with handicapped children, so that the incomes of those families are substantially healthier than they were a comparatively short time ago.

Over the past few days and weeks we have had fairly vague suggestions from the Opposition about what it might do in relation to social security payments. We wonder whether it will tighten the eligibility rules, toughen up the income and assets tests or abolish the indexation of pensions, benefits and family allowances. Is that the way it is planning to go? The Opposition's major policy platform during the past three weeks indicates that its suggestions begin and end with slashing social welfare expenditure. Is the Opposition planning to target family allowance payments that are currently being made to nearly two million families with more than 3.8 million children-Senator Knowles should note that not all those families are in poverty-or will it target the payments to the 1.1 million children of those 530,000 low income families who have been very much the beneficiaries of this Government's welfare policy? Is that the way the coalition is planning to go?

I remind honourable senators-and Senator Walsh reminded us of this today in Question Time-that we have made considerable gains in targeting social security outlays to those most in need, to the point where, since 1983, social security outlays have fallen from 6.9 per cent of gross domestic product to 6.2 per cent in 1987-88. There is not a great deal more cutting and slashing that can be done there. We expect social security outlays to be at 6 per cent in 1989-90. Social security has also declined as a proportion of real budget outlays from 24.1 per cent in 1983-84 to 23 per cent in 1987-88.

What we have been able to do is to target a great deal more accurately those individuals and households where the need is greatest. From what we can see, the Hewson solution would destroy the past seven years of repair work and targeting done by this Government since we inherited the social welfare problems of 1983. At that point families were suffering very badly from the fact that over those years of the Fraser Government the assistance directed to families had been dropping steadily in value.

What we have also heard from Senator Knowles today is criticism of the way in which we have been able to remove barriers to employment, particularly of young people. Quite clearly, Senator Knowles is unaware of the facts. Young people and teenagers have benefited very markedly from the policies of this Government. They are the people who have shared in the extra jobs that have been created under this Government. Also they have seen the situation move from the disastrous set of circumstances when we came to government, when the unemployment rate for young people was absolutely astronomical, to the present situation where the unemployment rate for young people, as well as the general unemployment rate, has markedly reduced. The rate of youth unemployment now is almost the same as that of the adult population. That is in very marked contrast to the situation six years ago. Teenage full time unemployment has fallen by 80,100, which is a 50.8 per cent reduction, to about half what it was under the previous Government.

We were confronted by an absolutely appalling situation when we came to government. A number of schemes have been very successful in getting young people back to work. Of course, the most successful measures have been our policies which have generated a much healthier economy, and which not only have taken young people into the work force but also have assisted a great many more of them to acquire the education and training which will make their future prospects a great deal more rosy. At the same time, we have introduced job training schemes which have been of considerable assistance one way or another.

I spoke about targeting. Perhaps I should explain it a little more carefully for Senator Knowles. For example, when looking at a scheme to assist sole supporting parents back into the work force, one appreciates very well that not every sole parent will need assistance; many will be out of the work force for only a short period. Their education, training and general experience will allow them to return to the work force without any great assistance from us. Others may have small children, sick children or dependants which will require their presence in the home for a longer period. However, amongst the cohort, there will be women who do need bridging education and assistance with training on a one-to-one basis. It is for those people that schemes such as the jobs, employment, and training, or JET scheme, and Jobstart have been introduced. We introduced the training schemes of that nature to avoid people being unemployed for long periods.

TALK.START.PARA: —All have been a disaster.
—Our experience so far is that these will be very valuable and will be successful in whatever terms one likes to use.
—You know that not to be true; it is quite the reverse.

—I know it to be true. I have had the satisfaction of being involved with the planning of these schemes, as has Senator Crowley. I would like to know how else Senator Knowles is able to account for the fact that the unemployment rate for young people is currently one-half of what it was when we came to government.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been some strange reference to tax scales, which also shows considerable confusion in the mind of Senator Knowles. She referred to rates as though they were flat rates and was not totally open and honest about the fact that the group to which she referred, those earning between $17,600 and $19,500 per year, have a marginal tax rate of 29c in the dollar, which means that they would probably pay in taxation between 12 per cent and 15 per cent on average of their incomes. She should take a closer look at the taxation rates before she starts making such sweeping statements.

In addition, a considerably greater amount of well-targeted assistance to families helps them to look after their children in the home rather than their being put into institutions, which used to be the case. Our child support scheme is another extremely valuable measure of this Government and one that I am very glad to observe has bipartisan support in this Parliament. Although the scheme has been functioning for a relatively short period, already we see a substantially reduced number of sole supporting parents who qualify for full benefits, for the very good reason that they are now receiving maintenance to which they are absolutely entitled but which they had not previously received. Their standard of living in very many respects is greatly enhanced.

In addition to increased employment, the Government has improved services in the provision of child care and refuges for young people. Youth homelessness is not a new phenomenon, as Senator Walters will confirm. We were both on a committee which looked closely at this matter years ago.

In conclusion, I would like just to quote from what has been said by the Opposition and what we might expect from a coalition government whose secret agenda, we believe, is to cut families adrift from community support. That is what John Howard meant in his reply to the April statement when he said that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) should have announced further measures to reduce Government spending and that he should have arranged for families to look after themselves. We believe this Government already has many reforms for families in this nation, to enhance their standard of living and to greatly enhance the opportunities for their children in the years to come. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance that we are debating today, put forward by Senator Knowles, states:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to take immediate action to reduce the appalling level of poverty and homelessness of Australian youth and to apologise for the Prime Minister's campaign device in promising Government action to ensure that no child would be living in poverty by 1990.

Of course, this is a matter of enormous public importance. This Government and any government should be urged to take action where there is poverty and homelessness in this country. Clearly, there is poverty amongst children and young people, and clearly, there is homelessness, in large measure as a result of this poverty. There is also homelessness which has not come as a result of poverty. We need only to look at some of the documentation. In the brief time available to me today, I will begin with the document released relatively recently as part of a campaign put forward by the Brotherhood of St Laurence entitled `Promise the Children'. I was a little disturbed by the title of this campaign. Children in this country have had enough promises; I would have much preferred to see the campaign named `Action for Children' or something of a much more positive nature. Nevertheless, that is the title that the Brotherhood has chosen. In its document Child Poverty: The Facts it documents facts which have been put already by Senator Knowles and are becoming all too readily a matter of general knowledge and, unfortunately, are not reducing very significantly. As Senator Knowles said, in terms of absolute poverty among children, among Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries Australia lags only a very short way behind the United States, with a very high level of almost 17 per cent.

The massive documentation in the report of the National Inquiry into Homeless Children by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission-the Burdekin report-brings the issue of homeless children very much to our minds. The Brotherhood reminds us that the Federal Government's introduction, in 1987, of the family allowance supplement and income supplement for children in low income families has reduced the number of children living below the poverty line by about 30 per cent. Of course, that is not adequate. The Brotherhood refers to what it sees as the causes of child poverty in Australia. It lists as the key elements unemployment, sole parent families, high housing costs, inadequate levels of government income support and low wages. On those, the Democrats have no disagreement whatsoever. They are all results of the sorts of economic policies that are being operated in this country.

Unemployment is still with us, and it is a matter of great concern to the Democrats that the Government, the Opposition, the business community and even the unions appear to be somewhat satisfied with the unemployment plateau of about 7 per cent that we appear to have reached and at which we appear to be stuck. Yet only a decade ago this country would have been horrified at the thought of accepting that. During Question Time today Senator Coulter asked whether Senator Walsh could explain how home building in this country was contributing to our foreign indebtedness; in reply, the Minister for Finance spent several minutes explaining how detrimental the building industry's growth is to our economy.

In this week's newspapers the Master Builders Association and the housing and construction people are reported as having pointed out that some 40,000 jobs in the building industry are likely to disappear because of the pressures that are being put on the economy by the Government's policy of high interest rates. However, I do not take too much comfort from the alternative offered by the Opposition. Senator Giles has referred to the remarks of the new shadow Treasurer, Dr Hewson, with regard to cutting government spending. Senator Giles pointed out that this Government has also cut its social security payouts by targeting. Given that we still have unacceptably high levels of youth homelessness, child poverty and unemployment, the mind boggles at the thought of what would happen under the alternative government, whose expenditure on welfare, education and health could be cut, as Dr Hewson has been quoted as suggesting.

Dr Hewson has been talking about better targeting. The appalling nature of some of this Government's targeting-and I will get to that matter later-is bad enough; imagining the alternative makes for nightmares. In its 1989 Budget submission, the Business Council of Australia urged the Federal Government to introduce spending cuts of $1 billion. We know that the Business Council of Australia has considerable influence on the coalition's policy-making. The prospect of the alternative to what we have now is not terribly appealing. On the basis of what we have heard so far, the Democrats do not believe that the Opposition would provide any comfort or would address the issues that Senator Knowles has raised in this debate. It is staggering that the Opposition should raise such issues, given that, apart from the sorts of things I have just mentioned-which provide no comfort at all-it is not putting forward any policies. Unemployment is a problem already, and it looks like getting worse if, for instance, we are to squeeze back on the housing industry, which at other times of high unemployment has always been seen as a way out. Now we are told that it is contributing to our foreign debt and, therefore, that it is going to be squeezed even more. That will cause higher unemployment, and the poverty and homelessness problems can only get worse.

Sole parent families as a group seem again to have dropped off the political agenda altogether, on both sides of politics. As the Brotherhood says, some people seem to think that the growth in the number of sole parent families is due to young women purposely having children outside marriage, knowing that they can claim a government pension. Of course that is not true. The level of payments to, and the struggles of, sole parent families are most significant and most damaging, and all too often result in poverty and homelessness. In fact, the majority of sole parent families result from separation, divorce or widowhood.

Family policies are touted throughout the Opposition's document Future Directions, to which we are asked to go for an indication of what the Opposition proposes for the future, should it get into government. There we are told that the precise details of the Opposition's social security and taxation policies must await its assessment of the overall resources available nearer the time of the next election. At the same time we are asked to accept the Opposition's rhetoric about the family. It says that it wants to improve the system so that individuals and families in need are properly supported and encouraged to assume more personal responsibility for improving their circumstances. I hope that, unlike the current Government, the alternative government would support family support services.

The Burdekin report, at recommendation 15.3, recommends that, where possible, families ought to be reunited and that negotiation, conciliation, counselling, provision of information and assistance with access to services to the family are required. Yet this Government, about three years ago, set up a pilot program of family mediation centres. There were three around Australia, one of them in Noble Park in my city of Melbourne. That centre was of enormous benefit to families of all kinds. It was able to provide services, support, information and advice, whatever the family problems, whether finance, relationships between family members-children and parents, parents and grandparents, children and grandparents, or whatever. Yet the program in Wollongong was cut off some time ago. The people at Noble Park are staggering along for another 12 months, having now to get their funds from the same sources as the marriage guidance people, whose guidelines require that there has been breakdown. So we have moved from a pilot program which dealt with prevention, support, and reuniting people to a program under which, if there is breakdown, the people concerned might get finance. A major cause of child poverty is sole parenthood, and much of it results from marriage or relationship breakdown. It seems to the Democrats that in this regard a major focus of policy must be the extension of a program of family conciliation centres, not a pilot for a few years and then a cut-off. Whether we are dealing with children in poverty or young homeless people, some such preventive program would make a major contribution. So far as we can see, however, there is not much hope on either side of politics.

The other area to which the Burdekin report points specifically, where there would be considerable assistance to young people, is that of income support. The point is made that young people often leave home because they are unemployed or because they are seeking employment. Often young people from isolated rural areas and from regional areas have got to go to other centres for employment. A submission to the Burdekin Committee pointed out that in the City of Ballarat in Victoria 50 per cent of the unemployed are under 25, and that the overall unemployment rate is twice the national average. Those people are forced to move in order to get jobs. Young people moving to get jobs on reduced unemployment benefits and inadequate income support systems are very quickly sinking into homelessness through no fault of their own. It is a simple matter for the Opposition to say that young people cannot get jobs because we are paying them too much. It is time that we recognised that one of the reasons that young people find it extraordinarily difficult to get jobs is that the jobs which a generation ago, and longer, existed for young, unskilled people, which were socially useful jobs, now do not exist. In many cases they are done by machines, by mechanical means, by some electronic process and so on; or they are taken by older people in the community who, as breadwinners, have been given priority as their jobs have been replaced through technological advance. I was brought up in a small country town where every biscuit was bagged, where every pound of tea was taken out of a large tin and put into a small one and where every retailer did home deliveries and took home orders. All those sorts of jobs, in which young people used to skill themselves to work up to becoming very important members of the community, have gone. We do not give those options to our children now.

What we must do is accept our responsibility. As Brian Burdekin says, we must meet the obligation to support them as required by the Declaration of the Rights of the Child. We do not do that. The young homeless allowance in this country is inadequate and almost impossible to qualify for. The Burdekin report makes several recommendations which reflect amendments to the young homeless allowance. I myself attempted to have them passed in this place some two years ago. It is very difficult to get the young homeless allowance and it ought to be easier to achieve. One of the major recommendations which the Australian Democrats would support is that the total benefit paid to homeless young people should be the equivalent of the adult rate of unemployment benefit; that while people are qualifying-and let us hope the qualifications are made easier-for the young homeless allowance there should be an alternative income support strategy; and that a special benefit should be paid during that interim period. The suggestion is a total equivalent to the job search allowance plus the young homeless allowance. Clearly, it is a major problem.

The other area that the Brotherhood of St Laurence draws attention to is high housing costs. For two or three years the Democrats have been pointing out that it is housing costs that have been pushing more and more people into poverty. Until both the major parties in this place agree to remove negative gearing, we will continue to have people finding it difficult to purchase their own homes, putting pressure on public housing and so on, so that the people at the bottom of the pile continue to be the worst off. As a result of the inadequate levels of government income support, we, as a community, have an obligation to support those who simply cannot get work or housing.
