SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this month, on the Appropriation Bills, I spoke on this very subject. At that time I asked how many senators had watched the television program Nobody's Children. I asked whether the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or his minders had bothered to familiarise themselves with the plight of those children. I asked whether the Treasurer (Mr Keating) had seen the program. I asked, if they did, whether the Prime Minister still maintained that he was on track for that wonderful election promise he made: that by 1990 no child would be living in poverty. At the time, I said that the Prime Minister had abused and used those forgotten children; that he had used them for his own political purposes, giving them promises and expectations that he knew at the time would never be fulfilled by him. As we know, he subsequently wanted to change that, ever so slightly; but he has not got away with it.

SPEECH.PARA: I was appalled that Senator Giles in her speech on homeless youth did not even bother to talk about the years of experience that she and I both had on the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare inquiring into homeless youth. She referred to that in only three or four words, saying that she had been a member of it. This is not new. On 5 December 1980 the Senate was so concerned about the homeless youth problem that was developing at that time that it gave the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare terms of reference which included the causes of, the problems associated with and the effect on Australian society of homeless youth, including the appropriate responsibilities of governments at all levels in the provision of services to this group; and the role and responsibilities of the family in supporting young people. That was in 1980. In August 1982 the Committee reported to the Senate. This Government came to power six months later.

What has this Government done in the period it has been in power? It had a report and it had recommendations. I would like to read just a couple of those recommendations. I am unable to go into them fully due to the lack of time. One of the recommendations was:

That when family support breaks down irretrievably or is non-existent, both government and the community have a clear responsibility to provide the necessary support for the young person until such time as he or she is able to make the final transition to full independent living.
The Committee also said:
That family breakdown and youth unemployment are major factors which are associated with youth homelessness.

The Committee said that the Commonwealth should provide additional funds to ensure that a properly coordinated data collection study be undertaken and that a nationally supervised `in service' youth refuge worker training scheme be established. The Government has done absolutely nothing. Because it has done nothing, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission decided to set up yet another inquiry. The letter written to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), which can be found at the front of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report entitled Our Homeless Children, states:

It is with deep concern that we present the report of our National Inquiry into Homeless Children and Young People. On behalf of the many thousands of children affected, we respectfully suggest that the Government give urgent consideration to the report and to the recommendations we have made.

What recommendations did it make? They were almost identical to the recommendations that we made nine years ago. What is the point of the Government having these recommendations put to them? The Burdekin report says:
In 1982 the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare stated-
and I was Chairman of that Committee-

so unreliable are the statistics available on the extent of youth homelessness that the Committee was hesitant to refer to them at all . . . Until such time as a properly conducted survey is undertaken, with adequate supervision and controls, there will continue to be conjecture as to the actual extent of the problem and whether or not the problem is increasing.

The Burdekin report goes on to say that in 1980 a survey showed that an estimated 9,000 young people per year were homeless. What is the figure today? At the time of our report, it was estimated that there were 9,000; today it is 40,000. The Government has sat on its hands and on our report and done absolutely nothing about the plight of these children.

Because there is no data, we do not have the ability to plan and work out just what we should be doing for these children. Our Committee gave a rough profile of homeless youth. They were probably 15 to 18 years of age; probably Anglo-Saxon; had experienced conflict within the family-for example, disputes with parents, unable to get along with a de facto parent or authoritarian father-may have been subject to physical, sexual and/or emotional abuse; often came from a non-traditional family such as a single parent or de facto family; the possibility of a drug or alcohol problem; and so on. We had the rough profile. We gave it to the Government. We asked it to do something about it, and it has done absolutely nothing-except the Prime Minister made the promise in an election speech that no child would be living in poverty by 1990. What a disgraceful event that was. It is disgraceful that the Government had on its plate the recommendations of the report of the Standing Committee on Social Welfare, but did nothing. Senator Giles did not even bother to refer to that report today even though she was a member of the Committee. I wonder why. Was it because she was ashamed of her Government for not having implemented any of the recommendations? Or was it because of the television program Nobody's Children, which portrayed so well how the homeless youth have been used and abused by this Government?

When I first went on that Committee I had a vague feeling that perhaps the majority of those children were children who had run away because they were not prepared to put up with parental authority. That is far from the truth. By far, the majority of those children have been used or abused by their parents or by their de facto parents. We went around the shelters throughout Australia. We had a cup of coffee with these children in the shelters and found them to be very outgoing. They talked to us about their problems. One young girl said, `Mum's not too bad. She gives me $10 every now and again'. It was her de facto father from whom she had to get away. The girl's mother knew that her de facto spouse was sexually abusing her young daughter. For the security of the rest of the family she allowed her daughter to leave home because she felt she could not cope without the spouse's financial support.

In another case, two young children, a boy and girl aged seven and eight, had gone home after school one afternoon to find that their mother and their de facto father had packed up and gone-lock, stock and barrel. The two young children went back to the school and slept in the school grounds over- night. It was a couple of days before the teacher found out that they were completely parentless. I felt very sorry for another young chap who at the time was about the age of my youngest child. He was covered in tattoos, he was wearing a singlet, he had long hair, and he wore earrings. I thought, `What would I do if my young son came home looking like that?'. When I said to him, `What's your story, lad?' he burst into tears and walked outside. The person who was looking after the shelter said that it was his first night away from home and that he would toughen up.

What a dreadful situation we have in Australia. I know that the Government cannot wave a magic wand as the Prime Minister pretended he could do, nor can it legislate for good parents. I am fully aware of that. I am also fully aware that there is much the Government can do. I am fully aware that the Burdekin report made a recommendation saying that it was the Government's responsibility. It stated:

Where children and young people leave or ought to leave home because of serious neglect or abuse, the Commonwealth should meet the obligation to support them, regardless of their age, in conditions where they are protected and can develop as required by the Declaration of the Rights of the Child.

That is a very basic recommendation from the Burdekin report. It is also a very basic recommendation that our Committee put down eight years ago. Why has the Government not done anything at all in that period? It has buried its head. The only use it has made of those children is for the Prime Minister to grandstand prior to an election.

The television program Nobody's Children and the subsequent Couchman program in which Peter Couchman interviewed young homeless children brought back so many memories to me. These were the same children as those we interviewed when I was Chairman of the Committee on Social Welfare. They were making the same requests. When asked what sort of accommodation they wanted, they said exactly what they said in 1982. They said, `We want a block of flats so that we can all live together'. When that proposition was put to us, when we talked to them one to one across the coffee table, I asked, `Do you really believe that is practical?'. One of them said, `No, I guess not. We'd only get into trouble. We'd only have the police calling. We know that we need adult supervision'. They were asking for the same thing on the Couchman program, but they were not asked whether they thought the proposition was practical. They were not asked whether they should have adult supervision. The failure to ask those questions gave people watching the wrong impression. The majority of those homeless youths to whom we talked, as a committee, were fully aware of their own problems, their own failures. They knew that, left to their own devices, there was no way they would not get into trouble, that they needed adult supervision.

What these children ask for is pretty basic. They do not ask for much. They ask to be given somewhere to shelter but not the type of shelters around Australia in which they can stay only for a few weeks at a time before being shunted off. They cannot stay at the shelters for more than three weeks. They ask for permanent accommodation. These children are not there because they want to be there; they are there because they have been abused. It is the responsibility of this Government to act on the recommendations of the two reports that have been put in front of it. If it does not respond to those recommendations, if it continues to make false promises, this Government is far worse than most of us on this side of the chamber think it is. Surely there should be some humanitarian feeling on the Government benches. Surely there must be some responsibility somewhere amongst this crowd who profess to care for the underdogs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are asked today to consider as a matter of public importance the need for the Government to take immediate action to reduce the appalling level of poverty and homelessness of Australian youth, and to apologise for the campaign device of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in promising Government action to ensure that no child will be living in poverty by 1990. Let me say at the outset; on behalf of the Prime Minister, the Government and myself, that I do not apologise for that statement. That statement is usually lifted out of context by the Opposition. Even by itself it stands as a commitment to the intention and aim of this Government. It is a statement of which we should be proud-not ashamed. If the worst criticism that could be levelled against this Government is that it has not quite achieved that aim by 1990, we could say that it still has to keep to its promise. To suggest that it is no more than a device is insufficient and is, I think, a measure of the Opposition's capacity to address this topic. It is precisely because this Government cares, it is precisely because it recognises the damaging effects of poverty that it makes as a political statement, as a priority of policy, a commitment to reduce poverty. I will quote what the Prime Minister actually said at the time. Opposition members never want to know the full context. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: By 1990 no Australian child will be living in poverty.

And to this end, my Government will establish a new program of family help-a program designed to lift more than 1 million Australian children into security and to help the more than half a million Australian families in greatest need, the hardest pushed, the most disadvantaged.
Labor's new Family Allowance Supplement will be paid, to mothers, on the basis of family income and family size.

That was the commitment and the promise. The Government will deliver as of 1 July this year. Last year in the appropriation debate we were criticised by the Opposition, in particular by Senator Chaney. The quote that I have used on a number of occasions by Senator Chaney appears on page 2630 of the Senate Hansard of 23 November 1988. He said:

With respect to assistance to families, I condemn the Government for the fact that the only families it has been prepared to help have been those on the lowest incomes. It has been prepared to help 10 per cent or so of families through the family allowance supplement.

The Government was condemned by Senator Chaney for doing precisely what Opposition senators say the Government ought to do. Senator Chaney acknowledged that it was our priority to help the lowest income families in this country. He said we had done this and he condemned us for doing it. I asked him then-he has never answered-whether he would have preferred it if we had actually helped the people at the top end of the income scale. He just does not know how to answer it. The Government is condemned for doing precisely what it said was its priority-to help families on the lowest income. It has done that. In the Budget statement last year it said that by 1 July tax cuts and changes in family allowances would occur. It made that statement and promised to do that. It has delivered. Again, the Government's commitment to assisting families out of poverty is on the record, not only as Senator Chaney complained about families at the lowest end of the income scale but now families well into the middle income scale through tax cuts, family allowance benefits and the family allowance supplement. The Opposition has great gall. It also has a lack of rigorous analysis. It has very little imagination. Ultimately, it has no policies at all.

Senator Walters said that she was a member of a committee which inquired into homeless youth which started in 1980 and reported in 1982. That report is something I know about because it has been cited. It was a very useful report. My colleagues Senator Zakharov and Senator Giles have drawn it to my attention. We have used it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What recommendations have you brought up?

—Senator Walters should wait. Nobody interrupted her while she was speaking. She should hold about. That report contained useful information. It was brought together in a report put to people like myself and others who have worked in that field, as have you, Madam Acting Deputy President. We have had first hand experience, unlike the appalling claims of Senator Knowles that some of us never work amongst poverty or know about those cases. It is a disgraceful way of debating anything. Whether we have the experience or not matters less than that we understand and appreciate it. Some of us have had long years of experience in these areas and know what is contained in that report about homeless youth. We know about the shocking program on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation called Nobody's Children. In some ways this excellent program said not so much what was new but presented old and appalling information in a very powerful and pungent way.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has been aware of a huge number of priorities it had to address when it came into government. One of these was to tackle the area of assistance to families and homeless children, particularly those who may have been homeless as a result of domestic violence or family break up. The dramatic increase in funding under this Government to the shelter movement is one way this Government has very seriously addressed the question of homeless youth. That seems to be quite overlooked and ignored by Senator Walters. I would certainly agree that there was not a sufficient number of youth shelters, but certainly the shelter movement for youngsters is in place and there is a very dramatic increase in the commitment by this Government towards public housing. The Government is on its way to addressing those problems.

There are two things that need to be said. Firstly, the Opposition's analysis of what causes the breakup of families and what causes youth homelessness and so on is similar to its analysis of the cause of domestic violence. It is very insufficient. All of us who are serious about examining these questions know that they are multicausal. Secondly, there are questions of poverty which contribute to this problem but many of us can cite children, let alone wives, from very wealthy families who find themselves victims of domestic violence or homeless children. The question of poverty certainly correlates highly with this problem and one would be a fool to ignore the consequences of poverty in those two very important areas. But they are not the only causes. Thousands of poor families in this country do not bash their wives or their children and do not have children leaving home. We are talking about a number somewhere between 9,000 that Senator Walters's committee wanted to say was correct-I suggest that was a very reasonable and modest number-and approaching 40,000, which was Mr Burdekin's suggestion. Senator Walters's report said that the data was not there. Mr Burdekin's report said the data is not there. One would have to qualify those figures. Senator Walters qualified her figures very thoughtfully and very reasonably.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. Senator Crowley has obviously misunderstood me. I was quoting from the Burdekin report, not from our report.
—There is no point of order.

—Senator Walters would do anything for an interruption. She was very reasonable in her report, as has been brought to my attention, because she said, and still says, that it is very hard to examine the question with an insufficient database. I am advised that in her report-I have read it and know it to be the case-that she could not be sure that the children who were in one shelter one night were not counted again in a different shelter the next night. Those were her words. That is in the report. So she put a qualification on the figures. I simply urge her to put the same qualification on the figures we have now. We cannot be sure. There are some thousands of children in this country who are homeless and that is appalling. It is a tragedy. This Government is well aware of it and is addressing it. It is addressing it through the shelter movement, through public housing and through the assistance not just to the youth shelter movement but to the domestic violence shelter movement. It is also addressing the question by its recent announcements of increases in the family allowance supplement and by tax cuts.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the causes of youth homelessness is poverty. We have not for some time defined what poverty is. It has been used extraordinarily loosely in the debate today, as has the word `child'. What do we mean by a child? That has not been properly defined. Most of us would understand in lay terms that a child might cover children between zero and 14. `Youth' tends to be the word we use for children once they have become established teenagers. I am not suggesting they are not children or minors but in terms of the way we are using the word in this debate we are slipping between assistance for children in families where it is much more targeted in two different ways by this Government, by children between zero and 13 and an increased amount of money for children between 13 and 16, to youth homelessness. To argue the Prime Minister's promise that child poverty will not exist in 1990 by quoting evidence of youth homelessness is somewhat fraught. I would like some more precision in the Opposition's presentation.

I would also like to know what the Opposition is so unhappy about. If it says that there is more to be done I would say to them, `Absolutely, this Government knows it and that is why it has just established its second stage of policies to deal with it'. If we were to say to the people of Australia, `Who do you think will do something about this-the Opposition that complains or the Government that has been here for six years in doing something about it? Which is the Government that has established benchmarks for the cost of children, which is the Government that has introduced these payments and increased them-the latest figures are $24 for a child between zero and 13 and $34.10 for children between 13 and 16 as of 1 July-which is the Government that has introduced these tax cuts, and not for the first time--

TALK.START.PARA: —I give in. Which is it?
—Order! Would you cease interjecting, Senator Alston, unless you are in your place.

—If we were to believe the Opposition, the best it has come up with since Dr Hewson has been running the economic show is the suggestion that it will cut spending on health, education and social security because these areas are not properly targeted. One of the things it indicates is that Dr Hewson has not examined the huge changes under social security, both with the review by Dr Bettina Cass and the specific targeting and consequent reduction in expenditure under this Government, so that while the total bill has come down the payments per individual have gone up. Together they are a commitment and are evidence that this Government knows what it is doing. It is addressing poverty, the establishment of benchmarks and, for the first time, indexing those payments so that families will not fall below this level again.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard some quite far-ranging comments and contributions in the debate, most of which are hard to tie together. They came in particular from Senator Knowles. Somehow the price of fuel and insufficient allocation of excise for roads got into the cause of everything. The people are being asked here whether they would prefer to stay with a government with its policies in place, its commitment, its practices, its tax restructuring, its capital gains tax, its fringe benefits tax, its massive surplus, the first ever, that has allowed it to fund the recent tax cuts over and above the ones introduced in earlier years, or whether they would prefer the Opposition, which has no policies, no specific tax policies, has nothing but a series of complaints and now promises cuts in health, education and welfare under the new shadow finance Minister, Dr Hewson. I would think that the choice for the people in this country was very clear. I would think that most Australians would say, `We do not believe that Mr Hawke was an idiot to say that no child would live in poverty. We are glad to have a government that makes that sort of commitment on the public record as a priority, as a policy commitment, as a statement of what we will do and what we have willed to do since'.

This Government is saying that poverty and child poverty in this country are not acceptable. We are the people who will address that problem. We are the people who have taken those very significant first steps. Out of the Opposition's mouth, this Government stands condemned for actually helping the bottom 10 per cent of families. I take that as high praise indeed. We are the Government that, since the last Budget, with its promises for tax cuts and increases in family allowances, said in the April statement that those promises will be delivered by 1 July this year. Of the two-the Opposition and the Government-I ask the people of Australia whether they can seriously wonder about the Opposition. The Opposition seems to want to condemn us for having a commitment to reduce and/or alleviate child poverty. Child poverty is not only a matter of income but to the extent that it is a matter of income support, this Government has made its contribution and made its steps clear. If it is a matter of social structuring, education, jobs and health policies, the Government's record is there. While more may remain to be done, the Government's commitment is clear. Its commitment to help women, as with its contribution to assisting families out of poverty, is also on the record.

I would have thought that the choice for the Australian people was not to agree with this ridiculous matter of public importance. While the substance is important, the way it is couched is totally ridiculous and I reject it out of hand. I have no shame-in fact I am proud-that I am part of a government that has a commitment to reduce child poverty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing this matter today not because it was put in terms which Senator Crowley now tries to qualify, terms of commitment and aim, another qualification that we have had to what has already been put forward--

—I rise on a point of order. I have actually quoted precisely and literally what the Prime Minister said and I object very strenuously to being misrepresented by Senator Reid. It is a subtle way of calling me a liar and I object.
—There is no point of order.
—If I may, I will quote from the Hansard of the House of Representatives of 24 May 1989 where Mr Macphee asked the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke):

SPEECH.PARA: Did he, at the launch of the Australian Labor Party's 1987 election campaign, promise that his Government would eliminate child poverty by 1990; if so, what were his exact words.
In his reply the Prime Minister said:
For our next term, we are setting achievable new goals for Australia's future in the world.
And at the head of these goals is the future of all our children.
So we set ourselves this first goal:
By 1990 no Australian child will be living in poverty.

When I heard that on my car radio at the time of the delivery of the policy speech in 1987, I did not have any doubt what he meant. I suspect that most people who heard it thought that he meant what he said and that is the reason we are debating it today. Had he in fact couched those sentiments, which he has put into Hansard, in the way that Senator Crowley referred to them, as commitment and aim, people might have reacted somewhat differently and interpreted his actions somewhat differently.

Senator Crowley went on today to debate the age of children and the age of youth. That is a good academic exercise but what we are really talking about is homelessness in our community. As has been said, the topic we are discussing states:

The need for the Government to take immediate action to reduce the appalling level of poverty and homelessness of Australian youth and to apologize for the Prime Minister's campaign device in promising Government action to ensure that no child would be living in poverty by 1990.
The Prime Minister's original statement has been rephrased and, in Hansard, the Prime Minister, in his answer said:
. . . by 1990 no child will need to live in poverty.

It would be everybody's hope that that would be the case. The Prime Minister, in April this year, brought down the family allowance payments. We do not suggest that they are not necessary or that they should not have been brought down, as seems to have been conveyed by some of the speakers this afternoon. It is interesting to look at the statement put out by the Prime Minister under the heading, `A Fair Deal for Families':
The 1989 economic statement contains major social reforms never before implemented by any government.

He then gave the details of the family allowance payments, and points out that for the first time family payments will be indexed and the child poverty pledge will be met in July 1989. That is perhaps the most outstanding statement of all. After the first statement, which most people had great difficulty believing, in April he said that, having brought in these welcome family allowance supplements and indexing them, he would then merely declare that the child poverty pledge would be met in July 1989. This document from which I am quoting does not say that the commitment and aim will be met in July 1989; it says that the child poverty pledge will be met in July 1989. We know for a fact that it will not be met in July 1989.

The Prime Minister really has little choice but to back down and back away from the pledge he made. He cannot ignore the fact that so many young Australians are continuing to live in poverty and will be living in poverty next year. The important thing for the Government and the Parliament to look at is why that is so and what we are doing to solve it rather than getting excited about the issues put forward by Senator Crowley.

Senator Giles seemed to devote a considerable amount of her time to what she called the abject failure of the coalition when in government. Unfortunately for us, it is now six years since we were in government. I find it remarkable that Labor members of parliament can continue to talk about the previous seven years. We were elected in 1975; that is a long time ago. I would have thought that six years in government would have given them something to talk about, the things that they have done themselves. But somehow it is the abject failure of the coalition that seems to dominate the thoughts of Government senators when they talk on these matters. Something about it really gets to them.

The fact is that anybody in our community who is involved in caring for young homeless children or who is trying to find solutions to the problem could not have been but astonished to have heard the promise before the 1987 election and would have been looking for a great deal more by now. All of us would have wanted to see the promise met. Most of us appreciate the gravity of the problem, and it comes as no surprise to look to 1990, close as we are to it now, and know that the promise has not been met. Senator Walters and others have referred to the recent Australian Broadcasting Corporation program which so graphically put together the facts on this issue.

Whatever the rationale behind the Government's policy of somewhat misinforming the public, it is shameful that the Prime Minister and members of his Government regarded the tragedy of children living in poverty as fair game for winning votes in the 1987 election. I do not think anybody doubts that that was what the Prime Minister was doing at the time. Perhaps he hoped that people would forget it. Perhaps he did not really care whether they believed him. He made the dramatic promise that by 1990 no Australian child would be living in poverty. Of course, we all know how family incomes have suffered during the six years of Labor government. A family in receipt of average weekly earnings is $56 a week worse off because of the taxation policies of this Government. That does not include the well over $2,000 increase in mortgage repayments in the last 12 months, let alone the increases which occurred before then, which affect those families attempting to buy homes.

The problem with child poverty and youth homelessness is that the Government has pursued policies which actually exacerbate the problems. High interest rates, high taxation and high inflation have seriously damaged the ability of middle and low income families to provide for their children in the way in which they want to provide for them. Families are facing very severe financial hardships at present, as is evidenced by the sort of public meetings that are being held in Canberra tonight and in other places.

Senator Crowley seemed to think that we were suggesting that children being driven from homes by violence was associated with poverty. In some instances it is, but we do not for a minute suggest that violence in the domestic situation relates only to poverty. None of us would ever suggest that it does not happen in families that are financially well off. We all know that it does. We know that there are many reasons why families break up and why children go in different directions. Some of them have problems with the blended family relationships which are subsequently established. Most of us have friends with families which in some respects appear perfectly stable. The families may comprise four or five children, one of whom leaves home and becomes a homeless child, while the others do not. It does not have to do merely with money. It is necessary to look at financial issues, but what we are talking about today are the consequences of a breakdown of some kind which results in children leaving families, and the pressures that are placed upon them. I had intended to refer to the comments made by Bishop Owen Dowling. I quoted his comments in the Senate the other day, so I will not refer to them in detail. He commented that the Prime Minister's pledge stretched his credulity. He, too, is a man very much attuned to what is going on in the community.

Some children, of course, who remain in a perfectly stable and quite happy home are living in poverty. To suggest that this occurs only in single parent families flies in the face of reality. Certainly, I can point to two-parent families living in poverty in Canberra because of the financial situation they face at present. The Prime Minister's recent backtracking on his promise was an attempt to imply that no family ought to be in poverty, so long as the parents are not spending the Government's largess at the TAB or on the poker machines. That sort of suggestion is very offensive. It is a gross insult to many thousands of families to suggest that they only find themselves and their children in poverty because of their own mismanagement. That is not the case.

As I, said, the program entitled Nobody's Children put together most adequately the issues that we are talking about. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has produced a report entitled Our Homeless Children. People who have read that report must be much better informed than previously, if they had any doubts about the issue that we are discussing. The Institute of Family Studies has also reported on the problem. The impact on the individual is very great. It takes an enormous toll on the health, self-esteem and opportunities of children who are living in poverty with no hope for the future. Nobody's Children referred to them as a new underclass.

The toll on the rest of the community is great. It results in increased juvenile crime. It has an enormous impact on the health of children. There has been an enormous increase in under-age drinking among those who are homeless. There are reports about increase in brain damage of young Australians who are well below the legal drinking age. There is evidence from Dr Jean Lennane, the Director of Drug and Alcohol Services at the Rozelle Hospital, that there is more alcohol-related brain damage amongst younger Australians than has ever been seen. Such young Australians do not drink because they seek great excitement; they drink out of despair. Young people are drinking to get drunk because they see that they have no future. One 15-year-old boy is quoted as saying, `Drinking is a way to blot out the way I am feeling'. How can we live with ourselves when young people are in that situation? Alcohol is frequently seen by many as a crutch.

It is even more distressing to look at the suicide rate. The Australian Bureau of Statistics released figures last month which show that young Australian males have a suicide rate three times greater than in the 1950s. There were 417 youth suicides in 1987. Of course, that figure does not include deaths due to accidental overdoses or deaths of young people from car accidents, where frequently alcohol is a factor. On cannot simply look at the instances and know whether homelessness or other factors were involved, but the amount of drinking among young homeless people indicates that there is a serious problem. The consequences are enormous.

Sociological and psychiatric studies indicate that for every suicide there may be as many as 100 attempted suicides. Even if the figure were only 50, it would be a tragedy. There is an appalling social cost because young people have no hope for the future. Some of the consequences that we face include the care that they need and the range of mental illnesses from which they may suffer. It is not just a problem in the larger cities; it affects every community. In Canberra about 700 young people spend time in crisis refuges every year. Many others cannot be accommodated. Many turn to petty crime, drug dealing and prostitution to survive. It is a national tragedy; no one would disagree with that. The solution is not merely to declare that it will be wiped out. We need to find suitable education opportunities, jobs and activities which are meaningful for these young people.

Any senators who fail to support the raising of this matter have a very shallow view of the matter. What led us to raise this very important matter today was the callousness of the Prime Minister in making that pledge in 1987 which cannot be met by him. I hope that all senators will support the matter. It is a very genuine message that we need to send to the Prime Minister about the urgency of the problems faced by so many young people, including homeless young people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E. .

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to note the way in which the Opposition senators deal with these problems. They do not attempt to give a factual background to the sort of wild statements that they make; rather, they supply a string of anecdotes to try to grip the heartstrings of those who may be listening to the broadcast of the debate. I am not suggesting that the anecdotes that are trotted out are not in themselves compelling or worthy of great concern and sympathy from all of us. I certainly do not lack such sympathy. But sympathy is no substitute for analysis, policy formulation, long term planning or systematically trying to overcome the problems. In this respect there is a great deal of hypocrisy in the raising of this matter of youth poverty and homelessness in this way. It is not only hypocritical of the Opposition but also politically stupid. It is stupid because, arguably, the record of this Government in the area of youth poverty in particular is among the best records of any government in the history of this country. Youth poverty, of course, is essential to the question of homelessness in any case. There is no way of dealing with the question of homelessness unless one deals first or partly with the question of poverty.

SPEECH.PARA: In contrast, the Opposition's record is abysmal. There is no point in saying, as Senator Reid does, that we should not mention the record of the Opposition when it was in government or the statements that the Opposition makes currently. There is a point because what this shows is a fundamental difference between the attitudes of those on this side of the House and those on the other side of the House. There is a fundamental difference in the care and concern that is shown at the practical end when it comes to divvying up budgets and thinking of policies over the long term. We do not just convey anecdotes, gripping and compelling as they are. We do something about the situation. The Opposition's record, and particularly its recent statements, show that it has made no attempt and does not show any interest in making an attempt to do the same. It shows how bereft of talent and ideas the Opposition is. There is pressing legislation involving the provision of funds and resources for many needy groups, including many provisions for youth, banked up in the Senate waiting to be considered. The Opposition is prepared to waste the Senate's time with fatuous censure motions, such as the one we dealt with this morning, and matters of public importance, such as the one before us, which are not relevant to the general purposes of the Parliament or the Government and add nothing to the stock of human knowledge.

Former speakers have gone into the Government's record in some detail. I will give an overview and summarise the Government's record although a summary is not meant to trivialise this record in any way. The Government introduced the family allowance supplement to lift one million children into security. That and subsidiary proposals have been welcomed by all social security observers and workers in the field as going a long way to achieving the sorts of ends about which the Opposition talks but does very little. The Government has provided rent assistance and a child disability allowance free from means testing. It has introduced indexation of all family related payments, thus preventing the erosion of the real value of payments, in areas such as the family allowance, the family assistance scheme, pensioner and beneficiary children, the dependent spouse rebate, the sole parent rebate, the mothers and guardians allowance, the double orphans pension and the child disability allowance. All of these are firsts. All these areas were indexed to make sure that there was no erosion of the original benefits.

The Government has also implemented tax cuts. Despite what those on the Opposition benches say, the greatest increases in benefits are at the lower end of the tax scale. We have made the tax scale more progressive to assist those in greatest need. It was interesting to hear Senator Knowles talk about punitive marginal taxation rates. In 1983 the lowest tax rate was 30c in the dollar. Nowadays the lowest tax rate is 21c in the dollar. The next rate up was 46c in the dollar; it is now 29c. The next rate was 60c; it is now 39c. The highest rate is 49c, going down to 47c. But most importantly-Senator Knowles would not agree with this-we have made the tax scales more progressive, not less progressive, and the nonsense which she and other speakers raised about an unsubstantiated figure of $56 a week loss in average income--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is $58 now, actually.

—It is $58 now. That unsubstantiated figure was tossed up, I think, by the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock). How does the Opposition arrive at that? I know that there is a conflict between the Liberal Party of Australia and its partner, the National Party of Australia, about many things. But how does that fit with the question which Senator Stone asked Senator Walsh yesterday? He quoted from the Australian Statistician's report:

SPEECH.PARA: In current price, seasonally adjusted terms, wages, salaries and supplements rose by 3.4 per cent in the March quarter 1989, following a rise of 4.5 per cent in the previous quarter . . .
Senator Stone went on to say:
That is, an 8 per cent rise during those six months.
He asked:
Has the total rise in wages, salaries and supplements during the 12 months to March 1989 amounted to no less than 11.7 per cent?

He was saying that there had been a wages blow-out and we should not have allowed it to happen. On the other hand, the Opposition is saying that there are massive losses in income. It does not fit together.

TALK.START.PARA: —As against a Budget projection of 6 per cent. That is the point.

—The Budget projection for this year is 6.5 per cent. The point is that Senator Stone is making out that those rises have occurred and the Opposition is making out that they have not. That is the fundamental difference. To return to the Government record: under this Government there has been an abolition of the six-week delay in the indexation of pensions and benefits and the bringing forward of those indexation benefits by another six weeks. Prospective supplementary payments for low paid workers have been introduced. There has been improved training and income support for sole parents and the long-term unemployed. Child support arrangements have been upgraded and there has been an improvement in general terms in employment levels. The Government's record in this area is second to none. This Government is applauded all over the world as one that is achieving employment growth at twice the rate of Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries in general.

SPEECH.PARA: One does not have to believe me or the Government, because we are likely to have an interest in trumpeting our achievements. I draw the Senate's attention to a couple of statements, one of which was quoted before. I think that it deserves to be quoted once again. The statements were made by independent observers, not observers who are easy to get along with from the Government's point of view-in fact they are constant critics of the policies which we bring down. Referring to the whole family allowance arrangement and particularly the April statement which brought that to final fruition, the Brotherhood of St Laurence stated:
This pledge, the most specific social commitment of the century-
get that!-
has been the subject of a historic package to provide a guaranteed minimum income for poor children . . .
It went on to say:

We congratulate the Federal Government on its work on child poverty, which represents a historic breakthrough in the national attack on child poverty. The Federal Government has now built a solid foundation of income security for Australian families.
The Brotherhood of St Laurence is a very cogent critic of every government's policies, and no less of this Government's policies. Bishop Peter Hollingworth said:

In strict income security terms, it is true that the Prime Ministerial promise ``that no children shall live in poverty by 1990'' . . . will be achieved. This represents significant progress, and demonstrates that governments can meet some modest social justice objectives, even at a time of economic restraint when they are involved in public sector cutbacks and tax reduction in order to improve their economic efficiency.
The Australian Institute of Family Studies, which again is a very difficult critic and one whose people are not easily convinced by government policies but were convinced by the package, said:

The package appears to redress the erosion of family incomes since 1976 through tax bracket creep and the failure to index family benefits. The indexation of family benefits is an historically significant feature which will ensure that these payments will not be eroded in the future.
On the Institute's analysis of the Government's package 70% of families will gain more than $1000 per annum.
48% of the cost of the package goes to the 30% of households which include dependent children.

The Government has, in addressing family poverty, addressed the question of youth poverty. But enough of the Government's record of which I am proud and for which I do not apologise. Let us look at the Opposition's record and what it currently stands for. The only adjustments in payments that were made during the Opposition's time in office for low income families were as follows: in 1980 it raised payments from $7.50 to $10. In 1976 the Opposition cashed out tax rebates for children into the family allowance and, in doing so, cut total assistance for the first child from $4.50 a week to $3.50 a week. In 1982 the parties now in opposition increased family allowance for the first child to $5.25, a net nominal increase of 75c in seven years. That occurred against the backdrop of a blow-out in labour costs when they lost control of the economy because they did not have a wages policy, and against the backdrop of an explosion of unemployment. What gains were made were very quickly lost.

More cogently and more recently the Federal Opposition, at the 1987 election, effectively made a commitment to cut all benefits for under 18-year-olds. How will that help youth unemployment? The Opposition said that it would cut the dole for under-18s. It said it would introduce a special youth training wage which would be much lower than the current wage and it said it would introduce work for the dole for anyone over 19. I fail to see how any of those proposals will assist poverty.

It is no different now. In the Peacock regime, the shadow Treasurer, Dr Hewson, has made a commitment to cut welfare, education and health payments. How, on the one hand, can we be highly fiscally responsible, as Dr Hewson is saying we must be, and cut the big budget items of health, welfare and education and, on the other hand, expect to do more for the youth of the country in greatest need? The Opposition is trying to have it both ways. No amount of bluster and no exercises in the petty semantics of what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) did or did not say will hide the fact that the Opposition's position is hypocritical. It talks about savagely cutting outlays, although as yet it has not-and I doubt that it will-specifically identified where those cuts in outlays will occur. Given its record, they will occur in the neediest areas; they will not affect its supporters-the well to do, those with silver spoons in their mouths, the North Shore brigade or, in Perth terms, the Dalkeith set. They will get their assistance and their perks. There will be no means tests and no targeting. It will cut broadly, in the way that it always has, and hurt those most in need. I cannot see how that will help youth poverty or, for that matter, youth homelessness.

On the one hand the Opposition talks about cutting outlays and on the other it talks about a sort of cargo cultism. I simply cannot match those two together. It believes that there is some sort of magical way of producing revenue to meet all the various demands. It wants to increase expenditure in almost every area. At Question Time we get a constant barrage of questions about why we are cutting in certain areas and how we should be increasing expenditure in other areas. Yet we have this talk of cutting outlays, particularly in the areas that will hurt the people that the Opposition is addressing in this matter of public importance. I do not apologise for the statement made by the Prime Minister. I do not apologise for the Government's record. It stands up extremely well in contrast to the Opposition's record and the Opposition's recent statements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

—by leave-Today's debate has been very interesting if nothing else, particularly to hear the Government's position on this very important issue of child poverty. Senator Giles and Senator Crowley did not even have the courtesy to stay in the chamber to find out what the Opposition was putting forward in this debate. I find it absolutely amazing that six years after the Government has assumed power it is still harping and carping about former coalition governments. If, God forbid, the Australian Labor Party were to be in government for the next 50 years, it would still go back and cry about the Fraser years. When will it take responsibility for its initiatives? Senator Crowley was totally rude and abusive and could not debate the substance of the whole issue. The statement that domestic violence occurred only in high income families is one of the most outrageous we have ever heard.
—She said that domestic violence occurred only in such families?

—Yes, Senator Crowley said that domestic violence occurred only in high income families. Senator Beahan was almost as outrageous. He had obviously written his speech-not all that carefully, I might add-before he even bothered to listen to the debate. He said that the matter of public importance that we were discussing here this afternoon `was not relevant to this Parliament'. What is more relevant than ensuring that people, particularly children, are not living in poverty? Senator Beahan went on-once again harping back-to say that the tax rates during the Fraser years were nowhere near what they are today. Dead right: they were nowhere near what they are today. But he failed to mention the effect of bracket creep. A cynic might say that `Bracket Creep' is currently in Paris. As I mentioned before, Labor's policies will, in two years, see two-thirds of Australian taxpayers paying tax at the top marginal rate. The alternative that we are offering, and that we and the Government should be looking at, requires attention to housing, employment and education. We should not just act as born-again concerned politicians in this absolutely important issue. People should not have cheap political tricks played, at their expense, by a Prime Minister who is simply looking to win a vote at any given opportunity. Today's debate has really shown the Government's true colours. It does not care.
—Order! The time for consideration of the matter of public importance has expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: CODE OF CONDUCT FOR AUSTRALIAN COMPANIES WITH INTERESTS IN THE REPUBLIC OF SOUTH AFRICA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The report on the Code of Conduct for Australian Companies with Interests in the Republic of South Africa, which we have just received, is an interesting report. It is the second report under the Code of Conduct for Australian Companies with Interests in the Republic of South Africa. Mr Bannerman, in his report, brings to our attention the fact that there are now only seven Australian companies in South Africa, employing about 740 black workers. He makes the point that this interest in South Africa is tiny by comparison with the United Kingdom, the United States and other countries. Of course, compared with the South African economy itself, it is minute. In fact, he reminds us that South Africa's population is already more than twice ours. So we are looking at seven Australian companies to which this report refers, in a country with greater than twice the population of Australia.

He raises the interesting question of whether the code is serving a worthwhile purpose and whether it need continue, not only because of the very few companies involved under it but also because of growing evidence that questions the value of such codes within the South African economic environment. He says in the report that industry groupings at the peak level tend to see the codes as obsolescent and having mainly domestic value for the home countries of the companies concerned. Perhaps we should think about that. Unions at the peak level do not believe in codes but rather in what they can achieve themselves.
