SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade is very important. The state of our mine countermeasures capability is very disturbing. I have been drawing attention to this deficiency in our defence capability for many years. In my view the Navy has been far too interested, far too involved, in programs to defend merchant ships on the high seas against submarine attack-which to my mind is a very unlikely eventuality, bearing in mind that 95 per cent of the ships carrying our trade are foreign-flag vessels-and has ignored the very real danger of our ports being made inoperative by mines. Mines can be laid by submarines or aircraft or, clandestinely, from surface merchant ships. These are common ways for relatively low technological warfare to be waged. One only has to look at recent experiences in the Red Sea, the Persian Gulf and Nicaragua to see how effective this type of campaign can be. It must be tackled. We must have the capability to deal with this in our ports. In my mind, it is the most likely low level threat that we will have.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say a few words about the nature of the mine warfare problem. There are two types of mines-moored mines or buoyant mines, and ground mines, which are not normally buoyant but lie on the seabed. Moored mines or buoyant mines are the oldest type of mine normally operated by running into them or colliding with them. The method of dealing with them is to use mechanical sweeps to cut their mooring wire. They then come to the surface where they can be destroyed. Ground mines, which are normally only effective down to about 90 metres, lie on the seabed and may be activated magnetically by the magnetic signature of the ship, acoustically by its noise or by its pressure pattern, or by a combination of these. Once activated, a large explosive very seriously damages the bottom of the ship. To make them more complicated, these ground mines can be fitted with delay mechanisms, a time delay, so that they do not become active and, therefore, cannot be swept for any amount of time. They may also be given a period delay mechanism so that they have to be activated a certain number of times-say, 10 times-before they go up. So the area can be swept nine times and be thought to be clear, and the tenth time a ship goes through up the mine goes. It is a very difficult problem to deal with.

Another type of mine is the rising or homing mine, which I do not think that we should concern ourselves with at the moment. That is really a ground mine which is capable of operating at much greater depths. When activated it either rises on its own buoyancy, having been tethered to the bottom, or homes on the ship above. These are high technology mines which are only in the hands of the big powers at the moment and, for technical reasons, are not very likely to be used in our waters.

How do we deal with these types of mines? There are two basic solutions. One is mine sweeping. We can either tow a mechanical sweep which cuts the mooring wire of the buoyant moored mines or undertake influence sweeps which give out a magnetic signature like a ship and, therefore, causes the mine to go up or make a noise like a ship which makes the mine go up. Of course, pressure is much more difficult to simulate, therefore mine sweeping is never going to be a complete answer. We also have to go in for mine hunting which normally uses sonar to locate the mines on the bottom of the sea and identify them from among the debris on the bottom of the sea. Having located the mines lying on the seabed, one uses either a remote control vessel or clearance diving swimmers to deactivate them. It is a very difficult problem.

What do we have in this country to deal with this? At the moment, we have one old clapped-out coastal mine sweeper, two experimental mine hunting vessels and three clearance diving teams. That is pitifully inadequate for what we need. It is not that there is not a very great deal of highly devoted work going on in this field; what is being achieved is very impressive. But that is what we have at the moment. What do we need? First of all, we do need mine sweepers to clear large areas quickly. There has been a very imaginative program called the craft of opportunity program to take up vessels such as fishing trawlers, fit them with equipment and make them suitable as mine sweepers. The imaginative part of this program-and it is a very great breakthrough in the technology made in this country-is to avoid the necessity in most mine sweepers of having very high power outputs to create the necessary magnetic field or acoustic field in order to detonate the mine. Our designers have managed to produce towed arrays which can take a magnetic signature or an acoustic signature without external power supplies. This is a very great advance. The idea is that we will have a number of these craft of opportunity outfits or equipment. We will get them in when needed and they will be manned by naval reserves, which gives the reserves a very sensible and useful role. This is very imaginative and is going to be a very successful program. But they cannot do mine hunting. As I said at the outset, mine sweeping will never do all that is needed.

We are in real trouble in mine hunting. We have two experimental fibreglass catamarans. They are of very interesting design, but they have great problems. One is that their sonar does not work. With current plans, it does not seem that it will be working before the mid-1990s. Also, the ones that we have got were designed for inshore work and have very poor seakeeping characteristics. They cannot go to sea in rough weather; they are only suitable inshore. An example quoted in the report is that the type of limiting weather is that experienced in Gage Roads during the America's Cup races. If it were any worse than that, the mine hunting inshore (MHIs) could not operate. That is really a problem. We do need very urgently larger mine hunting vessels that can go to sea in reasonable weather. The Committee recommends-and I think it is very conservative-that we should aim to have three smaller MHIs and four larger mine hunting vessels. Of course, that is dependent on getting the MHIs to work-particularly getting the sonar to work, and possibly fitting a different one.

We also need what are called precursors. One cannot put these mine clearance vessels through a mine field and allow them to be blown up, because they tow their arrays. The mine hunters can do it, but the mine sweepers cannot. There were experiments done with precursor sweeps by helicopters, which I think is the most attractive way of doing it. That appears to have been abandoned in favour of having drone boats doing it, which are radio controlled boats. That seems to have got logistically out of control because none of the mine hunting vessels can carry the drone boats. Some rethinking has to be done there. I agree with the Committee that we must come back to helicopters, as the obvious way of doing the precursor sweeps, to clear the way for the mine sweepers and the mine hunters.

One final point I make concerns a curious omission from the report. All mine clearing and mine hunting vessels must themselves be as safe as possible from mines. They are normally what is called degaussed to counter their magnetic signature and normally have specially mounted quiet machinery to reduce their noise. That is automatic with any mine countermeasure vessels. There used to be a system in this country where all Australian registered ships were fitted with degaussing gear to eliminate their magnetic signature and make them much safer from mines in shallow waters. That program should reactivated. It is the most serious problem facing us. Nothing can be done about foreign flag ships, but our own ships should be made as safe as possible from it. It is the most important untackled task facing the Australian Defence Force. There is a great deal of dedication, knowledge and skill which this Government has not yet motivated or organised in the right direction. The problems are immense. If we cannot clear our minefields in the face of a low level threat, foreign flag ships just will not come here. This country would be economically crippled by a handful of mines laid by people with a low technological capability. It is crucial that this problem be tackled and tackled fast.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report on the Priorities for Australia's Mine Countermeasure Needs was formally tabled last week by me as Deputy Chairman of the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in this chamber. It is the third major report of the Defence subcommittee in the Thirty-fifth Parliament. As a former academic, I would be quite confident in claiming that the academic standards of those three reports more than satisfy the requirements of a PhD thesis in one of the humanities. They are certainly up to textbook standard. To produce three reports of this nature within the two years of the Parliament is a great credit to my colleagues on that Committee. I will take a moment to formally thank my colleagues on that Committee. I thank the Chairman, the members of the Committee-some of whom are in this chamber at present-the Secretary, Alan Stephens, who performed with his usual brilliance and dedication. He was assisted by Dr Derek Woolner from the Parliamentary Library. I would also like to thank the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and the Department of Defence. I thank the Navy, particularly the Defence Science and Technology Organisation for the help it gave the Committee through this inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: The terms of reference broadly dealt with the capabilities that Australia has in the mine countermeasures field and the likelihood of attacks, and the way we should oppose them. One of the tragic things about mine warfare and, therefore, mine countermeasures, is that there is no public interest in it. It is not a glamorous subject; it is quite unfashionable. It has a poor public image, but it is incredibly important for Australia, and Australia is a very vulnerable country for mine warfare. It is important that we have the countermeasures to cope with that. There is a belief about also that it is a very basic level of technology. That is true. A very basic level of technology can be involved in warfare and we saw that in the Iran-Iraq war where mines were used that had been built for the Tsar's Russia before the revolution in 1917. They sat in warehouses for all those years and were successfully deployed in the Persian Gulf. Those mines were quite devastating something like 70 years after they had been made. Mine warfare also involves the leading edge of technology. We can get to the stage where some mines literally are quite unsweepable. It is very secret technology. I have spent most of my time in this Parliament with a major interest in defence. One can find out quite a lot about the electronic systems, the radar systems, the fire control systems, and the weapons systems that exist in the Services if one makes an effort to read the technical journals. There is very little information in the literature on mine warfare and the latest generation of mines. The countries that produce mines simply are not ready to exchange that information unless they can trade it for comparable information.

Mines come in a variety of forms. They can be moored on the bottom-the ground mines-or they can lie on the bottom. One can swim them into harbours or into approach paths. They can be on the bottom and one can swim them to the site of operation. They can be detonated in a whole variety of ways: by contact with ships bumping into them, by magnetic radiation from a ship-the magnetic signature-by the noise radiating from a ship or from the pressure of a ship passing over. All sorts of permutations and combinations are possible on that triggering device. A ship can pass over a mine 30 or 40 times and on the forty-first time it can be programmed to detonate. It can be programmed to detonate on a particular noise or magnetic signature, for one particular ship out of a whole class of ships. It can be an extraordinarily sophisticated business. I come back to the point I made a little while ago, that mine countermeasures work is slow, painstaking and unglamorous. It never gets on the front pages of the newspapers. The only thing I can compare it to is the work of an Army infantry scout patrolling in close country. It is the same sort of slow, unspectacular, painstaking work with violent death always near.

Mines have been used since 1776 when George Washington used them in the War of Independence against the British. Large numbers were used in World War I, World War II, Korea, Vietnam, the Red Sea and the Persian Gulf. The characteristics of mining procedures are that they can be involved at relatively low cost. The capability can be acquired easily by technologically backward nations, and all sorts of platforms can be used to sow mines. The fact that mines are sown, produces a quite disproportionate response in the country's waters in which they are sown. It is also very difficult to prove who sowed those mines. We can prove where the mines were manufactured in some cases, but unless we catch the person redhanded, it is difficult, if not impossible, to prove who laid them. The final point about mine warfare is that if someone declares that a minefield has been sown, it effectively closes that harbour because the host nation has to go out and physically prove that there are no mines present.

The relevance of this to Australia is that we are one of the great trading nations of the world, and well over 90 per cent of our trade moves by sea. We are extraordinarily vulnerable at present because we have no practical countermeasures against mining. It will take us some years to acquire that. This is in the face of stated priorities by the Navy and the Department of Defence over many years that mine countermeasures were of the highest priority to the Australian defence industry. After at least 10 years on the mine hunter program, we have no capability whatsoever. How do mine countermeasures come about? Very broadly, there are two procedures: there is the sweeping procedure and the hunting procedure. It depends on the nature of the mine that is being sought. With the sweeping procedure, we can either mechanically sweep the moored mines or we can use influence sweeps to emit a magnetic pressure, or noise signature. In the hunting operation, where the mines are on the bottom and have different triggering devices perhaps, we have to go out to find the mines because they lie on the bottom. We have to look at the bottom. We can put human beings down there-clearance divers-to look at them, but it is a very slow and limited operation. We can put television cameras in little submersible, remotely piloted vehicles, or we can use sonar, the projection of sound waves which is the mass screening process. But that process is enormously slow. It is tedious and it is very high technology.

Australia has no mine sweeping capability at present with the retirement of HMAS Curlew. The Navy and the Department have been quite innovative in developing the craft of opportunity (COOP) vessels. Suitable large fishing trawlers are modified for the towing role. The Defence Science and Technology Organisation has developed the mini-dyad program. It has developed a towed magnetic and acoustic emitter which uses very little power but which generates the necessary signals. It is a world first for Australia. It has been very successful. We have the capability in hand of developing good mine sweeping capabilities in the short term. But in the mine hunting field, the history is one of failure. The very first recommendation of the Committee is that we abandon the mine hunter inshore program with its COOP sonar DSQS-11H sonar which simply will not work and buy or lease one of the Thomson-CSF sonars, or one of the proven sonars that actually work.

The major criticism of this report rests with Navy for having persisted with the mine hunter inshore program in the face of demonstrable failure. Navy is to be commended for the craft of opportunity program and for the emitters that have gone with that. It is to be commended for being innovative in developing the inshore hunter with its catamaran hull and its COOP sonar. But after the expenditure of over $100m and nearly 10 years on this mine hunter program, we have a sonar which simply will not work and will never work. No-one in the Navy has had the courage to stand up and say that this will not work. While I am attributing blame, the Minister must take blame for this too. Mr Beazley in many ways is similar to Mr Keating who is supposed to be the world's best Treasurer. Mr Beazley has known that the program has been a failure for the six years that the Labor Government has been in power and no-one has done anything about it.
In conclusion, this is the highest priority we have in the defence field. This country can be held to ransom until we can demonstrate that we have the capability to clear our own harbours of mines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is another report from the subcommittee of the Joint Committee of Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade which has been so ably led, in my view, by Mr Manfred Cross and by his deputy, Senator MacGibbon. Each report that they have brought down to the Parliament has been very important and worthy of serious consideration. This is yet another one. Unfortunately, the Government in the past has shown little inclination to make meaningful responses. The Navy effectively has no capability to deal with mines laid in Australian waters. Mr Manfred Cross, in a speech in the other place, said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the Joint Committee's judgment that, in the prevailing strategic climate, the use of sea mines represents one of the most likely threats to Australia's security and trade. It is a threat which is equally applicable across the range of conflicts, from low level contingencies, through to escalated low level conflict, and up to more substantial conflict.

We have to take this report in the context of imports and exports and to remember it in that light. In 1986-87, 78 per cent of our imports and 86 per cent of our exports travelled by sea. Any attempt to harass our trade will have wide ranging and serious implications for Australia's economy, which has already been damaged so badly by this Government. The neglect in the area of dealing with mines is yet another example of this Government's failure to look after this country.

An effective mine hunting capability is central to our mine countermeasure force and priority should be given to acquiring craft of opportunity platforms for mine sweeping operations. This is one of the recommendations of the Committee with which I personally agree. The program has been a mess. It is approximately 15 years since the catamaran project-the mine hunters-was first proposed, yet there is not yet an operational vessel. In 1983 the expenditure which was approved for the two prototype mine hunter inshore was $53m. By 1987-88 the expenditure had already topped $82.6m. It is expected that for each additional vessel the cost will be $86m. In addition, we have the debacle of the sonar system, which is still not satisfactory. A great deal more effort and cost will be needed before it satisfies the requirements of the Navy. The serious implications of this relate not just to money and wasted time but also to the lack of decision-making within the Department and the Navy in that an alternative sonar system is available. No decision has yet been made to purchase it, although it has been facing the Navy and the Department for a considerable time.

The mine countermeasures program has within it a typical example of the lack of concern which this Government has shown to its servicemen-a subject which I have drawn to the attention of honourable senators on many occasions. I would like to quote from page xxi of the report under the heading `Personnel'. Mr Cross's Committee says:

Equipment without people represents only half of the defence capability equation. It is essential to remember that the lead time for recruiting and training people to operational standard can be at least as long as that needed to acquire equipment. The retention of a skilled personnel base is fundamental if Australia is to regain an effective MCM capability.

The Committee is concerned by the high loss rate from the ADF of MCM specialists. We believe that the recommendations made regarding job satisfaction in our 1988 report on personnel wastage are particularly relevant, as is the recommendation in this report on reviving, the mine hunting element of the force.

There speaks a very sad Committee which has just seen the Government virtually turn its major report on losses of Australia's defence force personnel into a little side issue in the defence debate. The failure of the Government to come to terms with the desperate need for meaningful measures to stem the losses from the Defence Force is a disgrace.

When I visited HMAS Waterhen recently there were several matters I found relating to personnel which the Parliament should be aware of. For instance, the craft of opportunity minesweepers-commonly known as COOPs-are a brilliant idea for a defence force with scarce dollars to spend and a capability to acquire. Yet there are not enough bunks for a crew crewing those vessels. In other words, they are hot bunking. One man gets out and another man gets in. Surely that is pretty unsatisfactory in today's Navy if we want to retain those people as professionals in a professional force.

Then we have the question of allowances. The men on these minesweepers are still waiting for a meaningful seagoing allowance. When I visited them I spoke to them about such matters. I was told how a number of them have come from other vessels to the COOPs and immediately had their seagoing allowance rate dropped. I asked a question about this in the Estimates Committee hearings. I was told that the long range plan is to use permanent and reserve force personnel. Currently, they are permanent personnel. Senator Hamer mentioned earlier that the plan is to use reserve force personnel but the answer I got was that it would use a mixture. The Navy told me that it is investigating the matter to determine whether there are sufficient grounds to justify payment of the full rate of seagoing allowance to the crews of these COOPs. The investigation, which has already taken a devil of a time, has so far revealed sufficient evidence to justify placing the crews of these vessels on the same footing as those of torpedo recovery vessels and other general purpose vessels-that is, at a lower rate of seagoing allowance. Anybody of a fair mind who visited these COOPs-they are converted fishing boats with a lot of extra equipment put into them so that there are minimal facilities for the crew and minimum space to sit, stand and sleep-would expect that they should be entitled to the highest level of seagoing allowance. They are making a major contribution, increasing the defence capability of this nation, and yet they are paying for it.

The other difficulty that the COOP program is facing is that it is having difficulty finding COOPs of sufficient seagoing quality to enable them to be included in the project. That is because the fishing vessels around the coast which have licences make it far too expensive for the Navy to acquire them for its fleet. Proprietors of vessels are unwilling to lease them to the Navy while they hold these valuable fishing licences. I would have thought that would have been something that could have been worked out before the project got under way. It seems to have been a bit of a bungle from go to whoa.

This whole story of mine countermeasures and our lack of capability is a sorry tale of woe, as anybody who has read the report of the Committee will verify. I believe it is yet another example of bungling in the Department of Defence, bungling presided over by a Minister who is not interested in the management of his Department. He is interested in the honour and glory. He is interested in the shiny toys and being photographed sitting in FA18s. I do not think he is very interested is seeing that his Department runs properly. We have heard criticism in this place recently about the Department's inability to be accountable to this Parliament. We have had further examples of the bungling of the Department in its failure to come to a decision on the armoured fighting vehicles. Just like the mine countermeasures arrangements, interminable discussions have gone on year after year.

There are 13 recommendations in this report. Surely Mr Beazley should be able to cope with only 13 recommendations. It should not be beyond his ability to do something about this report. I believe that Mr Cross's Committee has done the nation a favour yet again by telling us the awful details concerning the management of Australia's defence. Perhaps this time the Government will take action.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON MIGRATION REGULATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a joint select committee be appointed to-
(a) consider regulations proposed by the Minister under the Migration Act 1958 which prescribe decision criteria for the grant of visas and entry permits; and
(b) examine whether those regulations:
(i) reflect current and announced policies in relation to the grant of visas and entry permits as at 1 June 1989, and
(ii) lead to outcomes which would be consistent with those achieved under the policies referred to in subparagraph 1 (b) (i).

(2) That the committee consist of 10 members, 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips, 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 1 Senator to be nominated by any minority group or groups or independent Senator or independent Senators.
(3) That every nomination of a member of the committee be forthwith notified in writing to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
(4) That the committee elect a government member as its chairman.

(5) That the committee elect a deputy-chairman who shall act as a chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee, and at any time when the chairman and deputy-chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee the members present shall elect another member to act as chairman at that meeting.
(6) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the chairman, or the deputy-chairman when acting as chairman, have a casting vote.
(7) That 5 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee.
(8) That the committee have power in relation to its functions to send for persons, papers and records.
(9) That-

(a) in respect of proposed regulations received from the Minister before 31 October 1989 the committee shall furnish its observations to the Minister before 21 November 1989 and report to each House of Parliament within 5 sitting days of the tabling of those regulations; and

(b) in respect of proposed regulations received by the committee after 31 October 1989 the committee shall furnish its observations to the Minister within 56 days (unless the Minister declares the regulation urgent, in which case it shall be 28 days) and shall report to both Houses of Parliament within 5 sitting days of the tabling of those regulations.
(10) That the Committee cease upon the dissolution or expiration of the House of Representatives.
(11) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.
(12) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution be communicated by Message to the House of Representatives with a request for the concurrence of that House in the resolution.

I will not speak to the motion at length other than to say that, since the passage of the Migration Amendment Bill last night, over the next 18 months a variety of regulations will be produced by the Department of Immigration which will put in place what were previously ministerial directives in the form of regulations so that they become binding as a decision of law. I circulated the terms of reference as widely as I could. I understand that Senator Alston will be moving two amendments, which we have discussed, and I find those amendments acceptable. This is, of course, a select committee dealing with a very narrow range of subjects. It may well be that, in a year or two, this select committee once it has completed that task, will become a standing committee on immigration generally, that is, a joint standing committee of the Parliament to look at all immigration issues. We will see how the committee develops as a select committee for the purpose for which it is set up.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the Minister's cooperation in the establishment of the committee. I endorse his remarks about the hopes and aspirations we have for that committee. I seek leave to move the two amendments that have been circulated in the name of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Paragraph (1), leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:

``That a joint select committee, to be known as the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations, be appointed to inquire into and report upon the extent to which draft regulations and tabled regulations under the Migration Act 1958, which relate to decision criteria for the grant of visas and entry permits:
(a) reflect current and announced policies in relation to the grant of visas and entry permits as at 1 June 1989; and
(b) are likely to achieve the goals of the policies referred to in subparagraph (a).''.

(2) Paragraph (5), leave out ``That the committee elect a deputy chairman'', insert ``That the committee elect a non-government Senator or member of the House of Representatives to be the deputy chairman''.

The first amendment merely formalises the name of the Committee as the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations and tidies up some of the earlier language without changing any of the spirit of it. The second amendment gives effect to what I think is a widespread convention relating to office-bearers of committees of the Senate: that is, to provide that the deputy chairman of the committee be a non-government member of either the House of Representatives or the Senate. That is the practice. I am sure that it works effectively. I understand that the Government has no objection to that. Therefore I hope that this committee can operate in the normal manner, carry out some very useful and constructive work, and, hopefully, facilitate the workings of the new Migration Act.
Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I apologise for doing this at this late hour but I, too, have some Australian Democrat amendments to move to the motion to establish a joint select committee on migration regulations. I would like them to be circulated at this stage.
—Are you moving the amendments?

—I regret that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) and Senator Alston have not had time to consider them. Perhaps it would be pertinent to delay debate while they have time to consider them, if that is in order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-If Senator Jenkins is referring to the amendment that would omit paragraph 9 and substitute four additional sub-paragraphs, I have had an opportunity to consider the matter. It may be helpful if I indicate the approach of the Opposition. Essentially, the Australian Democrats proposal is to substitute the present scheme, as proposed in the Government's motion, for one that would involve a reporting to the Parliament before the reporting to the Minister. That was something that initially attracted us. I have discussed it with my colleagues and with the Democrats. The view that we take-I think it is shared by the Government-is that it is desirable that there be an opportunity for flexibility and negotiation and that in the first instance the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations should be in a position to approach the Minister without having a fixed position and be able to canvass the desirable form of the regulations. If that is done the Government will be obliged to respond in a formal manner by tabling the regulations and at that stage the Committee would also have an opportunity to acquaint the Senate and the public at large as to its formal position.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that is a much more flexible and sensible approach to take, otherwise the Committee will find itself locked into tendering formal advice to the Parliament which might then limit its opportunity to have discussions with the Minister, even in a public relations sense, because if it is already on the record as having said one thing, it might then have second thoughts and want to proceed in another way. We do not think that makes for sensible decision making. We take the view that it is desirable that the process be in four parts: that the Minister proposes draft regulations to the Committee; the Committee then comments on those proposals to the Minister; the Minister then formally tables the regulations; and the Committee then formally reports to the Parliament. If that procedure is adopted we think it will strike the necessary balance between flexibility and formality and that it will provide a much better opportunity to arrive at the right decision. Whilst I can understand the concern of the Democrats that the Minister should not be given preferential treatment, given the fact that there is an obvious requirement for the Minister to table the regulations, which can then be disallowed by the Senate, if necessary, on the basis of the advice tendered by the Committee, we think that all the safety valves are in place and that that is a much more desirable approach to adopt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Paragraph (9), leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:
(9) That-

(a) when proposed regulations are received from the Minister before 31 October 1989, the committee make an interim report to each House of the Parliament, before the first sitting day in December 1989 of that House, on the proposed regulations; and

(b) when proposed regulations are received from the Minister after 31 October 1989, the committee make an interim report to each House of the Parliament before the first sitting day of that House that is 56 days after the proposed regulations are received by the committee; and

(c) when regulations under the Migration Act 1958, which relate to decision criteria for the grant of visas and entry permits are tabled in each House of the Parliament, the committee report to each House of the Parliament not later than 5 sitting days of that House after those regulations are tabled; and

(d) when the Minister urgently refers proposed regulations to the committee, make an interim report to each House of the Parliament, if each House is sitting on that day, not later than the day that is 28 days after receiving the proposed regulations, or otherwise as soon as possible.

The Australian Democrats believe that paragraph 9 of the motion as it stands creates an ominous precedent. The trouble is that Senator Ray's proposal is entirely in keeping with the provisions contained in the migration legislation which vest undue power and discretion in the Executive. The Government proposes that the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations report to the Minister. That has the effect of requiring the Committee to give the Minister its observations before communicating with the Parliament. Committees can give Ministers observations at any time. I hope that this Committee will certainly do so. I believe this Committee will have to work closely with the Minister on many occasions. But if the Minister wants to know how the Committee feels about his proposed regulations, the Democrats believe that it would be better for him to know formally at the same time as the Parliament is formally informed, because there will have been negotiations with the Minister beforehand. In fact, the danger is that Senator Ray's proposal may create a unique situation to the effect that a committee of the Parliament communicates its view formally to the Government before communicating it to the Parliament. As I said, this may create an ominous precedent. It will mean that at least those 10 parliamentarians on the Committee are liable to be inculcated with the notion that such a thing is normal parliamentary practice. I do not believe that it is normal.

In time, the terms of reference of other committees may well be altered to reflect this new, more efficient or expedient standard of reporting. The word `efficiency' was used frequently during last night's debate on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill. If this happens, parliamentary committees can thereby become instruments of the Executive or mere working parties of the Executive, and their membership conscripted to serve the Minister's interests and not the Parliament's. All parliamentary committees, first and foremost, owe their loyalty and commitment to the Parliament. It is possibly not surprising that if the Executive wants total control of the migration process, it should also seek as much control as possible over the parliamentary committee. Paragraph 9 of the Minister's motion certainly helps to do that. It is appreciated that the committee is being set up as a parliamentary committee. Obviously it will be a very useful committee because there will be so many regulations in conjunction with the migration legislation. The Democrats believe that it is therefore all the more important that the Committee shall be seen to be responsible directly to the Parliament, not to the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not realised how devious I had been. It never occurred to me that this was a device to strengthen the Executive. If I had wanted to strengthen Executive control over immigration decisions, I would never have moved to put decisions in regulations that were open to scrutiny by Parliament. I would have used the existing powers of the Act and continued to issue ministerial directives willy-nilly without any senator being able to say boo to a goose about them. It is not a conspiracy theory.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Jenkins totally underrates the personnel who will make up this Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations if she thinks they will be my lackeys. The legislation that we considered last night is designed to move immigration under the control of this Parliament, where it has never been before, by issuing regulations which have the effect of law, that are binding and are reviewable by this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I concur entirely with the views of my colleague Senator Alston with regard to flexibility of discussion with the Minister before any members of the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations are locked into a position. I also concur with the Minister that this is a concession by the Executive with regard to the precise wording of the regulations. It is not just that there is a check, that the regulations express current immigration policy; but also, as has been expressed in debate, there should be sufficient flexibility of procedure for ministerial discretion to be exercised in special circumstances. The essential concept is that knowledge is power. The ability of the 10 members of the Committee to have prior discussions in this way is exactly the concession which the Opposition sought and which the Government has given. I believe there is good faith in the arrangements that are before us in respect of the negotiations that others have referred to during recent weeks and during debate on the legislation yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: I attended a luncheon today for the launch of His Excellency Professor Gordon Reid's book on the history of this Parliament. I sat opposite a distinguished former senator, a former President of the Senate, Sir Magnus Cormack. He recalled how he had advocated, but without success, in the latter part of the 1960s, a procedure for managers to deal with differences of view between the Senate and the House of Representatives-that is, between the House in which the Government has a majority and the House in which it does not have a majority. This procedure is followed by the United States Congress and by the Parliament in my State of South Australia. I commend our informal arrangements regarding managers. My colleague Senator Alston referred to the dialogue which will take place between the Committee and the Minister. That is part of that general field of operation. I am not unmindful of Senator Jenkins's reference to parliamentary committees in the main reporting to the Parliament first. In some cases it would be unthinkable-for example, for the Privileges Committee, and indeed most standing committees-that it would be anything other than the Committee which received a reference from this chamber reporting back to this chamber. The Committee's terms of reference have been set out and I concur that the Opposition and the Government ought to support them fully.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has happened is that this chamber, during its last debate on the Wheat Marketing Bill, carried a large number of amendments which the coalition parties believe-and we were supported by the Australian Democrats-would have substantially improved the Wheat Marketing Bill. The Bill as amended by this chamber was taken to the House of Representatives and the Government rejected in effect all of those amendments in substance. It has agreed to some of the minor amendments, but the amendments of substance have been rejected by the Government. The Government has now brought the Wheat Marketing Bill back to this chamber asking that we do not insist upon the large number of amendments which we carried on the last occasion the Bill came before us.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's agenda on the Wheat Marketing Bill has not been to the benefit of the wheat growers of Australia; it has been that of playing politics in an attempt, in some way or other, to divide the coalition parties. I make it very clear at the outset that the coalition parties have accepted the deregulation of the domestic wheat market. Let me explain what I mean by deregulation. By deregulation, what we are talking about is fewer controls on an activity, business enterprise, to allow the people in that business to do their own thing in the hope that this will encourage diversity and competition. That is what we mean in ordinary plain language when we use the expression `deregulation'. It is what we mean when we talk about micro-economic reform and the Government's agenda for micro-economic reform. What we are talking about there is the same thing-the reduction of controls in a business enterprise or enterprises which would enable people to do their own thing so that there would be diversity of actions by people engaged in that enterprise with a view to encouraging competition, opportunities and, hopefully, development of that industry to the benefit of all people in Australia, to the benefit of those engaged in the industry, by using their own initiative and enterprise, and to the benefit of consumers because the competition would keep down prices and offer people choice.

This country is in desperate need of micro-economic reform. At the top of the agenda should be micro-economic reform in the transport industry, on the waterfront, with coastal shipping and in the labour market in particular. Those should be the priorities. This Government has not had the courage to move into the reform of those areas. However, what it did do was to say to the coalition parties, `You are doing a lot of talking about micro-economic reform. We'll give you an area of micro-economic reform. We'll introduce it into the wheat industry'. The coalition parties have said, `Well, this country's need is so desperate that we will accept that deregulation of the domestic wheat market because we believe so very much in the need for deregulation and', as I have said, `micro-economic reform'. Wheat should not be the top priority because, after all, wheat is an industry which is very much dependent upon the other areas about which I have spoken-that is, the deregulation of the transport industry, the deregulation of the labour market and the deregulation of the waterfront and coastal shipping. Those things should have come before wheat. However, this country's economic situation is such that we are prepared to accept domestic wheat market deregulation. We go along with it.

What we are talking about here is amendments to improve the administration of wheat marketing. Our amendments do not deal with deregulation. Our position on deregulation has been clear from the outset. I will quote, firstly, from a press release by the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr John Howard, on 26 April this year in which he said:
As foreshadowed by both Bruce Lloyd and myself-
Bruce Lloyd being the shadow Minister for Primary Industries and having the primary responsibility in the Opposition parties for the carriage of this Bill-
the Opposition will be moving a series of amendments to the government's Wheat Marketing Bill.
The coalition's criteria for the wheat legislation forced the government to make substantial improvements at the last minute.
The amendments that we are now proposing will further improve the legislation. They do not imply any change to the coalition's decision to support the thrust of the legislation.

We will be moving amendments relating to the underwriting guarantee, membership of the Wheat Board and the ambit of the legislative provisions to override restrictive State wheat transport, handling and storage regulations.
This is just as I indicated before. It continues:

In particular, we will be proposing a 95% underwriting guarantee to provide a satisfactory first advance or cash trading option for the Wheat Board. This guarantee will allow the Wheat Board to borrow more and pay a better advance. Should this amendment not be carried, we will review the level of the underwriting guarantee on returning to government.
We believe that the membership of the Wheat Board should be adequately representative of the industry and, in particular, the Chairman should be a wheatgrower at the time of appointment.

Mr Howard then made reference to some other amendments. It has subsequently been suggested that under the new leader, Mr Andrew Peacock, there has been some change. Let me assure the Parliament that that is not so. Indeed, on Thursday last, 25 May, Mr Peacock made a personal explanation in the House of Representatives, in which he said:
. . . the course of action outlined by Mr Howard on the attitude of the coalition to the wheat legislation has not and will not be changed.
In another part of his personal explanation he said:
And so I repeat, Mr Acting Speaker, there is no change in attitude of the coalition to the wheat legislation.

I hope that that matter has been put aside, and that it is understood that there is no change in our approach. We are not opposing the deregulation of the domestic wheat market. Our amendments that the Committee of the Whole is now considering do not go to the question of deregulation of the wheat market but go to the proper administration of the Act and the sale of wheat both externally and on the domestic market.

There is much merit in these amendments. In particular, I draw attention to the amendments that deregulate the labour market. I put it to Senator Walsh, who happens to be in the chamber, that the amendment to insert after clause 88 a new clause which deregulates labour practices in the storage, handling, transport or sale of grain for export, would be a marvellous amendment and should have been taken up by this Government if it had any real agenda for micro-economic reform. I mention also the amendment relating to the 95 per cent underwriting. After all, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), in his second reading speech, said:

In all years the principal benefit of the GMP scheme has been the backing it provides to enable the AWB to borrow at favourable interest rates and pay a relatively high first advance to growers delivering wheat to the AWB pools.

The significance of what he said is that this is not a question of drawing on the taxpayers of Australia. The whole purpose of this scheme is really to enable the Wheat Board to borrow at favourable interest rates and pay a relatively high first advance to growers. That is the key to all this. The Minister went on to say:
Essentially this means that the AWB's borrowings will continue to be underwritten by government . . .
Mr Bruce Lloyd, during the second reading debate in the other place, said:

However, by having an underwriting of 95 per cent it materially assists the Board to borrow-and to borrow favourably-so that wheat growers can receive a better initial payment and it generally assists the industry at no cost to the Government.

I will not elaborate because I am sure that my colleague Senator Panizza will take that up and expand on it. But these are matters that should be adopted by the Government. At this stage I say to the Government that, although it has listed all of the amendments that it is rejecting, it should not reject amendment No. 7, which would require the chairperson to be a grower; it should not reject amendment No. 8, which would require there to be five grower members; it should not reject amendment No. 11, which relates to the non-application of the Trade Practices Act to pools-that would assist marketing of wheat by the Wheat Board; it should not reject amendment No. 17, which would put in a 95 per cent underwriting provision; it should not reject amendment No. 18, which would delete the sunset clause in relation to the 95 per cent underwriting; and it should not reject amendment No. 20, which deals with the levy money raised.

During the almost final stages of the debate on the Wheat Marketing Bill, I ask the Government whether it is prepared to accept any or all of these amendments that I have listed. I understand it has rejected a large number of them-all of the ones previously put by us. At this stage of the committee debate on this Bill, I make a final plea to the Government to accept amendments which I have listed. I will repeat them for the benefit of the Minister and the advisers. They are amendments Nos 7, 8, 11, 17, 18 and 20.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating the Wheat Marketing Bill, which was last in the Senate on 10 May. SPEECH.PARA: At end of the motion add ``, but the Senate:
(a) deplores the Government's betrayal of the wheat farmers of Australia;
(b) condemns the Government for weakening the position of the Australian Wheat Board as a strong trader in the domestic market; and

At the conclusion of the second reading debate on the Bill, all members of the National Party of Australia, with one exception, voted for that amendment. Subsequently we crossed the floor to vote against the second reading of the Bill. The one exception was, of course, quite understandably, my colleague Senator Boswell, whose position at that time, and indeed now, as a member of the shadow Cabinet precluded him from such action.

As Senator Lewis has spelt out, the Bill was then amended in the Senate in a great many particulars, some obviously more important than others. In due time the Bill went to the House of Representatives, where the Government, on 23 May, accepted some of what I would say were the more minor amendments for the most part-in fact, I think entirely so. There was a useful tidying up of some elements of what has always been since its introduction into the other place, an extraordinarily defective Bill-a Bill to which the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) himself had to introduce some 39 amendments on the day it was taken for consideration in the House of Representatives. It has again been subsequently amended as a result of action in this place.

Having considered the Bill afresh in the House of Representatives on 23 May, the Minister then issued a most minatory letter to all honourable senators, and I would like to quote somewhat extensively from that letter. It is an extraordinary letter to be issued by a Minister of the Crown to all honourable senators. He began by saying that the House that day had passed an amended `Wheat Marketing Bill' by rejecting a number of Senate amendments. He said that the amendments, that is, the ones rejected, `can be portrayed', and he chose his language carefully, `as allowing the Board to ignore the Australian Constitution'. He did not say that they actually do. He said they can be portrayed as producing that outcome, as allowing the Board to ignore the Australian Constitution, `to abuse its market power'. Again, he did not say that the amendments would actually allow the Board to abuse its market power; he said they can be portrayed as allowing it to do so. He continued:
. . . to risk having people on it who are not the best available, and to expose the taxpayer to the risk of 95 per cent underwriting.

Of course, the Minister is perfectly well aware-nobody knows better than he-that there is no risk whatsoever in 95 per cent underwriting at the present time. The Minister went on to say, in the third paragraph, which I shall quote in toto:

These are all unacceptable to the Government. If the Senate insists on these amendments, there will be no Bill passed, and the sunset clause in the existing Act will be triggered on 1 July. This means there will be no underwriting of the 1989 crop and the Board would suffer a severe crisis of confidence-
I interpolate that that includes confidence on the part of the financial markets, upon which the Board is dependent for its borrowing activities in terms of financing the first advance and so on-
as its very existence after 1991 would be at risk.
The Minister went on:
The Senate must pass the Bill as it now stands.

If a letter of that kind had been written by someone outside the Parliament threatening honourable senators in that manner it would be regarded as an extraordinary abuse of privilege, but the Minister has his own privileges, of course, and I cannot raise that question. I simply want to put on the record that it is an extraordinary letter, and extraordinary action for the Minister to have taken. I want to take up the next paragraph because I want to put to rest what I can only assume to be diversionary charge that the Minister raised in a subsequent paragraph. He said:
. . . so any attempt to use these amendments as a back-door attempt to sabotage domestic wheat market deregulation will not work.

There never was any attempt from the time the Bill left this place on the evening of 10 May-it may have been the early morning of 11 May by the time it actually left here-to sabotage domestic wheat market deregulation because, as my colleague Senator Lewis has very clearly spelt out, that matter is no longer in contention. Indeed, the only sentence in the Minister's letter with which I thoroughly agree is the penultimate sentence, in which he says:
The issue is no longer about deregulation-that was settled . . . two weeks ago.
Of course, the Minister was correct in making that statement. He concluded:
I trust that you will be able to assist the wheat industry by ensuring that the Bill is passed in the Senate.

That is precisely what honourable senators on this side of the chamber have been trying to do-assist the wheat industry. The Minister is quite correct in saying that the issue in this Bill as it now stands before us is no longer about deregulation, as Senator Lewis properly said; it is about making improvements in the Bill as it now comes to this chamber with a view-to pick up the Minister's own words-to assisting the wheat industry, not for the sake of picking out some favoured son of the Opposition and saying that that industry should have particular favours but simply to apply some commonsense to the piece of legislation before us so far as it affects the activities not only of the 46,000 wheat farmers in Australia but of all those dependent upon them including, if I may say so, those in their immediate families as well as those in the settlements and country towns of which their activities are the focus.

We believe that even at this late stage it is possible, while not asking the Minister or the Government to accept anything unreasonable, to assist the wheat industry in the four matters which Senator Lewis has referred to. I will not weary the chamber by repeating them because we are pressed for time. It should be possible for the Government, even at this late stage, to say, `We are not so filled with venom or spleen or animus towards the wheat farmers of Australia that we continue to insist that we will not alter a jot or comma of this Bill before us tonight'. If that continues to be the Government's position, that will undoubtedly be the interpretation placed upon its position. I repeat that it has nothing to do with deregulation. It has to do with what is or is not to be considered a fair-minded approach by the Government towards the wheat industry of this country, the matter of deregulation as such having been settled.

I say to the Minister now at the table, the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, that he and his colleagues I hope will consider-it is certainly a matter they should consider-what is to be the spirit or the tone in which this debate is concluded. What is to be the final attitude of the wheat growers in this country, leaving the Opposition aside, towards the actions of the Government? Are they to be convinced, as I think so many already are, that the Government has been motivated in its whole approach to this matter by animus, by spleen, by a feeling of antipathy towards this industry, for reasons which I have neither the time nor the desire to go into? It was with the objective in mind of assisting the industry that Senator Chaney, Senator Lewis, my colleague Senator David Brownhill and I-this is a matter of public report; I am not divulging any confidence and I have no intention of doing so-called on the Minister Mr Kerin, at 6 p.m. last Monday for the purpose of what I think it is proper to call an exploratory discussion with him. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is worth noting that we are debating a motion from the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) that the Committee not persist with 15 amendments, including the most important amendments which were sent to the House of Representatives from this chamber when we last debated this legislation, and that the Senate accept some half a dozen altered amendments, the alterations being of a minor nature but close to amendments which the Senate passed. I say that because what we have heard from the Opposition so far has simply been a series of questions and pleadings to the Government. I still do not know what the Opposition's view on the motion is. The motion is about whether the Senate will now lie down and die on the issue of the Wheat Marketing Bill 1989; that is really the question before us now.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I make any more remarks, I will say that the Australian Democrats will not lie down and die on this one. We will vote against the motion and call a division. I say that because it might be helpful to those people in the Opposition who sit behind the two spokespeople who have already spoken and who perhaps do not have the faintest idea of what is going on, with the exception perhaps of Senator McGauran and his National Party colleagues who are in the chamber at present.

We do not believe that the Senate should lie down and die on this matter. It is for that reason that, in the absence of the Government's having done so, we took steps at the beginning of this week to get this legislation debated in this last week that the House of Representatives is sitting in order that the Senate could continue its push on behalf of the wheat industry of Australia and get the legislation back again to the Government in the House of Representatives and persist with the amendments in line with statements that have been made by Opposition leadership of one kind or another in recent weeks.

I believe the three most critical amendments are the amendments which ensure appropriate grower control and representation on the Wheat Board; amendment No. 7, relating to the chairperson being a grower at the time of appointment; and No. 8, which provides that five of the members of the Board should be wheat growers. Those amendments fall into the first category which the Democrats consider to be crucial. It appears that the Government has not been prepared to concede even one of those. It seems extraordinary to the Democrats that in a piece of legislation in which the Government is saying that every wheat grower in this country is a capable marketing entrepreneur and therefore it will free up the market and deregulate-the Opposition is saying exactly the same thing, or has been until now in pursuing this amendment, but at least it is consistent in terms of grower expertise-the Government also says that the growers do not have the expertise to be on the Board. That is an absolute contradiction in terms.

If we look at the top 500 companies in Australia, we can get some idea of how the Board has been run in the past under these circumstances, with grower chairpersons and grower control. We might also get some idea of why this deregulation or privatisation push is taking place in this industry. The Wheat Board is No. 48 in the list of the 500 most profitable companies in this country, with a revenue of $2 billion and a pre-tax profit of $1.7 billion. That is a significant corporation in this country. I point out that its pre-tax profit matches pretty closely that of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and Westpac Banking Corporation, which are in the top five, the National Australia Bank, which is in the next five, and Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd, which is lower down.

Thus, the Wheat Board is a significant corporation which has been run by a grower chair. Of course, it is a corporation in an industry in which another great Australian company has considerable interest. We have seen on television advertisements for a certain Mr Elliott's company which conclude by bragging that it is Australia's only international grain trader. Now he wants to become the biggest national grain trader, does he not? He wants a slice of the action. He is likely to get it here, if not tonight, perhaps tomorrow, which will be very sad for the wheat industry in Australia.

I cannot see how this record of the Wheat Board precludes the Government from accepting amendments which insist that these growers, who with deregulation will have to go out and battle on their own, should be involved on the Wheat Board to the degree that we in the Democrats believe they should be. I urge the Opposition to persist with that amendment.

The other amendments that are particularly important and which relate to this whole area are amendments 12, 13, 14 and 15, which provide for exemptions from the provisions of the Trade Practices Act. The Rural Guidelines discussion paper has been referred to in debate previously. It points out that there is a great deal of concentration in the buyers' camp and an enormous diversity in the sellers' camp. What we are doing here is turning the clock right back and making our wheat industry growers price takers rather than price makers. Part B on `Rural marketing agreements and authorisation' begins with this paragraph:
It is critically important to primary producers to come together when they act as sellers to exert countervailing market power in markets where they may be selling to a small number of large buyers.

Only 11 companies are listed in the field of biscuits, cereal products and bread. If we take out about four of them which are quite small, we are left with a very small field in that area alone. Tens of thousands-Senator McGauran had the number off pat in his speech-of wheat growers will have to compete with those large agribusiness corporations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Forty-six thousand.
—Forty-six thousand was the figure I was looking for: I thank my National Party colleague.
—If the amendments are not accepted, there might be only 30,000.
—Certainly, as my colleague from New South Wales says, the numbers will soon be reduced if this legislation goes through.

SPEECH.PARA: The other important category relates to the issue of underwriting, on which the Government seems to be reluctant. I, too, was astonished by the letter I got from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). I will read the whole of that second last paragraph because it is important that the wheat industry hears this full paragraph. It states:

My colleague Senator Stone, who, apparently, was born on a wheat farm-weren't we all?-spoke some fine words. In spite of those fine words, we are choosing between having a healthy wheat industry and having some wimpish thing that will be eaten up by John Elliott, the US Congress, and all the rest. We can opt for a healthy industry or we can go down the deregulationist path. The choice is there. We can persist with these amendments in the Senate and send them back to Mr Kerin, and tomorrow we pass the extending legislation and send that back.

The Government, or the Opposition, or both, have to face this question of what is going to be lost in all of this. One thing is quite clear: if the Opposition goes ahead with its deal with the Government, it will lose the wheat growers of this country-and well will it deserve to do so. Quite clearly, a small handful of National Party members of the House of Representatives and senators-Senator Bjelke-Petersen and Senator McGauran, who voted against the Bill at third reading, together with Mr Peter Fisher and one or two others in the House of Representatives-have chosen, as individuals, to continue to side with the wheat industry. Unfortunately their parties have not backed them. The parties are more concerned about the survival of the coalition than about the survival of the wheat industry.

I remind the Committee that Mr Kerin's threat not to extend the legislation is significant. Without extension of that legislation we will not have just a deregulated domestic market but we will have killed the possibility of having any kind of organised marketing arm for our wheat exports. That is extraordinarily dangerous. It is about the most irresponsible thing I have ever heard from any Minister. This industry is a $2 billion export earner, currently facing enormous stress on the international market, our friend Dan Quayle notwithstanding. The Opposition will be acting irresponsibly unless it persists with these amendments and joins with the Democrats in opposing this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The broad line on this motion has been well presented by my colleague Senator Lewis. I will deal with the matter on a detailed basis, but before doing so I should say that it is obviously accepted that the domestic market will be deregulated. That is what the Government set out to do, and that is what its agenda was in the first place. But that was the public agenda, which was backed by a number of my colleagues. Unfortunately the Government had a hidden agenda. With deregulation of the domestic market, it attempted to undo a lot of things. These amendments are intended to turn this into good legislation again.

SPEECH.PARA: I personally have always opposed deregulation of the domestic market. That is on public record. I have said so in various places, as well as in my second reading stage speech some time ago. I said that I believed that time would prove me right. Time could quite easily prove me right in the years to come but for the sake of solidarity, I decided to vote with my colleagues that night, and I will be doing so again this evening.

However, there are certain amendments that I believe are cornerstones of this Wheat Marketing Bill. In return for my colleagues' sticking together on these amendments, I decided to accept, in principle, the deregulation of the domestic wheat market.

TALK.START.PARA: —But are they agreeing to it now?
—The debate is not finished yet. If Senator Powell waits, she will see.
—The grain growers want to sleep tonight!
—The grain growers of Western Australia will not sleep tonight anyway. They are so bogged down with worrying about whether they are going to be able to get their crops in.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the amendments on which there should be no giving are No. 2 on intrastate trading; No. 6 on the Minister issuing directions; No. 7 on the grower chairperson; No. 8 on grower representation; No. 17 on underwriting; and No. 18 on transport and deregulation. In the debate in the House of Representatives the Government gave its reasons for being unable to accept these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of them are not very good reasons, either.
—That is right, but I am coming to that.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason given by the House of Representatives for disagreeing to amendment No. 2 on intrastate trading is as follows:

The amendment is an attempt to provide the AWB with powers to trade intrastate in the absence of complementary State legislation. However, the amendment goes beyond the Commonwealth Government's constitutional power and simply cannot be accepted.

I will come back to that point later. If all the States pass complementary legislation, even I will accept the Minister's words. But if they do not pass complementary legislation-and it may be that Western Australia is one of the States that have passed it already, or is thinking of passing it--

TALK.START.PARA: —Our State has indicated that it will.
—It has indicated that it will. I am just taking an example. If it or any other State were not to pass complementary legislation, the whole situation would be thrown into confusion.
—What about New South Wales?
—I am not talking about New South Wales now, but it could happen there.

SPEECH.PARA: If there is not intrastate trading by the Wheat Board, all domestic wheat that is traded beyond the farm gate has to be in a deregulated system away from the Wheat Board altogether. The Wheat Board simply could not deal with it. Farmers will then have to build more storage facilities so that they can handle what they have to sell on the domestic market, or even attempt to provide what is needed on the domestic market in case of drought, or whatever. New South Wales seems to like on-farm storage, but I, as a practical farmer, will not ride it. I consider myself to be an expert in the growing of wheat, and a reasonable expert in selling it. I do not consider myself to be an expert on farm storage-storing wheat in such a way that it can be kept weevil-free, and so on. The farmer has plenty of other things to do, without bothering about that. All intrastate trade will have to be through the private buyer system. More storage is going to be needed, and the more that is traded privately, the greater the down pressure on prices. In addition, there is no flexibility. If there is a drought in Western Australia, the Wheat Board will not be able to sell the wheat back to the farmers in Western Australia. The Wheat Board will have to bring it from South Australia. With the amount of skeleton weed in South Australia, I would certainly not want to see that sort of weed brought back to Western Australia. The Government has said that the amendment goes beyond the Commonwealth Constitutional power and simply cannot be accepted. That is where the hypocrisy comes into this place. Amendment No. 18 on page 7 states:
The Government is already providing substantial assistance to the Wheat Board through its two borrowing guarantees . . .
It goes on to say:
In addition it has broken new ground through provisions in the Bill to exempt the Board from restrictive State regulation of transport, handling and storage.

In other words, the Government says that intrastate trading is beyond its constitutional powers. Yet, in amendment No. 18, it says that it is going to use its own powers and do what it likes to deregulate the State transport and handling systems. How can any self-respecting government put those two together and expect the people to believe that it is genuine?

Amendment No. 6 is a bone of contention. The Government says that it is not acceptable. This amendment provides for the Minister to issue directions. We have been hearing time and time again in this debate that the Government wants the Wheat Board to have more flexibility. It wants us to go out and trade ourselves and do all those sorts of things, but it also wants the Minister to have the power to give certain directions. I do not know what he has in mind, but it will not accept responsibility for any losses that may be incurred by the Minister giving directions. I believe that people should be responsible for their actions. If any wheat growers lose money as a result of the directions of the Minister, or the directions of anyone else, then I believe that the Government should pay their damages.

Amendment No. 7 is not acceptable because it places an unnecessarily restrictive condition on the appointment of a chairman of the Board which could be deleterious to the Board's success in a deregulated domestic market and environment. In other words, it does not regard it as a necessity to have a grower chairman. The Government has already indicated that initially the chairman will be a grower, although it regards this as a transitional arrangement. It has said that in the longer term the chairman should be a person who has the appropriate skills, et cetera. In other words, the Government is telling us that out of 45,000 wheat growers around Australia a suitable chairman cannot be found. I think that is an insult to all wheat growers. If the Government considers the wheat growers of my age group and the age group of Senator Stone and Senator Brownhill-Senator McGauran is too young-to be ignorant in wheat growing and that one of us could not fill such a position, we have sons and daughters who are as educated as anyone else in this place or in any industry or corporation around Australia. It is an insult to our intelligence.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is going to appoint a wheat grower as chairman. He has said that. But he can change his mind.

—That is right. Surely we can produce a son or daughter among the 45,000 wheat growers around Australia who can take up this position. I move to amendment No. 8, which again deals with grower representation. I believe that it is a cornerstone to have five growers on the Board plus a chairman grower; so each State has at least one representative. I believe that Western Australia, because of the amount of wheat it grows, will always have a representative. I am mindful of the lesser wheat growing States which need their own representative-for example, Queensland-to make sure that their interests are looked after.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 17 is the underwriting amendment and the most important. Underwriting has two very important parts to play. One is a guaranteed minimum price (GMP) and the other is so that the Government, as has already been pointed out, can borrow overseas or within Australia at a favourable rate. The Government has decided that it will try to bring the GMP down to 90 per cent and then phase it down further. Borrowing and the GMP have important parts to play. In a deregulated domestic market, the base price will be the GMP. Anyone who is in marketing would not tell me anything different. Let us go to the reason why this Government will not have a 95 per cent GMP. A scaremonger has put it out that the Australian taxpayer will have to foot the bill. In 1986, the worst scenario, they would have had to put up $300m. It is a pity that the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, is not present in the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —He knows about your point of view.

—He knows, but he will not admit that he is wrong. I have been asking questions of Senator Walsh in Question Time for the last two days. He made a statement that in 1986, under a 95 per cent GMP, the Australian taxpayers would have had to put up $300m. The truth is that they would have had to have put up nought-zilch. He cited figures. He did not actually seek these figures out himself. I believe that they were sent over from Mr Kerin's Department to try to confuse the minds of the Australian taxpayers. He said that the Australian taxpayers would have had to pay out $300m. Senator Walsh or Mr Kerin should have known that in 1986 the estimated price at the time the GMP was set was $125.72. There was a final realisation of the pool for that year of $125.50, which was only 22c short of the projected figure and was 98.9 per cent of what had been estimated. So there would not have been one cent paid out with a 95 per cent underwriting. Yet this Government insists, through the Minister, that it did not mislead the Senate. I will continue to press the Government until it finally gets around to admitting it and withdrawing, no matter how long it takes.

SPEECH.PARA: I intend to go to the wire on this. We will not compromise on this. If we compromise we will have to live with the situation for the next five years. I would prefer to go to the wire. If we are going to have a 90 per cent phasing down, then I will accept that for one year. But by the time the next season comes around we will be in government and we will make it 95 per cent then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to start with a quote from Socrates, which was:

SPEECH.PARA: Nobody is qualified to become a statesman who is entirely ignorant of the problem of wheat.

It is of concern that the Minister in this debate on the Wheat Marketing Bill has at some stages actually looked as though he could have become a statesman. The Government's performance over the whole issue of the wheat debate and the way the legislation has been introduced has not been to its credit.
