QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 11 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: On what external bodies is the Department of Transport and Communications represented and for what purposes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Transport and Communications is represented on the following external bodies:
Asian/Pacific Telecommunity (APT)

This body is involved in the planning, programming and development of intra-regional and international telecommunications networks. The Departmental representative leads the Australian delegation to annual meetings.
Association of Australian Port and Marine Authorities (AAPMA)
The Department's representation is consistent with AAPMA's role to promote uniformity of shipping charges between the States.
Australian Road Research Board (ARRB)
The ARRB conducts research into various aspects of roads and road construction. Departmental involvement is a result of Federal involvement in road related issues.
Industrial Design Council of Australia
The council's objective is to promote excellence in industrial design in Australia. The Department represents the Government's interests in these matters.
International Airports in Northwest Committee (WA State Government)
The Departmental representative has observer/technical adviser status.
International Association of Lighthouse Authorities
Departmental representation ensures familiarity with international developments and assists in the development of appropriate standards.
International Association of Ports and Harbors (IAPH)
IAPH is an international organisation established to protect the interests of world ports. The Department represents the Government's interests in this regard.
International Cargo Handling Co-Ordination Assoc. (ICHCA)
ICHCA's objective is to increase efficiency and economy in the handling and movement of goods by all modes of transport. The Department represents the Government's interests in this matter.
International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO)
The Department is represented on the ICAO-Fares and Tariffs Committee which advises ICAO on regulatory issues relating to tariffs, consumer and industrial issues.
International Institute of Communications (IIC)
The IIC is involved in research and analysis of communications policy issues. Departmental representation ensures familiarity with developments overseas and presents Australia's viewpoint.
International Maritime Organisation (IMO) and associated councils, committees and sub-committee
The Department is represented to ensure Australian views on international ship safety standards and marine environment protection are taken into account in forming suitable standards.
International Omega Technical Commission
The Department's role is to provide advice, in association with representatives from other overseas operating agencies, on operating and maintenance costs.
International Telecommunications Union (ITU) and associated National Study Groups
ITU is a specialist agency of the United Nations, dealing with telecommunications issues. Departmental representation facilitates consideration of Australian perspectives.
Land-use Planning Around Airports (WA State Government)
The Departmental representative has observer/technical adviser status.
Marine Law Association of Australia and New Zealand
Departmental representation in the Association provides a forum for exchanging views on maritime law and legislation.
National Association of Australian State Road Authorities (NAASRA)
NAASRA represents the interests of State Road Authorities. Departmental involvement arises from Federal Government involvement in roads funding.
National Maritime Industry Training Committee
The Department's representation is to assist in the development of an effective training program for seafarers.
National Motorcycle Forum
The forum aims to further the interests of all aspects of motorcycling in Australia. The Department's role is to provide advice on safety issues.
National Road Freight Industry Training Committee

This body designs and conducts training courses to develop skills and improve industry efficiency and safety. Departmental representation facilitates consideration of Government interest in these matters.
National Safety Council of Australia (Victoria) (NSCA (Vic.))
Departmental representation on the council reflects recognition of the importance of community search and rescue efforts.
Pacific Telecommunications Council
The Council is established to promote the development, understanding and benefits of telecommunications in the Pacific region. The Department represents Australia's role in this regard.
Permanent International Association of Road Congresses (PIARC)

PIARC fosters progress in the construction, equipment maintenance and development of roads and encourages the growth of road systems throughout the world. Departmental representation facilitates the communication of Australia's viewpoint.
Public Broadcasting Foundation (PBF)
The PBF provides funding to the public broadcasting sector. The Department is a financial contributor.
Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE)
The SAE aims, inter alia, to promote and encourage automotive, aeronautical, transportation and allied engineering. The Department's involvement relates to its transport engineering responsibilities.
Standards Australia and associated standards boards and technical committees

Formerly the Standards Association of Australia this is the major technical standards development body in Australia. Departmental representation is to ensure Government's views and requirements are taken into account in the formulation of standards.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 13 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which countries sent delegates to take part in the 13th Pacific Armies Management Seminar in Sydney from 27 March - 7 April 1989.
(2) What were the names of the Australian delegates who took part.
(3) What was the total cost of the Seminar and what was the cost to Australia;
(4) Did General James J. Lindsay take part in the Seminar and is he Chief of the United States (US) Special Operations Command which involves responsibility for US counter-terrorism and insurgency.

(5) Did the Australian Army's Chief of General Staff, Lieutenant-General Laurie O'Donnell, tell the Seminar that Australia would support Papua New Guinea in any armed conflict; if not, what did he say.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The following countries sent delegates to the 13th Pacific Armies Management Seminar: Australia, Bangladesh, Brunei, Comoros, France, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Kiribati, Korea, Madagascar, Malaysia, Maldives, Mauritius, New Zealand, Pakistan, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Singapore, Solomon Islands, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Tonga, United States of America, Vanuatu, Western Samoa.

(2) The names of the Australian delegates to PAMS XIII are: Colonel R. A. McCluskey, Colonel P. A. Sibree, Colonel D. J. Rowe, Colonel W. J. Crews, Lieutenant Colonel R. J. Breen, Lieutenant Colonel D. Smith.

A large number of Army officers attended all or part of the Seminar as observers and co-hosts. Brigadier F. J. Cross, Commander of the 2nd Military District, was the official Co-Host with Lieutenant-General C. W. Bagnall, Commander United States Western Command. His Excellency the Honourable Bill Hayden, AC Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia and the following senior officers addressed PAMS XIII:
Lieutenant-General L. G. O'Donnell, AO, Chief of the General Staff;
Lieutenant-General E. H. Burba Jnr, Commander, Combined Field Army ROK/US;
Major-General G. D. Johnston, MBE, MC, Commander, British Forces, Hong Kong;
Brigadier R. M. Earle, Brigadier (Operations and Plans), Land Command, Australian Army;
Major-General R. S. Buchan, General Officer Commanding Training Command, Australian Army;
Brigadier-General Kim Song-Jik, Director of Doctrine and Development, Training and Doctrine Command, Republic of Korea Army;
Brigadier M. J. Dudman, LVO, OBE, Commander, Land Force Command, New Zealand Army;
Major-General R. G. Fay, AO, RFD, ED, Assistant Chief of the General Staff-Army Reserve;
Lieutenant-General M. P. C. Carns, United States Air Force, Deputy Commander in Chief, United States Pacific Command;
Lieutenant-General H. Wanasingha, VSV, Chief of the General Staff, Sri Lanka Army; and
General J. J. Lindsay, Commander in Chief, United States Special Operations Command.

(3) Final costings are not yet available, however indications are that the cost of additional administrative expenses was in the order of $304,000 of which approximately $226,000 was the Australian share. Costs for travel to and from the seminar, meals and any other allowances were the responsibility of participating nations.
(4) Yes.

(5) Lieutenant-General O'Donnell did not tell the Pacific Armies Management Seminar that Australia would support Papua New Guinea in any armed conflict. The allegation in The Australian of 29 March that Lieutenant-General O'Donnell had issued a warning that Australia would support Papua New Guinea in any conflict with Indonesia was misleading and sensationalist. Lieutenant-General O'Donnell has categorically denied the claim in The Australian report that he had issued a warning to Indonesia and his response has been published by that newspaper.

In his speech to the Seminar, Lieutenant-General O'Donnell noted that friction between Papua New Guinea and Indonesia along their common land border ``is likely to continue, and it would be difficult for Australia to stand aloof, even if we wanted to, should that tension escalate into conflict.''

There has been no change in Government policy concerning Australia's relations with Indonesia and Papua New Guinea, or in its perspective concerning any border issues between those two countries. Any such issues are a matter for Indonesia and Papua New Guinea to resolve peacefully and through mutual discussion. Australia is interested in these matters because we are a neighbouring country with important relationships with both Indonesia and Papua New Guinea.
